reviewText:
FIRST, I LOVE PBS. NO COMMERCIALS, WONDERFUL WRITING FROM AUTHOR JULIAN FELLOWS. BUT... HE JUST LOVES TO KILL OFF CHARACTERS.  WHY OH WHY DID YOU KILL OFF MATTHEW????
I KNOW, IT THICKENS THE  PLOT, AND THE SHOW WILL WIN MORE AWARDS, BUT I WILL MISS MATTHEW...CAN'T WAIT FOR SEASON 4.

The discs come in plastic snap cases. The discs play fine. The first five seasons had swinging plastic pages to hold the discs. The sixth season stacked all of the discs on a single plastic peg.

Downton Abbey captivated me for several seasons. It was different, unlike any other series I was watching. I enjoyed the entire series and plan on rewatching the show. The locations and scenery and likable characters were great. It's not without its flaws. For instance, in the fourth season I was wondering what Thomas' job was. All he does is stand around, spying on people. Is he the spymaster? In season five I found some of the situations and characters tedious and boring. But overall I liked the series very much.

If you're looking for good stuff to watch consider miniseries like The Astronauts Wives Club (2015), Band of Brothers (2001), Frank Herberts Dune (2000), Frank Herberts Children of Dune (2003), Into the West (2005), Lonesome Dove (1989), Manhattan (2014-2015), Return to Lonesome Dove (1993), Pride and Prejudice (1995), Taken (2002) and The 10th Kingdom (2000), which are all terrific because they have clear beginnings that establish an objective, then strong middles and conclusive endings where the goal is achieved, like a good novel.

Other shows Ive really enjoyed include Battlestar Galactica (2004-2009), Breaking Bad (2008-2013), Cowboy Bebop (1998), Firefly (2002), Game of Thrones (2011-2019), Granite Flats (2013-2015), The IT Crowd (2006-2013), Jericho (2006-2008), Merlin (2008-2012), The Prisoner (1967-1968), Rome (2005-2007), Spartacus: Gods of the Arena (2011), Spartacus: Blood and Sand (2010), Stargate: SG-1 (1997-2007), Stargate: Atlantis (2004-2009), Star Trek (1966-1969), Star Trek Voyager (1995-2001), and The Tudors (2007-2010). I didn't list any contemporary series Im following that don't have an end date yet, not conducive to binge watching from beginning to finish.

If you like reading try some of my favorite fantasy and sci-fi authors: Richard Adams, Palo Bacigulupi, Suzanne Collins, Abe Evergreen, Diana Gabaldon, Hugh Howey, George Martin, Brandon Sanderson, John Scalzi, and Andy Weir.

I always like a mid-series review, just to get my impressions down before the 2nd half of the series alters it too much.  Season 1 was really strong, Season 2 had its own strengths, with the compelling story of the War and the tides of change.  Season 3 faltered a bit, but in a series with this level of attention to detail, a season spent exploring the characters and the estate was not amiss.

However season 4 (2-3 episodes in) has all of the flaws and few of the strengths of the previous 3 seasons.  Everything feels tired and played out, like the concept of hereditary nobility in 1922.

The bad:

-The Bates storyline.  At this point, Bates could be elected Prime Minister and it wouldn't surprise me.  A soldier turned valet turned convict turned butler with a heart of gold whose fatal flaw is that he's just TOO honorable.  Mr. Bates is the saccharine-tablet of this little banquet.  As far as I'm concerned neither Bates adds anything to the storyline at this point.  Simply put, they're walking stereotypes of the honorable servant, and Mr. Bates first name might as well be Job instead of John.  *mild spoiler* have just finished watching the Ep. where Anna gets assaulted by rando guest's valet.  I think the writers were attempting for a Sopranos reference, but they bungled it through laziness.  As with all Bates drama, there's one simple solution that would resolve 20 minutes of wasted screentime in 30 seconds.  Anna calls the police... they show up, arrest the guy, now Bates can no longer murder him in a fit of passion.  Instead, there's a lot of allusion to morals/character/lose women in the decision not to.  It's lazy writing for about eight reasons I can point to.  1) Drama is introduced very randomly.  Whether its Tom and Obrien disliking him, angst over his knee, his crazy ex, the weird murder conviction, prison... it seems like Bates is Job. 2) the actor who plays Bates simply isn't convincing.  I think the problem is that the actor really is kind of a smug douche (no offense) in real life, so there's a tremendous disconnect between that and the Biff Loman he's trying to play.  The writers could have had his character change or grow. 3) Just like with Kemal Pamuk the Turkish Crepuk the rapey butler is a cold, calculating psychopath.  He follows the same pattern of meet, charm, win social approval, and inspire jealousy - then isolate and assault.  He seems to think the same way... that any kind of accusation will be met with disbelief. 5) however, he's just a valet... and Anna is married.  Both those things would cut very sharply against him even in whatever farcical court system existed at the time.  6) even were they decide to keep a scandal quiet, one work from Lord G to the butler's employer kills his career. 7) Now Anna is trying to be noble and sacrifice herself for Job, I mean John... how original.  There have only been 87 times where John has made a hash of things (not telling the police he bought the rat poison months ago?).  Is the dark message here that John and Anna are actually too stupid to exist in Edwardian England. 8) the writers are not that clever.

The Ugly

Lady Mary.  Honestly, she's played out and less interesting than the old Ladies.  What started out as a kind of quaintly charming Jane Austen reference has turned into something offensive to the viewer.  Her speech patterns and mannerisms are worn out, because there's nothing of substance to them (again lazy writing).  Did the writers plan Lady Mary to take more of a role, then realize that they'd cast someone whose acting ability fell far short?  She goes from perhaps a millennial re-imagining of a Jane Austin stereotype into... a Jane Austen stereotype... into a soap opera... into... pure shlock?  Mary is so uninteresting, so insipidly boring, that the most tumultous events barely dent her ennui.  Oh War has broken out?  "I'm tired darling, think I'll rest."  Oh Matthew's dead... "I'm tired darling, I need rest."  Again, the writers are not clever enough for this, but the only way Lady Mary is a little more interesting is if she's a secret laudanum addict (rewatch any of her scenes and ask yourself if opiates may not be the explanation).

Lord Grantham -- he certainly hasn't learned anything from the last decade, except that the Granthams will still keep winning the lottery in terms of heirs, but suffering deaths at an alarming rate.  Heck, the man hasn't even found time to age!  His character now exists as a placeholder, a reminder of the monumental foolishness of a bankrupt nobility.

Lady Cora.  -- a season or two ago, I figured it out.  The actress who plays her really only has one neutral/happy expression... crosseyed and vampy.  Not sure if they wanted to make her stereotypical/cliched American for a British audience, or if she just can't act that well.  There's something really off about her, as if maybe she's taking a milder dose of Mary's laudanum.

('Lady') Rose -- I appreciate what they're trying to do... make her into a flapper, show us how what we find fuddy-duddy was shocking at the time.  It seems they wrote Sybil out and her in, in roughly the same role... but for whatever reason it doesn't work.  She's too vapid, and doesn't have the street cred of being a nurse in WWI.  Rose is purely about hedonism, she seems pretty eager to give up the trappings of nobility.  But all that means is that she gets into trouble and others get her out of it.. much like the early days of Sybil.  Around and Around and back where we started

TL;DR:  stop watching at the end of season 3.  There's no need to witness the decline of a noble house and noble characters due to lazy writing and played out plotlines.

What a wonderful series!!!! All of the characters were wonderful and the story lines with servants,  the Crawleys, and everyone else is amazing! From tears to claps to getting mad, I haven't felt in tune with a series like I have this one. As much as Lady Mary can be cruel, I fell in love with her. Violet and Mary were my favorites, but who am I kidding... I loved all of them. Conspiring with one another to the love stories, I am simplh amazed. For it to be a PBS production, I am shocked that it was this great! If you like time period pieces, this is a great one to watch!

My wife and I started watching this, via Amazon Prime, about 3 weeks ago..maybe 4. We just finished season 4. We've been hooked since the first episode of season 1.

But a question, if anyone reads this.......(mild spoiler alert)
It seems to us that in season 4, episodes 8 and 9 are switched. My wife first noticed that the dates had gone backwards, from 8 to 0, at least in how they are arranged here on AP. Also.... the dates, in episode 8, Edith's baby was already back on England and in Episode 9, she makes the decision, it seems, to go retrieve her. That's backwards.

Anyone else notice this?

Beyond the entertainment value, this series brings up points to ponder.  Change.  Traditions.  Values.  Family.  Justice.  What values do we hold to most tenaciously and why.  As the series continues it seems my interest in each character deepens and even if I don't particularly like them, I at least learn something from them.  Granny is the one I would like to quote most often -- subtle and sarcastic; I love her! She seems fearless in confronting the situations that threaten different family members, something I would like to emulate.
The drama continues and keeps you wanting more. I gave this season 4 stars because I didn't think it was as good as the first three. Still addicting though!

This captivating fourth season of "Downton Abbey" continues the depiction of the life of an aristocratic British family and their domestic servants in the early years of the twentieth century. It is a sweeping period drama by Julian Fellowes, which features superb writing, set design, acting, and development of the story line. "Downton Abbey" is absolutely outstanding, and it is certainly one of the finest television series ever created, and I give it a five-star rating, along with my highest recommendation.

I missed this series when it first came out and have truly enjoyed catching up on it on Amazon prime video. It is interesting to watch the type of life lived at that time in England during and after WWI. Such a division of the classes, genders, races and life styles. It makes me thankful I never lived during that time. The acting is very British and I enjoy seeing the unique humor and attitude of the time. The costuming is excellent and the sets interesting in detail. I am looking forward to seeing the remainder of the series.

I know this review is very late since the show is off the air.  I will say the first three season were pretty good. But when Matthew Crawley (played by Dan Stevens boy does he have some pretty eyes) died the show should have ended there. The next three season were just repeat story lines, with different people and different places.
With many holes in the story, many areas that the average human beings would not react in the way the characters are reacting or do what the characters are doing.

For example. (I like her character and the actress who plays her, but I don't think they made actress Michelle Dockery pretty or attractive in this series) and how is it that all of these suitors wanted to marry her after they had only met her for 5 mins.?  And how is it that Anna fights to prove her husband John innocence of killing his estranged wife but does not want to tell him who the man was that attacked her because she knew John would kill him?
And seriously a pregnant Edith goes off with an aunt to Switzerland for months to have her baby and give it away (to keep it a secret from her parents and Downton Abbey) really?

In the beginning of the series l loved Matthew, quite frankly he deserved someone better than Mary. (Mary's character is harsh and self serving)
Also the relationship with Anna and John started out being a wonderful love story. But by season 4 was on repeat and the characters and relationship went no where.
There is so much to say about the series as a whole but mostly the first three seasons would get 4 or 5 stars and seasons 4-6 a 1 star.

However, I will point out that the writer or writers did a great job as far as writing content for so many lead characters and even the supporting characters.

But, my favorite characters are grand ma ma (played by Maggie Smith) and Isobel Crawley(played by Julian Fellowes) they made the series.
Keeps me in my toes! never know what to expect

I thought this show was going to be as boring as an old English lady drinking tea, but I have been pleasantly surprise.  Surprisingly, the old English lady drinking tea is the funniest person on the show, and I don't mean that in a bad way.  The show, in spite of the boring-looking cover and boring-sounding title, is shockingly watchable and full of interesting drama.  Most importantly, it's a snapshot of the time period between the World Wars that a lot of us don't see.  I can't recommend this enough.

Good writing, directing, and performances. And the setting and costumes are fabulous. One thing that bugged me was how things seemed to go on forever, and then were resolved in moments. The final clash with Mary and Edith had been building for some time, then it was suddenly all over and Mary's all grown-up and mature. Plus, I never really did know why they despised each other so much. I would have liked more oomph there. Also, Cora and Robert were pretty quick to judge ~ ie: when that replacement for O'Brian comes on the scene (her second time at Downton) and sets Anna up. Cora is too quick to believe Anna capable of such pettiness, as is Robert when he later brings the issue up to Bates.

Downton Abby is a classic series that gives an accurate picture of life in England at the turn of the century Pre-World War ll. I always feel like I could step right into either the upstairs or downstairs society and feel at home. I also like the way all the characters grow as the years go by, some setting aside prejudice, others leaving their pride for understanding. The natural way that the love grows between the couples is so charming.

Though it is a romanticized view of domestic labor in that era, I still enjoy the character development, drama, cinematography, costuming, beautiful diction. It's historical fiction like Gone With The Wind, meaning it's more fairy tale than fact written without representing the grinding nature of slavery in the American South or service in the UK.  Yet, there is a more palpable feeling of what he era could have been like and the way WWI shook up the social order.  I love this series and with its flaws, will enjoy it repeatedly.  I am in season four and will savor all the way to the end. Many issues that women faced and still face are shown something short of full horror.  People might not keep watching if it was more realistic and painful.  There is enough heart warming overall.  Great lines delivered by Maggie Smirh  make it good entertainment even without all else.

This is not intense drama insofar as nobody points a gun at anybody.  Its genius is to present sympathetically the very different points of view of  the people involved.  Once again the familiar characters navigate the maze of a changing class system and the changing status of women, in this series between WW's 1 and 2.  The geographical setting is a surpassingly beautiful country home in Northern England in which an aristocratic family in close proximity to their servants progress through difficult times.  The overarching plot is to secure the succession of the noble aristocratic line in the absence of a son, a duty which devolves to a distant and reluctant cousin. The family struggles to accept changing social mores as it affects their daughters, in particular the betrothal of one of them to an Irish Socialist. Thrown into the mix are engaging sub plots and various romances.  The historical setting is accurate, the acting very accomplished and the videography is superb.

I have been an on again/off again fan from the second season.  I came into series in the second season, and watched through the third at that time, but when they killed Matthew and the season ended, my interests moved into other things.  But, having enjoyed the first three seasons immensely, I decided to check back in, as it were.  Unfortunately...
Something has happened this season...the writing is poorer, the situations are far more contrived, and the story-line is just tracking along without thought or plot, other than the most played out pairings and "tying up of loose ends".
Seriously?  Is EVERYONE going to get married and have a happy little life now?  I valued this series for it's relative believability, but this has become rather ridiculous.
On one side, it was nice, in a very juvenile sort of way, to see that everyone is being taken care of and everyone gets a trite happy ending...but I had more respect for this series than that.  Obviously, I was incorrect.  I feel almost betrayed, though I'm not sure that I have a right to feel that way, not really.
But, whether I have the right or not, I'm not a fan of the laziness of the progression here, not to mention the characters are being shuffled off with dispatch...it almost leaves me to wonder who will be around for season 5...if I bother to watch.

For all the negatives, the show is still beautiful, the costumes are period and exceedingly well done, the architecture and interiors are, as always, stunning.  Though the attention to detail about how upper-class life was conducted has very much slipped this season, the echoes are still there in many of the scenes.  Since I was a child I was always fascinated by the Victorian/Edwardian period in England, and this series has given an incredibly precise and thorough view into that world, even if liberties were taken with relationships and realities.
(That ruler...the one that *measures the place settings* gets me every time, lol!)

I am glad to have seen through this season, for the sake of completeness, but I have to wonder if I'm going to bother investing in season 5 at this point, or just wait until it hopefully comes online for free through amazon prime.  I can continue working on my sewing projects without losing anything in either money or time as I complete out the series, so I believe at this time I will hold out.

I'm torn between two and three stars here...there are some high points, and it's certainly not horrible...But the quality I had come to expect is certainly lacking.

Oh the history of it all! Downton Abbey continues to enthrall you in the ever changing landscape that is Early 1900's England. A must see for all history buffs and those who simply love good storytelling!

Set at the lovely Highclere Castle, this shows follows the lives of the nobles that live there and the people that take care of them. This show does an amazing job at giving you insight into both life styles of the rich and those who serve them and does a good job giving equal time to them both.

You find yourself becoming more enthralled with the characters and feel a connection to both the family upstairs and the servants downstairs. This shows takes you through the ups and downs of a changing world in the early 1900's! Great Show! I highly recommend it!

My wife and I have watched all 4 seasons over the past 2 months and have fallen in love with Downton Abbey. I would not say that the stories are gripping nor are you on the edge of your seat; it's not that kind of series. But we like how the writers strike a balance of likable vs. unlikable characters. The actors, sets, scenery, and costumes are top drawer, and the pace is quick. The storylines are intelligent and the dialogue is crisp. You will enjoy the character development as they overcome difficulties and tackle individual challenges. It's just pure pleasure to watch and learn how English aristocracy interacts with their servant staff. Highly recommended.

Awesome iseries, and season 4 fits right in to the totally superb writing, casting, setting, and flow of all the others! No wonder 150 MILLION people, world-wide, are watching this magnificent Julian Fellows story.  If 8 stars could be given.....Downton Abbey should be right up there at #1 to receive such a rating.  Anyone who loves a good story with a wealth of well-developed, fully-rounded characters will do well investing in this stellar production.  And, oh -- has there ever been a richer, more authentic reproduction of the times depicted?  Anyone who wants to dip back into England during the 1920's - 1930's -- here's your "time travel machine" at the ready.  You won't be disappointed with a single misplaced detail!

I just finished viewing season 4 on Amazon Prime.  As I stated in my review of season 3, this is hands down the finest series ever produced on television.  I heartily wish there were a season 7, and a season 8, and a season 9...The lives of the characters are so compellingly presented that their stories and dramas reach into our own lives and teach us how to live a bit more honorably, a bit more civilly, a bit less villainously.  I am used to being transported back in time and held in thrall by an excellently written book, but honestly, a television series has never hit that mark for me.  This one did.  Every episode, every season is absolutely outstanding, delighting, enthralling, entertaining, captivating...well, I just don't have enough superlatives to describe the Downton Abbey series!

The Tudors was the exception as I was riveted to each and every episode, but some more than others  DA has kind of gone down hill as it went and probably just lived it life out as most series do.  Just been an excellent one in many ways, however, and did not want to take that away from the creator or the actors and actresses. Thoroughly enjoyed it all and hope there will be more coming.  ;o)  Glad to see all the pieces available, but not interested in buying CD's, DVD's, etc.  PBS and/or Masterpiece needs to do the download bit and charge or rent like all the rest.  I quit buying the standalone stuff a long time ago as it quickly becomes old technology whereas download is whatever is the latest and greatest and fastest.  The future, not the past. The entire series has been one of the finest and most entertaining television productions I've ever seen.  It is so well researched in an effort to historically reflect the Edwardian time of class structure, from dress, to levels of responsibilities, to customs, to how world events began to change and impact that whole period from the 1910's through the 1920-30's.  The characters seem real so the selection of actors was done with care and each perform their roles with professionalism rarely seen from such a large cast of characters.

I have indulged my love of period drama by watching the British version of Downton Abbey after learning that our PBS offering was only five episodes long and theirs was nine episodes each season.  Apparently, the powers that be felt that Americans would neither understand nor care about how property was transferred down through generations in order for the great estates to remain in tact.  So, much of the main story line, around which the plot was built, was cut out for American consumption.  However, that leaves the finished product with an overall "choppy" feeling and questions that seem to go unanswered.  The British version, to my mind at least, develops the characters more fully, giving them more reasons for the actions they take, therefore making the plot points more tidy and less confusing.  I have been binge watching, one or two episodes each evening before bedtime, and have enjoyed every minute.  I liked the PBS version, but I LOVE the British version!

Downton Abbey is a fairly unique show with an interesting story about the changes in the English upper class in the early 1900's.  I thought it would be stuffy and not entertaining but have found that to be wrong.  The show has a lot of humor if you're paying attention as it is subtle but consistently there with the off hand remarks of the characters that you have to learn to know when they are getting in a good dig as part of one of their comments.  It is educational in the showing of how the upper class estates provided jobs and where the cornerstone of the economy at one time, but the industrial revolution and social change eliminated them as a middle class was introduced.  It isn't a show I thought I would like but once you learn the characters and understand the workings of "high society" it is very entertaining with a lot of drama to accompany the evolution of society that occurred during that period of history.  You have to pay attention to pick up on the wit woven into the dialog of the mostly very stuffy characters, but people are people and they exibit all the flaws and entertaining quirks of modern day if paying attention.  I find it quite entertaining.

When I tried to stream Downton Abbey 2 nights ago on my tablet (the same tablet I was able to stream on before) I was not able to.  Your website changed and I needed to access an app and install it.  I am not technologically savvy.  I was so frustrated I chose to forget it.  At 66 years of age, I don't need the aggravation and frustration level that I feel.  I am intimidated by it all.  I get it...I just really struggle with all the tech stuff.  If it's not simple, I can't do it and refuse to be frustrated by it.  I understand ...It's progress. I tend to wait till a seasons over then buy the whole DVD. But I didn't this time when I read reviews about Anna being assaulted. Thankfully I changed my mind. As always the costumes and scenery are sumptuous But it's the development of the characters that make this show successful Dame Maggie Smith is still tremendous as the grand Dowager But some of the most touching moments are between her and poor Matthews Mum. Lady Mary's emergence from her grief to deciding to take up what Matthew started and work to save Downton is great-nice to see a woman in this time period speak up and be heard. Anna's assault was heartbreaking And Bates tearful realization of what happened is a Kleenex moment We're left with a possible moral dilemma Anna's attacker meets an untimely death shoved into traffic Bates was in London on the day of the death Did Bates kill him? And is it really a crime to end the life of a monster who would not have been arrested for what he did? At the end of it we know Anna would have had no peace until her attacker was dead Lady Edith has a small, though unknown to most of her family, scandal Having a illegitimate child-we learn the child will be coming to stay at a nearby farm Will Edith's secret be kept? Will the father of the child appear? Some characters however seemed to have no purpose Braithwait as The lady of the abbeys maid is barely there then gone again The scandal it seems was a one night stand with Tom but it goes nowhere And of course Thomas the closeted gay footman who broods and make snarky comments, seems to have no purpose. Shirley McLaine reappears and brings Paul Giamatti with her,but neither are given much to do or say Roses introduction as court is a nice piece of history How the upper classes behaved and what made them more superior to others We see technology arriving with electricity, fridges and a food mixer Its well written and funny in the right places As we know WW2 is approaching Will the Abbey survive, will the servants move with the times and leave? I'm truely looking forward to the next season. But still crossing my fingers that Bates and Anna get their happily ever after
Continue to love the show story lines

Somehow after Matthew's death, the lustre of Downton came down by a notch for me. It's become more soapy. Matthew had a star quality to him that is hard to replace. His presence was magnetic with those deep, intelligent and penetrating eyes and sunny smile. His manner of portrayal also was very english in that he held back rather than bare everything. I missed him throughout season-4. It seems that Season-3 tamed Thomas a bit but he's gone off the rails once more. But what a handsome man Thomas is. Season-5 already has gone into the realm of the soap.

Another amazing season accounting the lives of our favorite aristocrats. The season delves into the joys, heartache and realities of shifting into a "modern era" on a personal as well as societal level. Whether related to advancing technology, social norms or self-evaluation, the season masterfully weaves these issues into the characters' lives.

I have watched the entire five seasons of Downton Abbey with my wife. We both love this series and are looking forward to season six. The writing is very good, the fidelity to the spirit of English royalty is unwavering, the acting is brilliant and the series maintains a consistent quality from season to season. We are fans of the series format and have watched dozens of them. Most have tidal ebbs and flows that make for disappointment in some seasons. This series is the exception to that and should you choose to engage yourself in it, you will not be disappointed.

Hugh Bonneville is absolute perfection as the patriarch of the family.  His portrayal of a laird caught between two distinct time periods is impeccable.  He can be quite old-fashioned and determined to have his way, but he loves his family so much that he often gives in. Mr. Bonneville's portrayal of Lord Grantham sometimes made me furious, but he made me cry more than once, too.

The series has me hooked, because I love old houses, vintage clothing and love the cinematography. Not because it's the best thing on TV.

The dialogue, plot and drama too often play out like an afternoon soap opera.

But, both new and veteran actors in this series show how talented they really are, by making a silk purse out of the sow's ear they're tasked with.

I don't know why they try and cram so much into every show, or why the actors are asked to carry forward so many disconnected plot lines, very often ending up with too short, too quickly wrapped up, story lines.

Still, an enjoyable, fun show for a vintage fashion and history lover.

Begins with Mary struggling with the loss of Matthew; similarly, his mother also withdraws into her grief. Friends of both try to get them to rejoin the living. In Mary's case, it would be to help with the management of the estate - especially since she's now a half-owner, along with her father - who resists. She meets another and is tempted to accept his marriage offer, but withdraws - not certain herself why. Alfred the footman leaves to pursue a cooking career after winning a paid training program. Cora's playboy brother in America loses much of his fortune. Thomas Barrow continues his skullduggery - persuading the Earl to hire one of his supporters his wife's maid. And Mr. Bates learns why Anna has been so aversive towards him - and simmers.

What repeatedly amazes me is that those involved focus so much on improving revenues from land owned by the Earl, and no attention is given to reducing serving staff within the household - supposedly the biggest drain upon revenues. Further, while the Earl sloughs off the topic as 'not possible to accomplish' and contrary to his dedication to providing employment for people of the village, he ignores the opportunities presented by frequent resignations and the ridiculously low utilization of the servant staff. The inevitable alternative to improved management - simply selling off Downton Abbey, certainly won't help villagers at all.

Also amazing is the Thomas Barrow's employment continues to survive crisis after crisis, despite non-stop extremely inappropriate behavior and dishonesty - at the very least someone ought to have flattened him by now. Then there was Anna - refusing to identify her attacker and contact the police, thereby creating considerable added complication and the risk that Mr. Bates would take revenge on his own. And finally, it's getting quite tiring by now to repeatedly have conversations interrupted just when they were about to make an important and provocative point.

Regardless, Season 4 did not measure up to the prior seasons, and Disc Three of Season 4 was particularly boring.

Excellent acting and storytelling. My wife and I watched all 4 seasons in about 5 evenings. Since I am from England and know a little bit about the era; I was impressed with the trouble that was taken to be authentic in dress mannerisms and so forth. The stories are compelling and show how all our lives evolve based as a result of war, changing exonomies, social norms and acceptable behaviour. This period changed Great Britain forever and was the beginning of the end of the empire along with those of much of Europe, including Germany and Russia. It was a time of social revolution and changing mores. Downton Abbey does a bang up job of portraying the tides upon which the working class and the upper class rode.
Sumptuous costumes, excellent historical research, interesting dialogue, fascinating characters and often unpredictable story lines.  Love the characters and the settings.

If I told you I thought the series gets better and better - you might think I've forgotten my position in society. Someday I might actually hug or kiss my loved ones but I certainly won't do it until I see them do it on Downton Abbey. I'm thinking I raised my kids wrong too - really wouldn't it have been better if I only saw them once a day. I'm hiring a whole crew of servants so they can fight each other and plot against each other. Oh - and fall in love without ever hugging and kissing.

I got suckered into watching this ongoing soap opera without soap commercials and will likely see it through to the end. I can't tell whether I detest it or adore it.

The characters in the series all seem to have multiple personality disorders, alternating between nice and twisted. Mary is so overplayed as a haughty witch, Carson is a pompous artifact from the 18th century, Thomas is creepy-evil, and the other characters all have their own mental defects fully on display. Only Anna seems to have her heart mostly in a good spot and destined for better days. (Oh, wait. Did she push that rapist into the path of a street car? Jerk had it coming, so maybe good DOES triumph over evil.)

For those believing that the fourth season is just a rehash of the first two: were you asleep while you were watching? Thomas has been undergoing some difficult personal issues and his cousin(?) Edna actually is nothing like O'Brien who was a witch of the first order. Did you not notice that Thomas originally had something on Edna in hopes he could manipulate her but found instead a person of integrity and quiet strength? Yes, the Granthams make assumptions in their dealings with their servants, but they are of a different era than Mary's and Matthew's (RIP) generation.
great....love this series

I think Downton Abbey is captivating and additive.  One cannot help becoming engaged in the lives of the Crowley Family.  The characters are true to form (Maggie Smith is especially delightful), the settings and costuming are a treat to watch.  It reminds one that no matter what the time or place setting, watching how families transverse the joys and sorrows of life makes for an engrossing story.

Season 4 was very good, although I did enjoy the previous seasons more. I did not enjoy the whole "Bates" story, I think they should have been allowed less drama.  As much as I disliked Lady Edith earlier on my heart broke for her and I look forward to see where this goes in season 5.
I really enjoyed the first three seasons, but it seems to have deteriorated into a soap opera with elements that are unnecessary and make it much less enjoyable to watch.

Mostly a disappointment after the first three seasons. Plots seemed tired with little flow or connection to the past. It's difficult to do justice to so many characters. Throughout the entire series, I found Cora to be irritating and one-dimensional. This season was no exception. As always, Bates and Anna--as well as Carson, Mrs. Hughes and the cook--and the delightful Daisy--provided the high points. Mary has turned to ice, apparently. The two males competing for her attention are so insipid, this viewer doesn't care which--if either--prevails. Rose's behavior is so bizarre, it lacks credibility. Also, there are the usual lapses which suggest these series have been edited and not in a good way.

The plot seems to repeat, i.e., things are always going wrong for someone, usually on schedule, largely due to the same bad guy(s). Then they shape up for that person and go wrong for someone else on the same manufactured plot schedule.  The people with power are consistently blind to the bad ones downstairs while they are consistently accusatory toward the innocent, upstairs and down, like they're blinder'n bats.  The direction of the plot seems predictable even as the details vary.  Nevertheless the production is typically English-superb, and the acting is, of course, unbeatable.

The most popular poorly written show ever presented on PBS. Julian Fellowes unimaginatively rehashes stale plot devices. Thomas Barrow has become a most tedious villain.  Frankly most of the characters have become tiresome, especially the aristocrats (Maggie Smith is, of course, the exception.) Time to wrap up the series.

I've been watching the series 2 or more episodes a day for the last few weeks. I liked season four in spite of, let's say, "changes" to the cast. Did some leave because of contract disputes? A bit jarring. But endlessly fascinating. Robert's character shows some real growth and depending, as does the Dowager's. Edith grows up a bit and Thomas remains a jerk, with only the memory of his tenderness toward the dying soldier to give me hope for his change of heart. And Tom Branson has certainly emerged as a real three-dimensional character. So the season was good and I am looking forward to powering through Season Five in the next week or two.

While watching it on TV I was more concerned with watching Mr. Green as he turned and recognized someone, smiled and asked "What are you doing here?" - his last words! What can you say about this fast paced period piece.  During one episode they covered 5 different story lines.  You don't have to wait weeks for a story to come to a conclusion.  The characters are very real and though not always likeable, the viewer begins a relationship with them.  I feel that I know these people.  After 5 seasons, I finally got my daughter to watch a show.  We sat for a whole weekend watching all 5 seasons.  Very addictive. Worth the time unlike so many other shows.

NEEEEEEXXTT.....Season 4.  I thoroughly enjoyed this season.  One of the things I liked the most about this season is that the more interesting stories focused on the staff rather than the family.  I've come to realize the staff have more interesting character arcs.  I enjoy what's going on down in the servants environment more than upstairs.  Still marveling at the impressive sets and costuming though.  For anone who has never gotten into watching Downton abbey, I highly recommend it.  It can seem rather overwhelming with so many characters to follow but that's part of its' charm.  The characters are very real and memorable and the relationships of these characters to each other will leave you wanting more.  Binge watch a season over a weekend sometime.  You'll be glad you did.

We enjoyed all four seasons of Downton Abbey very much and look forward to season 5 very much.  All of the character development and pace of the episodes are excellent, and we had a hard time waiting to see each new episode.  Some of the best moments were the snappy retorts traded between Isobel and Iris.  The ongoing love story between Mr Bates and Anna has been very moving.  We can't help ourselves, and sit spellbound as each new episode is viewed.  All the cast is superb.  Scenery and architecture is incredible.  Definately a well earned 5 stars from us.

I love period pieces and following how characters live and survive within the confines of rank, status and strict rules of conduct. Also, I love the romance and innocence of courtship. Things in present day have relaxed to the point of no boundaries whatsoever and r here's a serious lack of respect. Granted some of these boundaries needed to go such as in Jane Austen's world where if a young lady did not have a good enough dowry, she was destined not to marry well and genteel ladies did not work. So there was no hope of changing their situation. Alas, Mr. Darcys were far and few between. I have to agree with another reviewer in that a lot of the story lines in Downton Abbey season 4 were resolved with barely even a sentence or were not given any screen time at all. I also found myself going back to determine if I missed something. Some story lines came out of nowhere or were barely skimmed over. The writing is very lacking and disorganized. I love this world and many of the characters but the stories need to be better developed. Most importantly I will never forgive them for killing off Mathew twice. I loved Mathew and feel he was part of the glue that held Downton Abbey together. He survived season 2's season finale but not season 3's. I imagine by killing him off it allowed the opportunity for many more story lines as suitors stood in line for Mary, but it destroyed much more than it gained.

It is a very good series, but I can't help but think of it as really just an updated copy of Upstairs, Downstairs, the British series from the 1970s. It covers essentially the same period: Edwardian, the Great War, the 1920s, the parallel intersecting stories of "upstairs" aristocrats and "downstairs" maids and servants. Some episodes are very similar including ones set in Scotland, and at the beach.

All I can say is do not be fooled by some of the bad reviews. I agree that some scenes were there just for the purposes of being dramatic, such as Lord Crowley telling Bates to make sure Anna is lenient towards Edna. And also doesn't make sense Barrow is still in Downtown Abbey, and his character doesn't change. The first few episodes were disappointing with no Matthew Crawley. But eventually, the series does manage to pick itself up. Unlike some others, I thought the Anna and Mr. Bates plotline was pretty good. I am surprised that the show was still able to generate interest even after Matthew was gone. Matthew was the centerpiece of the show along with Mary. All of the actors are fantastic. Love the upstairs and downstairs division. Great show.

I  am  amazed  how  the  writers  can  come  up  with  so  many  twists  of  the  plot.  While  this  is  basically  an  up-scale  soap  opera,  it  does  an  amazing  job  portraying  the  changing  nature  of  British  upper class  and  servant  interactions.  I  think  the  chasracters  are  authentic.  At  the  outset,  the  upper  class  existed  to  be  waited  on  and  "dress for" various  functions,  as  dinner.  This  series  documents how  the  "system"  is  being  forced  to  change.  I  love  the  period cars.  The  dialogue  is  accurate  to  me.  The  characters  are  extremely  well-drawn.  By  the  way,  I  grew  up  in  a  city,  extremely  poor,  yet  I  (as  an  adult),  have  "ridden  to  hounds",  done  more  than  one  "point-to point", and  even  was priviledged  to be "staff",  who  worked  the  hounds,  and  "field-master"  who  managed  the  spectator-riders on  a hunt.  Great Show!

What a great show! It's suspenseful, clever, and provides an interesting glimpse into the lives of a British noble family and their servants in the beginning of the 20th C. Everything is well re-enacted: the decors, the costumes, down to the way people spoke at the time, allowing you to 'travel' in time efficiently. I love watching time pieces for this reason, and DA makes it feel authentic. Yet, it's not just about history: the rise and fall of a family, the plotting and love intrigues are rooted in human nature and very modern for this reason. A must watch!

I'm glad I jumped on the Downton Abbey bandwagon late. I'm able to binge watch episode after episode, season after season, especially during this crazy cold, stay inside winter we're having. This story takes place in a time when polite conversations, table manners and service to others had weight and value. Spoiler alert - don't read this review if you haven't seen the season.  I absolutely love this show, however, this season was lacking on so many levels I had to give it a two star review, although previous seasons were rated at 5 stars.  It felt like half the season was missing - many plot lines and characters introduced with no back story or resolution.  The most annoying aspect was that most of the significant plot lines were never actually shown, just discussed.  Mary is cleared by the solicitor to inherit - announcement made at dinner - this deserved at least one scene of that conversation.  Edith's man disappears, we only see her discussing her conversations with his office with no scenes of such.  She then  goes away for 8 months to Switzerland, we never see any of what would be compelling drama to create a backstory of what happens there for the next season.  Even more annoying is that this whole plot line is AGAIN resolved with a conversation.  Mr. Bates may or may not have committed a crime, which is again reduced to conversations.  Rose justifies a relationship with "It will make Mummy mad!!" - again we never see the conversation ending this relationship between the two characters involved.  I actually thought i had missed some episodes due to the gaps, but with no, there were only 9 episodes for the entire "season."  Television is to WATCH events, not watch them be discussed.
Actors are superb!  Mary is strong.  Edith can hold her own now.  Interesting events keep one wanting to watch more

Just had to criticize a couple of details.
(1) In the court presentation scene, Cora and Rose should not have turned their backs on the king and queen after Rose executed the curtsies and the king chatted her up. Simple rule: it's rude to turn your back on the sovereign, it is not done! Even for a viewer unfamiliar with that rule, the moment when they turned their backs to walk away carried an odd sense of letdown. I'm surprised the director allowed it.
(2) In the ball scene, couldn't they have gotten extras who actually knew how to waltz? Those dancers with pumping arms and excessive bobbing were, well, not very impressive. It would also have been nice if the orchestra had played something more fashionable at the time, like the "Merry Widow" waltz (which would have still been conservative but reasonably modern), instead of an old warhorse.
Those quibbles aside, I loved this extravagant episode as much as everyone else did!

Just binged-watched Season 4. I liked it, was captivated and just had to keep watching. That being said, I do not like "Rose," the young cousin relative, her daffy grin and childish antics were not compelling and the story line with her and the black singer just seemed like pandering. Lady Cora has become boring and predictable. They need to shake it up with her, let some real emotion show through. I tired of her endless graciousness and sweet smiles. It's too bad one of the two sisters aren't more likable. Lady Mary is aloof and the other one is just devastatingly difficult to look at, let alone like. Losing Mathew was a blow to the show after Season 3 but I think the show handled his absence in Season 4 exceptionally well. The show is brilliantly done, what I hope is that as it goes forward that it doesn't lose itself in being politically correct by throwing at us every social injustice angle that every existed. I do not like Shirley McClain's character, nor did I like her brother and didn't care for the side story about him and a brief romantic possibility. I think at its core, the reason people like Downton Abbey so much is that many of the people are decent, just and ever so civil. They need to keep riding that theme and have less of some of the 'side characters' who are just superfluous and plain annoying.

Of course I have been a Masterpiece fan since the first Upstairs/Downstairs from the 70's....some I have followed more ardently, some not at all.  At the end of the third season, I threw a fit and refused to watch anymore (you will know why when you see it), but my daughter watching in the next room finally weakened my resolve after 4 episodes and I am as devoted as ever.  Hope you enjoy and momentarily hate this series as much as I do!

Whenever a series of Downton Abbey ends it takes me days to stop thinking about them as if they were people in my own life.  This series is done with such class and depicts life in that era so well that for the first time in my life I understand how seriously people took one's station in life and how difficult it was to break out of it.  I understand English vs American and why we were such a shock to them.  I love the costumes and the structure of it.  I was even tempted to buy a handbook for the staff in a bookstore the other day just because I never realized how clearly depicted each job was.  It is made crystal clear when a butler is forced through circumstances to become a lowly footman and all the implications of that.  I find it very entertaining and educational.  I wait with anticipation for the next on whenever a series ends.  It is excellent!

I loved the first 3 seasons very much, but frankly, this one is kind of boring in spots and too predictable.

Although this season is full of really sad plot points, it still manages to be fun to watch. Everyone is having trouble moving on after Michael's accident, but Mary's mourning isn't keeping her from exploring her options. Edith's relationship with Michael takes some very interesting turns. Branson struggles to find his place in the world. The kitchen is full of drama, as is Anna and Bates' relationship. Rose is a fun, free-spirit who, much like Sybil, tests the Crowley's tolerance of people unlike themselves. And, as always, Violet is full of sass and one-liners. If you enjoyed the previous seasons, you'll most likely enjoy this one as well.

The drama and struggles and intrigue continue into the 4th season and Episode 9 sets up nicely for next season. Mary is being wooed by multiple beaus, poor Edith continues to face a crisis of her own, Bramson continues to question whether he belongs at Downton Abbey, the crass American relatives have come and gone, and Rose's presentation at court was a glorious event with all the pageantry you could expect. The costumes and sets continue to astonish in their perfection, the older generation continues to resist all efforts to modernize Downton, and Violet (Maggie Smith) still gets the best lines :)

The plots thicken, the costumes are fabulous, the acting is superb, and the pre-WWII time period is a great set-up to showcase that the landed gentry are on the way down while the common folk are on the rise.  Getting Mary reluctantly back into the land of the living after Matthew's death by introducing 3 suitors and placing Edith on a rollercoaster ride with her swain in peril are just plain fun.  Anna and Mr. Bates are always an item of interest, and the entire downstairs staff's lives are developing to support the times that the commoners have more options, much to the dismay of Carson the Butler.  And then there's Branson, riding both sides of the fence, along with Mrs. Crawley.  Downton Abbey is a tour de force!

It is easy to become involved with the characters with all their good and bad traits.  The effective reflection of changing morays and habits of people of the time are indeed eye-opening.

As much as we liked the first two seasons of "Downtown" (as we call it in our family) we always had to take the scripts with a grain of salt. Sometimes they got sloppy, sometimes plot arcs were stretched too for. However, most of the actors are so very good and the plots so fun that we completely enjoyed this silly piece of soap opera fluff. We gave the first two seasons 5 stars without reservation.

In the 3d and 4th season, however, the writers have found a way to make their bad habits more pronounced. The same faults are there (plot holes, gratuitous character inconsistency, ridiculous plot devices), but now they're really annoying. We still enjoy most of the shows (measured not by count, but by elapsed time). Some of the plot holes have gotten big enough to swallow the interstate highway system.

The first 3 and a half episodes of season 4 started out poor and got progressively worse. Fortunately things started improving and it pulled out of the tail spin. They finished up almost to the level of the first two seasons. Still complete fluff, but a lot of fun.

Still going strong after the death of two of the central characters, who in real life went off to pursue other things. Their deaths were so startlingly that you could almost tell that their contract was up and they chose to go.....however, the drama at Downton remains and watching them continue to live their lives is realistic and a strong plot line in itself. The suitors are lining up to pursue Mary all over again and with introduction of some new cast members more issues about class and life changing to the times continue with a new fervor. Also, there is some fun cameos of the royal prince himself, that really highlights how the upper class or "monarchists" view their role.

I have enjoyed Downton Abbey Session 4 very much.  The story line holds interest with the twists and turns of the family as it struggles to move into the  new century and the ways of the world it has moved into.  The struggle between the new generation and those past is only amplified by the struggle to keep the blinders on/not to change.  It happens in neighborhoods, small towns struggling to stay alive by new challenges, all while attempting to cling to values that have brought persons to the point of the day.  "Ever ancient, ever new" might be the phrase that fits this season.  Look forward to moving forward with the next edition!!

Ok, I'm a guy and Downton Abbey is basically a high budget soap opera. But, it's a great one and fun to watch. I like period stuff and the story, the sets and attention to details are terrific. My only complaint about the series is that they push the timeline much too quickly. They could have spent at least a couple of years(seasons) on each time frame before moving on to the next. The series could have lasted a couple of decades if they had slowed it down, but at the rate they are going, they will be in 2015 and still looking like they did in 1914!

Julian Fellowes has accomplished something difficult: he's created a truly sympathetic landed clan of English nobility that, though flawed and privileged, aren't blind or intractable. Fellowes manages to portray the real warmth and affection between the kindly Crawleys and the staff that serves them - without avoiding the hostilities that arise among the working class.

This fourth season finds Cora and Robert Crawley stepping back to give their surviving daughters room to grow. Mary must strike out on behalf of her son, George. Edith finds herself yet again unlucky in love when her editor and suitor has gone missing in Munich. And Edith also must cope with an enormous difficulty that will change her life forever.
downstairs, the staff tries to hide the brutal rape of one of its ranks.

What a wonderful show about the early 1900's England; the struggles of a prominent family during and after WW1 proves how quickly life at that time had to evolve and adapt to survive and keep their estate intact. The dramatic and scandalous story lines within the family and staff will keep you quite entertained.

Every season of Downton Abbey has its special delights, and Season 4 is no exception.  The younger set characters march excitedly into a new post-WWI Britain world, one where many traditions treasured by Downton's elder generations suddenly mean little or are discarded altogether.  The facial expressions and genteel but emotionally charged outrage of Lady Violet Grantham and her son Lord Grantham's make these episodes thoroughly entertaining and instructive all by themselves.  Luckily there's much more to enjoy too.  I can't wait for the next new set of episodes, and I'm likely to binge-watch all four preceding seasons beforehand as a warm-up.  That's how wonderful I think everything about this series is!

Breasts are downplayed in this series from every costume and camera angle and actress portrayal -- no one leads with their breasts; an anomaly in 2014 culture and media. The tea is HOT in every scene. This is the show of the thousand cups of tea. Watch the steam curl and rise from the cup lips. The success of this series proves the maxim to writers, "tell a better story." How else could, in our age of saturation on television with sex and murder and shock value from "reality tv" to American crime series like Law & Order SVU starring drop dead gorgeous model-worthy detectives with form fitting shirts boasting their wares in our age where women's bodies are defined by JLo booty, "Brazilian Butt Lifts" and the oversized bosom of "Big Ang" of "Mob Wives" -- it's astonishing the U.S. is so enthralled by Downton Abbey's flat-chested flat-bottomed girl-bodied female characters who kiss their men with closed lips, and keep us nonetheless wanting to watch more. Narrative fortitude decimates the PR drive need of the shock value hooks of American tv. The main character is the Abbey itself and all that goes on within and around it for generations. The story begins on the day the world learns about the sinking of the Titanic; an apt metaphor for the eventual inability of dukes and earls to support their palatial lives. The pacing and music composition is calm and serene. Plots weave like a long game of chess. The editing is patient and calm, always intercutting back to far shots of the Abbey to remind us that it is the main character. Close-ups of architectural and houseware details underscore this fact, as do back shots of characters; the movement of the dog, the ringing of a servant bell, the dusting of a crystal on a chandelier, the paintings that frame the characters, the fringe of the canopy of the Earl's bed. The magic lies in the story, the plot, the interaction of characters. And we can't get enough of a great story. Not now, not ever. The acting is flawless. America's greatest actors take part; Shirley MacLaine and Paul Giamatti. As does Britain's greatest: Maggie Smith. My favorite character? Daisy, by far. forever, Annie Annie Lanzillotto author of "L is for Lion: an italian bronx butch freedom memoir" SUNY Press and "Schistsong" BORDIGHERA Press www.annielanzillotto.com L Is for Lion: An Italian Bronx Butch Freedom Memoir (SUNY series in Italian/American Culture) Schistsong (Via Folios) Blue Pill Carry My Coffee (Live) Eleven Recitations

Frankly, I'm still in the process of watching the season, so my review is but four episodes worth of content seen.  And what I've experienced is getting better writing & performances from lead characters each week. Continues a great series. We are disappointed that our binge watch of the first four seasons is over. The show has a few rough patches, and you don't always like what's happening, but it's always interesting. This season had us seeing Anna in some new lights, and the actor was stretched in some new ways. She had always been likable and one of the best people in the series, this season she is forced through some troubled times. I like the fact that this series gives full play to both the peerage and the servants, and it helps us to understand the full context of their world. The timeframe of much social change is quite interesting, and multiple issues are handled pretty skillfully. I am glad we watched the series, and look forward to the upcoming season.

Love the show as always. So glad O'Brien left. I mean, she nearly killed her lady out of spite, did have her lose a child & got away with her bad behavior as always. Couldn't stand her or Barrow. Wish a piano or something would fall on him & crush him. Really, who acts like that? What does he need all that scheming for? Was hoping he'd die in America & never come back. Why do the downstairs management so to speak never tell the family of a person's bad behavior so they get fired or at least won't get hired back? Barrow was gone, but they brought him back knowing he'd make everyone's life a misery. The brief lady's maid should never have been brought back, she was obviously a troublemaker. Am glad the horrible nanny is gone though, which Barrow did instigate for the wrong scheming reasons of course but she did turn out to be a bad person. I know everyone else likes the drama for the backstabbing, otherwise why would horrible shows like 'Housewives of....' & other shows like that stay on the air, but I don't & downgraded it a star because of that. In real life I'd think they'd like to keep a bit more harmony in their life as life can be difficult enough without backstabbing schemers. Lady Mary is certainly nice enough but really every man just pines for her. Is it just the money & her charm or as my husband put it 'does she have magical lady parts?' Feel sorry for Edith of course as she doesn't have 10 other suitors hanging around she could choose from, like her sister does. Felt horrible for Mrs. Bates, she was in the kitchen, she should have knifed her attacker; & then to just let it go? You know he's done that before & will do it again. I can see not wanting your husband to kill him & get the noose for it but Lady Mary could have gotten him fired right away, just like she was going to when she found out. Hope they can keep the Abbey going, can't wait to see season 5.
Love the show, but I'm still upset over Matthew's death.  I know it was his choice to leave.  I almost wish they would treat it like one of our soap operas and bring him back.

Although the series is permeated with echoes--sometimes more direct--from "Upstairs/Downstairs," the production values are astounding.  What's also amazing to me are the actors, all of whom are first rate.  "Series Rot" is starting to creep in, however.  Inconsistencies, plot holes, repetition and double-reversals occur, but, just a guess, this happens with all series that start out with an unknown termination point.  Thomas' behavior is one of the most egregious.  In the beginning he intrigues against staff and family out of bitterness, then, through a great deal of effort by the writers, create a credible redemption.  But then he falls again with no explanation.  Perhaps the writers thought the audience liked an evil Thomas, or maybe they needed to have someone inside to wreak havoc and thought better to have an evil Thomas than to introduce another evil character (although there was a half-hearted attempt to do so).  Still, this is the season which sees some of the best writing ever involving Mary.  Also, watching the inconsistencies in Lord Crawley's character sometimes makes me wince.  Sometimes strong, sometimes whining, but increasingly petulant.  I realize the writers are trying to depict the descent of the peerage concomitant with the rise of the middle class, but at least give him some consistent dignity.  Strangely, though I feel that I should be cheering on this merging of the classes, I also find the story less compelling.  Crawley's opposite, Mr. Carson, thankfully and perhaps quixotically, remains consistent yet interesting.  For me, the butlers in both series are the most compelling characters.

I was not a fan of the more graphic scenes this season.
Excellent story line, production, direction and acted.

The cast, as usual, is marvelous.  The story has moved along nicely, with Lady Mary back to her usual rather chilly exterior.  Edith is has finally grown the start of a backbone.  The "Grand Dame" and Mrs. Crowley are becoming bosom buddies, much to the surprise of both of them.  Tom is still in a state of flux, does he or does he not belong at Downtown, should he go to America?  A young attractive school teacher has been added into the mix...love interest for Tom?  Mr. Barrow is up to his usual self-serving tricks, although with Mr. Mosley's encouragement, the new Lady's maid is not proving to be his ally in "digging up the dirt".  He threatens to bring up her past.  Rose finally has her coming out, and with some antics about recovering a love letter written by the Prince regent, he shows up and dances the first dance with Rose..sure to be cause for hers to be the most talked about season!  Season five can't come soon enough for me, although as they progress into the "modern" century, their problems will be of a much different kind.

With Season Four, Downton Abbey really pushes the drama--and stops really having anything to balance it out. Several of the characters have life-changing events happen which push them to their breaking points, which is interesting from a character-study perspective. The other seasons have done that as well--but they've also advanced the plot more than Season Four has. I found it more than a little frustrating, but your mileage may vary--I know plenty of people who absolutely loved this season.

All the actors carry their parts very well and I'm drawn totally into the story each time I see more episodes.  The costuming is gorgeous;  the Abby itself brings me joy just to look at it - so beautiful.  Recommended very highly for extremely intelligent, fascinating and entertaining television. This program subtly, but clearly, promotes a liberal agenda. This is not at all surprising considering it comes from PBS - the 'taxpayer funded outlet that has become a left-leaning channel for the liberal viewpoint.' The program favors divorce, feminism, adultery, etc. The program also directly insults Catholics, presents a false view of charity, and subtly (or not so subtly) promotes immorality. It is basically liberal propaganda disguised as entertainment. The more episodes you watch, the more you take in the liberal message. I wish someone would counter this rubbish with a decent program that upholds morality, marriage, and traditional family roles.

I found myself wavering between wanting to watch each episode spaced with lengthy time between and back to back.  With lengthy spacing, it would be longer before Season 4 was over. With back to back, I could satisfy my hunger of finding out what happens next. I am so happy that I have been able to see all the seasons on my Kindle. Now, I'm caught up and am looking forward to more. I do not have cable. I refuse to get cable. I haven't had it in 10 years as I was sick and tired of the "least common denominator" advertising and programming. My parents suggested I watch this series, so I put it on my watch list and there it sat for months. I had no intention of watching it anytime soon.

Then one night I was looking for something to watch...preferably something short that I wouldn't get sucked into very much. I started on season 1, episode 1. By the end of episode 1 I can fairly say I was hooked. I watched 2 episodes a night until I finished with season 4 just this past week. What a phenomenal series. Excellent acting and a generally interesting storyline.

Why are the Brits better at film than we are now? Because we have gotten away from the basics I believe. The box office hits require explosions and C. G. imagery (Expendables 2, Transformers.) Sometimes this makes for an excellent movie (Inception, Avatar.) But more often than not, it leaves me wanting. There can be no substitute for a great director, great acting, and a great story.

Each character is so human - it's not as though they are acting. Love it!!

Season 4 picks up 6 months after the shocking end to season 3 with Mary struggling to find her way and Anna suffering from a terrible crime. Season 4 was darker, and while the writing remains clever and witty, it seemed subsumed by  the more difficult plot elements. Additionally, the women seem weaker in this season. Rose is an annoying child; Lady Grantham seems terribly stupid, believing anything the servants tell her; and three suitors element with Mary had me rolling my eyes. I have simply never found her all that charming, and I can't understand why so many men are tripping over themselves for her. Overall, a bit of a disappointment, but I'm still looking forward to season 5!

I have just watched episode 2 of season 4. I am fascinated by the fact that so much has changed yet so much remains the same, i.e. technological, economic and social change affects people very similarly whatever the period of history, at least since the Industrial Revolution (approx. 1770). It has been an idea somewhere in the back of my mind for a long time, but after reading "Lost Illusions" by Honore de Balzac, watching "Downton Abbey" and reading "The Second Machine Age" by Erik Brynjolfsson and Andrew McAfee (the age of Artificial Intelligence), the vague thought has turned into a concrete block. It seems as if the human race is being forced to run on a treadmill towards something better. But the question is, what is better? I think I'm turning into a Luddite.
Of course, this brilliant drama is as perfect in every historical detail, every bugle bead, bucolic English countryside, and vocal accent as could be. All of the people who have worked so hard and with such intelligent and creative devotion to produce "Downton Abbey" deserve a standing ovation (and unimaginable wealth). Triple Bravo!.

I was hesitant to start watching this show at all, but all of my regular shows are over for the summer and I love the convenience of streaming video. Wow - what a fantastic show! I binged watched all the way through to the end of season 4 and cannot wait until season 5! The characters are so believable, the writing is terrific (Maggie Smith's quips are outstanding), and the setting and costumes are fantastic. This season includes on Mary's grieving and healing process, Edith's personal struggles, and lots of trips to London for a refreshing change of scenery.

Mr. Fellows, sir, what's the rush? We Yanks are famous for our hurried lifestyle, perhaps that's the reason we are so very fascinated with the Victorian lifestyle that you portray so lavishly, but why must the story be so hurried? Surely the family had simple non dramatic days or months, Let them have a day now and then to smell the roses,

Cinematography, script and sets continue to be excellent.  Production, directing, casting and acting are as superb as usual with Masterpiece Theater.  It doesn't (and, very likely, can't) get any better than this.  True cinema quality television that challenges (and consistently surpasses) Hollywood's finest big screen offerings.  Character and landscape scenes from the production are often as exquisite as the  masterpiece oil paintings that hang in the stately home where the series is set. What's not t o love?

Season 4 maintains the drama, in spite of losing a very popular character from Season 3.  In fact, Lady Mary is given a number of suitors to occupy our attention.  And just when you thought Bates and Anna were becoming a boring couple ... well.  Most interesting, however, is how the series moves gradually through the early 20's and you find yourself a witness to the subtle changes taking place.  The women take on a more assertive role while the aristocracy must either change or die.  But for our characters, both upstairs and down, perhaps it often seems a bit too idyllic at times in spite of their ups and downs.  Why else do we find ourselves pining for those days when watching this series? And yet we know darn well we could never really handle the 20's were they to come again.

Downton Abbey never disappoints. Whether killing off main characters when they're at the height of joy and revelry or simply making them just disappear with no explanation, Julian Fellowes has created one of  the best dramas ever to grace the television screen.  Things have taken a bit of turn this season with Lady Mary juggling pigs and suitors and Bates becoming a much more ominous figure. (Remember when you thought there was no way he could have had anything to do with his ex-wife's death?)  Rose has taken the place of Lady Sybil only much more capricious and liberal and Lady Mary and Sir Robert fight over how to manage Downton.  Altogether a great season, but much darker than previous  ones.

I had become tired of waiting for season 5, and so to appease my anxiety til it does,  I decided to re-watch seasons 1 through 4, at a leisurely pace that would carry me through until season 5 is available.  The leisurely pace morphed into the same "must watch-every night", two or three episodes. as I was drawn back inside the multiple story lines and plot twists that had made me an "abbey maniac" the first time around.  Wonderful story-telling, superbly acted, I have only three more episodes of season 4 left to watch and still 4 months away from season 5!  Ah, but thanks to the consummate skills of writer-producer Julian Fellows, I'll just switch over to watching "Monarch of the Glenn", which is almost as wonderful as Downton Abbey, and, if I carefully control myself, doing so will get me through to the Abbey, season 5.

If you are a fan of romance and period dramas, you can't help but fall in love with Downton Abbey.  I stumbled on this show by accident in its first season and I've been a fan ever since.  Wonderful acting and a marvelous glimpse into the disintegration of the aristocracy.  The US Season airs about 4 months after the UK which I can't stand, but I look forward to the new series every year.  Only about 8-9 episodes per season varying from 1-2 hours.  Nice to see Elizabeth McGovern in a role that seems tailor made for her.  Maggie Smith has me in stitches EVERY episode as the Dowager Countess. The special appearance of Shirley MacLaine was also a treat.  Enjoyable television with always a little touch of the risque.

Love this show! It's so fun to look back into history and get a glimpse of how life might have been for people just a mere 100 years ago. My how things have changed! It's so nice to see a simpler time when technology was at the brink of discovery and the "modern" world was becoming all the rage. A time when the women were actually courted over months, even years time and much more effort was exerted in the pursuit... When to spend an evening with family by the fire chatting, playing cards or listening to music was truly quality time. But of course there's plenty of scandal to go around too!
What a delightful escape from a hustling world!

So many people dismiss Downton Abbey as nothing more than a soap opera in period costumes.  Not true.  It is the well-told, historically accurate chronicle of profound social change whose ultimate implications we in the 21st century are still grappling with:  the politics of privilege vs. the politics of envy.
love it

Unquestionably one of the best tv series I've ever watched!!! Excellent writing A++++, Great period costumes A++++, Excellent setting A++++, Great directing A++++ and last but not what so ever least, the actors, each and every one, played their roles PERFECTLY!!!!
No vicarious violence, no pyrotechnics, no special effects - just one of those rare situations when a synergy forms between all of the elements - acting, setting, costumes, script and directing, to bring to life a drama about people and their daily challenges. Each member of the cast portrays their role with realism such that the audience cares about their daily lives. It's a story about people living in a time when England was transitioning into the early twentieth century and the how each individual regardless of class had to adapt to a new era.
I will be most saddened when this series ends... not for the loss of one central character but for each and every member of the cast who through their excellent acting brought to life their roles such that just living their lives, I became immersed and empathetic to their hopes and dreams.

This is one of my favorite series. The series shows mastery in its interweaving of stories concerning the lives from both the aristocrats and the servants. The character development is high as well as the hard work that goes behind the 'authenticity' of the historical period..the dress, the locations, culture and the 'language' of the characters.  Who would have guess that a 'bread and butter' note is an expected written thank you note by a guest for a hosted dinner (usually sent within a day of such an event). You are definitely transported to an earlier era, mostly gone. I hope this series goes on for years to come.

Season 4 begins with Lady Mary dealing with widowhood, both emotionally and financially. It ends with the London Season.

The family and servants continue to deal with changing times.

There are the usual incredible costumes, props and sets. Of course the Dowager Countess continues with her zingers.

The good news is no beloved major characters are killed off. The bad is a very disturbing sexual assault.

The season finale includes a great sub-plot involving the Princes of Wales, the future Duke of Windsor.

Like the earlier seasons, streaming on Amazon Prime allows portable access on multiple devices.

This season did pretty well, despite being a little bit rocky, as they tried to rewrite the story without Matthew (Dan Stevens). I didn't love the plots as much, and some of the new characters (and returning old ones) got on my nerves, but other things about this season were wonderful! Mrs. Hughes becomes more out spoken and viewers are exposed to a darker side of Mr. Bates that is quite intriguing. Maggie Smith's character has many wonderful one-liners, same as usual, which kept me entertained throughout. Mary goes through the mourning process and we see her emerge from it stronger, her sharp tongue in tact, and a desire to pursue new relationships as a means to preserving Downton for her son, George. Tom also dallies in new relationships as he struggles to determine where exactly he belongs. Forever banned from the country he loves, he continues to reside with the family of his beloved, deceased wife. He loves them, but doesn't feel that he truly belongs with them, and that as long as he stays, his chances of starting a new life (and maybe even finding a new love) are compromised. The women they paired him with were AWFUL. I thought them both to be whiny, annoying, and overbearing. Plus, all they do is try to make him feel guilty for living at Downton and enjoying his extended family. He already feels bad enough without needing their snide remarks. They just kicked him while he was down, and I hope the writers will not marry him off to such a girl! He deserves better. As always, it's all more drama and heartache for Edith. This season sees her making one poor decision after another, and suffering the consequences. The way the season ends, things are not set to look up for her in season five. In any case, it was a good edition to the series, and I can't wait for season five to start!
