BUYER BEWARE!!!  We bought this as a gift for our daughter.  Upon giving her this gift we began watching the series.  The production is outstanding but that doesn't get you very far if a disc is defective.  Half way through the 2nd disc we were unable to play the disc.  After first attempting to play the disc in a DVD player we then attempted to play it on a computer.  The computer reported that the disc was damaged.  When I attempted to return the disc, Amazon said we were a few days past the return window.  Bottom line:  Amazon left us high and dry. Regardless of the horrible ending to Season 3, from which I eventually recovered, I still really like the story of Downton Abbey and all of its denizens.  I continue to be enthralled by the scenery and costumes, but am becoming a bit disinterested in the lives of some of the characters.  However, in my opinion the acting remains superb, and -- for the most part -- I enjoyed watching Season 4.

Okay; "for the most part", but not entirely.  I have to say that it really changed the dynamic of the show for me when Matthew went to that Great Law Firm in the sky, and then we had to watch Mary heal from her grief by first acting like her and Matthew's baby was a complete stranger to her, then by immersing herself in the estate's business exploits and fending off a stable of suitors while only being a mother in seemingly 30-second increments.  Her storyline wasn't a complete disaster, and I still love Lady Mary, but this was a bit hard to swallow...

... as was the constant angst displayed by Tom about being a part of Downton.  We get it... you're an urchin from Dublin (or wherever) who doesn't belong to the aristocracy so you're going to continue to make poor decisions regarding moderately attractive gold-digging women.  That's great.  Look... Tom is one of my favorites, so please don't ruin him by making him so WEAK and then attaching him to some weaselly broad.

Anna and Bates.  I'm not a big fan of these two anymore, but I thought the tragic event was kind of oddly written/handled.  Not badly done, but the resolution/Bates finally finding out was somewhat awkward.  And now we have the inevitable "did Bates really do it??" storyline.  For the record, I hope he did do it.

Cora still sounds and acts like Carole Channing.  It's maddening, and it sets my teeth on edge to listen to her.

Poor Edith... will she ever catch a break?  Sheesh.

The only unbearable part, to me, was Shirley Maclaine being brought back as Cora's artless, tactless, obnoxious, arrogant mother.  As though the character isn't already written to be an unlikeable woman, they had to cast the most annoying, no-talent, abrasive has-been to amp up the unlikeability to epic levels.  That's just my opinion -- I fast-forwarded through old Shirley's scenes, and will continue to do so as long as she's screeching around the set.

The remaining story lines were good.  Of course, there was some room for character growth here and there (hello, Thomas), and I hope that the show gets back on track with Season 5.  I think that what's needed is the same sense of a personal relationship between writer and characters that we saw in seasons 1-3.

Downton Abbey has proven to be one of the best written shows in many years. With deep characters, evolving storylines (in part to the time period of the story), and likeable actors/actresses it has created a crack-like desire to see the next episode as soon as one finishes.
HOWEVER, in the desire to drum up more viewers or to prevent the drama from becoming flat, the commonly referenced rape scene pushes it beyond what was necessary for the show. There are some pathos that need not be depicted as vividly. I love the ability to watch these shows without commercials but a warning should have been present besides the standard TV-14 warning.
I recognize that people don't want to have the story spoiled.  But a sexual abuse warning was needed for the manner in which they depicted the events of Season 4 Episode 3 was too much. Any person that has dealt with rape first hand or had a loved one live through this trauma knows this impact. I am not advocating the removal of serious, deep life issues in television for more mature audiences. I do believe that more tact and discretion should have been taken for this specific conflict.

I have watched every episode of Downton up until number 4 of season 4 and this is where I call it quits. The decrease in quality has become glaringly apparent. I'm not talking about the acting, or the sets, or the cinematography--they are all excellent. Rather, it is the writing that has gone downhill. Basically the writing has devolved to make it more of a high-brow soap opera than the high quality dramatic production it was in the first season, and somewhat in the second and third seasons. By this I mean that, at its best, the plot proceeded in a natural, believable, and yet dramatic way as a result of the personalities of the characters and the times they were living in. But now it seems as if there is one "dramatic" bombshell after another, dropped just to keep things exciting or suspenseful. But these faux dramatic events are not only highly improbable but now the characters are bending out of shape to fit the extreme twists and turns of the plot, to the extent that the characters are actually out of character. I'm so sorry to have to stop watching, I was really hooked on DA, but I would rather preserve my fond memories of how good the production was at its best than continue to be disappointed by the devolution of the writing. UPDATE AS OF AUG 14, 2014: All right, I admit I am powerless to resist Downton Abbey. I returned to the show because I missed the characters and the acting and the great dialogue Julian Fellowes puts in the mouth of Maggie Smith. Now that I've watched two or three more episodes, I'm glad I came back; there are some very good moments and the plot hasn't entirely devolved into soap opera drama.

Yet another season of exceptional and engaging television.  Would that more programs were as well written and performed.  Sadly, there are few of those and, as such, Downtown Abbey stands out as an example of what television can and, to my mind, should be.  It is a diamond amidst far too many lumps of coal.  The writing is intelligent and yet empathetic to the human situation.  And, I would have great difficulty finding fault with the cast.  They are well chosen and quite masterful at their art.  Every episode challenges my mind, tickles my sense of humor and touches my heart to the point of tears.  Those sometimes from sadness but, more often, from joy.  This is not just entertainment; it is an experience.  And a quite wonderful one at that!

If you haven't stared watching this English Mini Series - GET HOLD of season 1,2 & 3  and start enjoying a great story. Then watch season 4. At the end of it, you will, like millions of others wait impatiently for season 5.

The story hinges around the lives of an English aristocratic family. It starts just prior to the First World War and shows the family slowly adjusting to the changing times. Its interesting to watch the cook adjust to the introduction of electrical appliances!

The economic fortunes of the family change with the times, Younger generations get involved in the management of the estate with "revolutionary" new ideas. Understandably there is tragedy and individual family member problems, all of which keep you stuck to your TV screen watching as the drama unfolds. This is a REALLY good story to get your hands on. It also is not one of those dramas that you will watch only once. After a few years you will get it out of storage and enjoy it again.

I'm not interested much in TV series; but I must tell you this one has really grabbed my devoted attachment. The locations are terrific; the storyline is accurate to the times and conditions; but most of all, the characters are excellent, excellently cast with exceptional actors and actresses, and one cannot help but become a part of the family of the whole troop. You can believe me, while the surroundings are authentic and actual, I'd find myself in the kitchen raiding the goodies, or butting thoughts with the butler, or falling in love with one of the girls,. This serious drama of life in a beautiful mansion, along with all of the problems of finance and family dignity the family heads must deal with; this series contains the most worrisome drama at times, and most humorous happenings at other times, and one cannot help but feel he is a part of the life of all. This is an excellent family entertainment package, and once you start watching, you will find yourself wanting more and missing the folks when it's between seasons - and if you have a passport and the funds, well, you'll be wanting to get there yourself. If I were an actor, and they were to call me, I'd jump a the chance without pay just to get to know the other actors who most delightfully play their character roles.

So Season 4 for me wasn't quite up to snuff. Spoilers coming!! I hated the whole rape thing with Anna Bates. Good grief, let this couple alone, Julian Fellowes! First you throw Bates in prison for most of Season 3, then you have this whole rape thing hanging over their heads. I'm sure stuff like that happened to the staff as it does to women everywhere from all times, but why did it have to be Anna? I'd have been happy to have none of it. My other pet peeve is the fast transformation of Lady Mary from somber, grieving widow to juggling several earnest suitors for her hand in marriage. None of whom are that interesting. The whole mess with Edith's baby and Michael missing is just that, a mess. At least no major characters died this season, although I held my breath when the Dowager Violet got sick. Loved having Cora's mother and brother on the show, sure hope Harold (Paul Giamatti) gets to hang around more in season 5. I still love this show despite its faults this season, and I'm looking forward to the debut of Season 5 on PBS January 4th, 2015.

Not my favorite season, but how could it be with the viewers and storyline reeling from the loss of Matthew. Then throw in Anna's attack to the formula, and yes how could this be any fans' favorite season. I have tried hard to like Rose as much as the British royalty seems to but her character honestly annoys me and much of the season was about Rose. I am glad for Mary honestly expressing her grief for Matthew and for Matthew's Mom's very real expression of feelings (her conversation in the nursery with Mary and Branson was one of my favorite scenes). It is a "transition" season so that's why I can not particularly like it but still give it five stars because I anxiously await discovering what the story will transition to in season five.

A lot of people have said that they thought season 4 was somewhat lackluster with regard to the various stories that evolved during season 4. I thought it was really well done as far as the writing was concerned. Would I say that this was on par with season 2 during the turbulent WW1 years ? No. It was extremely well done though and it was nice to see some different and suprising behavior from some of the cast regulars. I ordered this season through Amazon instant video service and streamed it through my set-top device. Admittedly I watched the whole season from start to finish in one sitting because it was that good. Different from previous seasons? Yes! Did it hold its own with interesting and developing story lines? Oh yah. Downton Abbey fans will no doubt be happy with it and there might ven be a cliffhanger or two to warm ya' up for season 5 reported to be coming to us in the U.S. in early January 2015. I can hardly wait.

They have done it again, another great season of Downton Abbey! I truly hope for a season 5. They have again done a wonderful job on the sets and costumes etc. The only thing lacking is that they seem to forget to delve into all of the characters, they seem to just give us a taste of who they truly are and then send them off to the side to focus on one character. I wish they would expose more of all the characters inner thoughts and feelings. This season seemed to focus mostly on Mary trying to find her way in life after becoming a widow, but what about Tom they barely touched on him. We got more of a view of the personalities of the people downstairs that upstairs, it would be wonderful if we could get a good inside look into all the characters. It would be wonderful to find out more about Lady Edith and who she really is and how she really feels. She seems to always be told what to do then disappears into the shadows. Hopefully that if there is a season five we will find out more about her and how she copes with her secret daughter.
Overall a great series and hope that season 5 gives us a little more insight. Please BBC don't just stop making the series the way you have in the past and leave faithful viewers hanging on and wanting more!

I gave this season this rating because of the ending more than anything. Sometimes a good solid story with a great ending is just what we need to make us want to go back for more. Bravo Downton Abbey.

Probably only so much you can do with a stuffy old upper crust family and the (increasingly good looking) staff that adds spice and high jinks but basically comes down to wash, rinse, repeat.

Note: The extras on the DVD were good behind-the-scenes items, but I would have also liked the after-show presentations they had on PBS.  I was really looking forward to those, and that's the only reason I rated this a 4 instead of a 5.)

WHEW! a lot happened in Season 4, didn't it?!? (As far as I can tell, those who said there was no character development hadn't watched past the first couple of shows.)

SPOILERS (as I address others' comments)

-- Regarding Edna, and why `clueless Cora' hired her:  first, obnoxious Rose stepped in (AGAIN) where she was not invited.  And remember, in Season 3  Edna was the clean-up-committee.  She was rarely in a room with the family and she was at Downtown a very brief time.  That's why Cora only vaguely remembered her, which is believable.

-- Someone mentioned they don't know where the Edith's baby storyline came from.  It came from the episode where she spent the night with Michael just before he left for Germany.  There, he was set upon by some of Hitler's "brown shirts" and even his newspaper isn't sure what's happened to him.  We watched Edith grow stronger as she makes company decisions for Michael (using her power-of-attorney privileges) and she does all of this while working through a way to hide her pregnancy (Aunt Rosamund to the rescue).  Good to have a show go the adoption route rather than abortion.  Nice touch.

-- I DO hope Rose isn't a big factor in Season 5.  O'Brien, Thomas, and Rose are the "Barney Fife" characters in this series, for me.  They become tedious to watch and you wish they'd just go away (which, thankfully, O'Brien did).  Newsflash to Julien, BBC, PBS, etc.:  the younger crowd was watching Downton before you added an obnoxious teenager.  If you keep Rose, could you please make her grow up q-u-i-c-k-l-y and keep the sweet parts of her character?  Othewise, she tiring.

-- To a totally different ... and tragic ... topic, they would have lost me if they hadn't come to a fulfilling conclusion after the rape.  An American production would have dragged that on a couple of years.  Dragging in on for a couple of episodes was bad enough.  Once John knew what was going on, we all could relax a bit (instead of the constant "Tell him!" tension.)

-- EXCELLENT CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT IN SEASON 4.
Joseph Molesley (we discover his first name) becomes much stronger, and Cora's new lady's maid - Miss Baxter - finally tells off Thomas.  I hope they continue the Molesley/Baxter storyline, because they deserve each other in a nice way :->.  Edith is heading to Germany, which has me a little nervous.  "Levinson" is often from a German/Jewish background.  Not sure if that's going to play a part in Edith's safety, going into a bad situation. Do any historians out there know when the Nazis began looking to the nth degree on ancestry for an excuse to kill people?  If Edith stays, she may be in danger.

-- Excited for Alfred as he finally makes it to underchef at the Ritz.  His dream-come-true is on its way.  Will he send for Daisy after all (as he once did for Ivy), or will she take up her former father-in-law's offer to take a place at his farm (her inheritance)?  The Daisy/Ivy loggerhead was nicely solved with Ivy heading to America with the Levinsons.  Hoping we'll see more of the Harold/Madeleine relationship.  Julian  left it open.

-- Good Mrs. Patmore/Daisy moments throughout the season, which were nice to see.  We discover Carson's long-lost-love.  Julian has given us an impossible choice when it comes to Mary's suitors.  All three are good candidates, but I'm rooting for Tony :->.  I'm hoping his honesty about Charles - when it was to Tony's detriment - gives him some extra points - ha!

Tragedy, intrigue, romance, scandal, and the old lord clearly stating he is a monarchist while defending his social class.  Great gravy, this was a good season.  Granny is better than ever.  We are watching her age and move closer to the end, and this actress remains the creme de la creme of the show.  Her patience with so many people beneath her social class clamoring to give her attention and a turn around the ballroom is amazing. Mary's class consciousness makes me want to send her to the House of Lords, but oh not in her day.  It is hard to believe that Robert and Cora would overlook the moody illegitimate pregnancy of one of their daughters.  They all hang out together too often to not miss her for four months and note that she couldn't care less about Swiss French.  Perhaps George will one day stumble over his half sister tending a pig pen, and look out for sparks and revelations.  The Irish Catholic chauffeur turned estate agent and adopted son in law does need to leave the house to make sense.  His love for the Crawleys seems to either be a calculated way to keep a higher status or a sad, insecure rejection of his own class values to keep his daughter in good favor with her mother's people.  Either way he needs to go to America or marry the school teacher and live in the village.  I am tired of the gay guy being the bad guy, and it would be nice if he met a railroad employee and ran off to find love, but no chance?  Cora is nice, but her people are awful. I am an American and I hate the intrusion of her relatives into this period piece fantasy.  It does highlight the tragedy of the aristocracy at the mercy of market capitalism and populist politics in the 20thc.  Ah well, banking, finance, diplomacy and maybe non-profit management are open to employ them.  Which man will win Lady Mary's hand in the next season?  Will Granny leave the show by God's hand? Will the little bastard be discovered and taken into the big house (unlikely, but they did take in the Irish Sinn Fein chauffeur)?

What hasn't been said in praise of this series?  They have produced a series that teaches the huge shift in world economics and social change that took place a hundred years ago.  For many folks, it's just very entertaining, but the writers have managed to sneak in the very importance and essence of the intricate social changes that still effect us all today.

PBS did a special on Highclere Castle, the actual site of Downton Abbey.  It is still occupied by an Earl & his wife.  There is a butler, two chefs, a total staff of about twenty.  It is still surviving, but the annual costs run over a million pounds a year, and the Downton Abbey filming is a big help in that regard.  I found that show on another provider's menu - Netflocks, or something like that.  Highclere is also a popular tourist attraction, a few thousand acres are now dedicated to productive farming, and high end bird hunting is also a bread winner for the estate.

Dowager Countess Grantham's wit does not disappoint after 4 seasons of this great glimpse into the world of English aristocracy.  She is still the absolute star of this cast of bluebloods.  I was delighted to see that horrible lady's maid depart Downton, but regret she left her  evil-doing partner in crime behind the wreck havoc both upstairs and down.  Downton survives in spite of his lordship who seems unable to change with the times as the ladies of the house show amazing good judgment and character at every turn.  I wish there were 30 episodes every season!

I found this season to be less interesting than previous seasons the word pablum come to mind .  The characters' interactions are less contentious and not as well developed as in the past.  Even Violet seems to have lost her edge.  I still enjoyed the relationship between her and Isobel, though. I felt this season was totally a set-up for next season.  But I am really not much interested in what happens to the characters since the season ends with everyone happy and at peace.  The sets were stunning and the costumes were beautiful.  I recommend it but be aware that you will find it a bit lacking.

Well, even though I heard from two friends and previous fans that it was no longer worth watching, I have just watched the whole 4th season and loved it. The characters continue to develop and are faced with unpredictable situations. It is almost worth watching just for the costumes, which are great fun. I like all of the characters, even the bad ones. They are all sympathetic in their own way. I am so impressed with the writer and creator, Julian Fellowes who has basically turned out - 40 hours plus now of better entertainment than is available on television otherwise. I looked him up on IMDB and see that he proposed to his wife 20 minutes after he met her. He wrote romance novels in the 70's under the name of Rebecca Greville, and is a fan of the 2012 series Smash. I will have some fun checking those out while waiting for Season 5. Before closing, kudos to Maggie Smith for experimenting with body language and coming up with something new and fun when all words fail, which does not happen that often with her character.

This series is so good that it seems like it should be fattening. I have to "ration" the episodes to make them last longer. Great acting, great dresses, great tuxedos, great setting, and the dialogue is incomparable. I especially the love the social "depth." We're treated to a glimpse into the debut of a titled socialite at the same time we watch Daisy's personal triumphs and disasters unfold in the kitchen, and also witness Molesly's personal growth as he hiccups, stumbles, persists, then watches in stunned disbelief as he's relied on for advice and support. This is some wonderful turning and twisting.

The current trend in movies/TV series is not to my liking, violence, crude language, poor quality editing, too much animation, "reality", etc,etc. At our house we no longer watch cable, don't have anything except internet connections....I am thrilled I can watch Downton on amazon with our ROKU, I love it. that version, whatever is on that one.

I enjoyed this, but the reason I  watch is to chill and get carried into a well done period drama.  I don't expect stark reality- in fact that is what is refreshing about these episodes- they don't try to be "raw" and "tough" like so many hangdog hollywood series. I am happy to see things roll along.

I thought the central conceit of the series is people stuck in a bygone era, resisting change....well you can't fault season 4 for failing to represent that.  It doesn't really matter to me that nobody ages in ten years, or changes their personality, and the main way to "move on" is to die- I'm still chuffed to kick back and binge-watch the disc.

Some things I noticed and enjoyed w/ this series- There was more humor, and  amusing rapartee .... although at one point there seemed to be a directors decision to have Mary and Edith talk as though they were captive in an underwater aquarium, talking slooow and low and  watery, (doubtful this had anything to do with conveying humor)  this was fairly quickly redirected and they reverted back to somewhat more normal conversations in an episode or two.

 I also noticed and liked that there was more of a focus on interactions and dramas with the staff, with longer, detailed segments devoted to the dynamics with their relationships and the various situations that affect their lives.  There were even gardeners this time- one wonders where they have been the past ten years. So yes, I will look forward to Season 5, and whatever else....

A show that shows the changing of the past, though slow are arduous for some.  Elegance for the rich and struggles for the poor, how strange that we are reverting to this horrible mainstay of the rich and the poor and no middle class.  Is this the future or shall it remain the past where it belongs.

Overall enriching and maddening at the same time.  Great to watch, but i could never live in the time.

Season after season never disappoints. There were some great new characters this season, we could hate and love.
Excellent as always, cant wait for season 5.

I'm caught in this British Soap Opera -- pulling for this character, mad at another, hoping Bates won't get caught, etc.  I'm hooked.  The characters are from another age but there are the likable, distasteful, and down right mean people, all mixed up in severly rigid class distinctions and full of intrigues and counter schemes that make me want to watch the next episode.  The end of Season 3 was just horrible (a very nice chap died in a motor car accident) and I couldn't watch it for awhile.  But then I thought, 'That's the way life is unfair stuff happens to the good and the bad guys get away with bad stuff.  BUT I think it all evens out in the end, you reap what you sow!  Downtown Abbey has me hooked.

While the series focus is aristocracy, it depicts snobbery in both camps in one form or another. What continually draws me back is how the series is actually telling the stories of growing up in this environment, making choices (some good, some bad), becoming aware the 'old' ways need to make way for the new and best of all, it shows how a family (and they ALL are a family) supports each other through their crises.  A fine example of life and how waxes and wanes through the cultures with a few twists of wanting to throttle some of the characters for their insecurities and joy when some receive a well-deserved comeuppance with a large dose of inclusion even if you weren't born into it - aristocracy.  Good all around show!!
Excellent entertainment

Love the "period" everything.  The main story and the sub plots are fun to watch and try to figure out.  My two favorite characters are Lady Mary and the Butler.  Mary because she is so confused.  Does she maintain the fake vainer of aristocracy or give in to the new changes in society which she obviously wants to do yet is constrained by her feeling of responsibility to the family and England.  Mr. Crowley, well he is just the epitome of the "Rock of Gibraltar".  Wants to maintain the status quo but can withstand the tide of change no matter his reluctance to change.

Downton Abbey is so engaging and enthralling and just keeps getting better and better.  I love the way it engages what i believe to be the actual unfolding of the 20th century, not only in that culture, but how the North American culture was at the same time and the actual ties that bind.  I remain enamored with the personal discipline of the Lords and Lady's and feel that those same values have never gone out of date or style.  Therefore, I love seeing it emulated as a reminder to me of the discipline of holding to my own values.

I'm so sorry the story involving Anna and John Bates was so far below the usual high quality of writing I've come to expect from Downton. Anna wouldn't control how she so cruelly treated him and then ask him later not to jeopardize what they had built together- seriously? It made Bates look like a fool and Anna a selfish victim, even though she says it was to protect him from going to prison. Even considering the mindset of the times,the fact that she gave him no more credit than to, herself, jeopardize what they built, made the entire storyline at the very least, insulting. The rest of the season is a good story line, but what a shame that Ross was such an unmelodious singer.

Downton Abbey is one of the best period dramas to come along in a great while and the writing is among the best. Even after watching it on PBS there is so much more to it that having the series on DVD to watch and review a time or two is worth it.  Upstairs / Downstairs was an excellent period drama during its time but D.A. outshines even that great series.

I know the light-heartedness couldn't last forever with Downton Abbey, and if that's the case, I think Downton Abbey should've joined the usual British-tv routine of just retiring the show while it enjoys international acclaim, and letting its memory live on as a warm-hearted series. I loved the previous seasons so I can reasonably be considered a fan of this show.

But last season - whew.  I struggled to maintain interest.  Mary claims that almost all single men were killed in the war and then we see an endless parade of suitors appear, all untouched by the war.  Lord Grantham has been turned into a completely dim-witted simpleton ("There's this man named Ponzi...") and Lady Grantham says almost nothing for the entire season. And we're really going to believe that an Earl is going to turn to his valet to ask if he knows a criminal from jail who can forge a note?  Seriously?

But the most despicable plot twist was the one with Anna.  When a writer runs out of ideas you can expect that violence against a woman is going to happen and it does here.  And if I thought my husband would commit (another?) murder he wouldn't be my husband for long.  What's being done to the characters is such a complete disservice to the first 3 seasons - they should have just ended the series with the death of Matthew rather than churn out such dreck.

The series, set in the fictional Yorkshire country estate of Downton Abbey, depicts the lives of the aristocratic Crawley family and their servants in the post-Edwardian erawith the great events in history having an effect on their lives and on the British social hierarchy. Such events depicted throughout the series include news of the sinking of the RMS Titanic in the first series; the outbreak of the First World War, the Spanish influenza pandemic, and the Marconi scandal in the second series; the interwar period and the formation of the Irish Free State in the third series; and the Teapot Dome scandal in the fourth series.  If you like British period dramas, Downton Abbey is for you

Once again, as in Upstairs..., the focus is on the abrupt challenges to the life-style of the privileged in pre-war (WW1) England. Through brilliant character development, we participate in the effect of the war on the privileged classes' sense of entitlement. We experience, along with the characters, the shock of such life altering changes as the womens's right to vote movement, dating between the races, the breakdown of the classes, and defiance of parental authority. Some are able to adjust, others stand firm. The present age is experiencing a similar dichotomy in the digital revolution. Be sure to watch only the UK version to avoid cuts made in the American version, probably not because of content but for differing time structure allotments.  Addictive.

Apparently I live in a cave because we are new to Downton Abbey. But not anymore! If you are interested in the dynamics of a employer and employee relationship in a single household, then you will love Downton
I never thought I'd find this type of series interesting, boy, was I wrong.  Well written with a cast of characters that makes this series a #1 hit.  Can't wait till next season!

I recognize that the show had little choice in killing off Matthew when Stevens chose to leave the show.  No choice at all, really.  And personally I found him bland anyway.  Once he and Mary were married, they were tedious together and all he did was tell her how wonderful she was.  They lost their chemistry.

Did they rise to the challenge?  Not really.  It started off strong enough, with Mary struggling to bond with her baby and snap out of her state of catatonic anger and grief.  But within three episodes they started to introduce new male characters to buzz around her like flies and it all went off the rails.  Through no fault of the actors, the "Three Stooges (Suitors)" storyline was both dull and silly.

 It was far too soon to throw Mary into the marriage market again less than a year after her husband's death. It would have been much more interesting to follow through on her struggle with motherhood, or to focus on her involvement in the estate.  When the three men drove off together at the end of the season, I couldn't help but wish they would all crash that car into a ditch just like Matthew did.

The highlights were the strong acting by Laura Carmichael and Samantha bond in Edith's unwed pregnancy storyline, Isobel's lingering grief (beautifully acted as well) and..that's about it.  Tom Branson's story went nowhere and it seems Fellowes can't get enough of throwing unpleasant, abrasive, and downright awful women at him.  He's a likable character, which is a a good thing in itself when there are almost none left on the show.  But the fire has gone out of him.

The rape storyline?  Very well acted by Joanne Froggett, but the way the aftermath was handled was downright offensive. Once again everything becomes about her insufferable brooder of a husband, Bates.  And then it devolved into yet another murder mystery.  The prison story was by far the worst and most tedious of S3, and now we are getting another one?  Lazy writing at best.

All of the servants spun their wheels all season, although Mrs. Hughes was a wonder to behold as always.  Cousin Rose was a bright and energetic presence, but she failed to compensate for the sunniness and warmth and Sybil and Matthew brought to the household. I must say the Crawley Household seems like a miserable and suffocating place to exist in general.  It didn't used to be that way.

And it doesn't help that the main female protagonist is, for the most part, as chilly, self-centered acid-tongued as always.  I find her about as unsympathetic and irritating as it is possible to find a character whom I am apparently supposed to enjoy.

Hoping that things go uphill next season, but I am not holding my breath.

An absolute must for legions of Downton Abby fans.  If you haven't been hooked yet, find the first three seasons on one of the streaming services and watch it.  I don't like many "chick flicks," but I found this series to be thoroughly engaging! The characters are well developed and the story line pulls you in.

Every new season is awaited with impatience and does not disappoint AND always feels too soon when it ends.  It is remarkable to see the rationale the monied classes always have for their own sense of entitlement.  Maggie Smith's question during the first season, "What is a weekend?" is sublime.  The family are not monsters, they are likable, caring people who are a reflection of their times and attitudes of their class.  That they never question life's primary daily occupation is dressing for meals (and even then it's unthinkable to do it without assistance) until the younger generation begins to involve themselves in helping the war effort is amazing.  That rationale for class structure, like racism, is still quite real, it's just more hidden today.

It is a multi-layered, rich exploration of humanity, morality, ethics and consciousness AND entertaining at the same time.  Bravo!

Downton Abbey, Season 4, does not disappoint. After learning beforehand, as we do in life if we are listening, that losses abound in anyone's existence and life seems to have ways for us to get through the sorrows that seem impossible at the beginning, we are brought into new and old characters' lives, into their adventures and misadventures as well.
The acting is as good as it gets and the character and plot twists seem reasonable, especially given the portrayal of a changing world, since after World War I.
I see some adventurous high school and perhaps even college teachers using the entire series as a backdrop through which to teach aspects of history and one benefit of watching is that we learn in the most satisfactory of ways, through the senses as well. They are all unstoppable in their acting, but Maggie Smith is so extraordinary, and the lines given to her just ease out of her mouth delectably. I recommend without reservation...

Just adding my vote.  The huge fan base is testament to the excellence of the production.  And though it is a bit of a soap opera on one level, it is also a very interesting reminder of the difficult transition the British went through moving from a centuries-old socioeconomic system to a radically altered one.  And though it shows why the change was needed and inevitable, showing the War and other events that hurried it along, it also leaves you with a sympathy for WHAT was lost, and WHO the losers were including some in the lower classes (butlers, etc) who would not have been intuitively obvious at first blush.  The effects and dynamic of this change could never be better epitomized than in the character played with such flair and excellence by the eminent and estimable Maggie Smith.

Several people had recommended this show to me . A friend had the 1st two discs that she let me use. I had to watch the beginning a second time , but I was very drawn to the story & characters. We ordered the last 2 discs , because I could not wait to see the rest. The characters were so interesting , especially in the way they adjusted to a dramatically changing world.  The concept of what made a marriage such a  short time ago ( compared to history of mankind) was shocking to me. It seemed so sad that some found love , while others took so much for granted.
There were a couple of surprises along the way , but the casting & costumes were fascinating. I enjoyed the extras on the DVD's  (behind the scenes.)  inter views with actors, makeup etc. It was interesting to see the transformation of very lovely ladies into the servant roles.
Someone asked me which group I identified with . I had not thought about it ,but then realized that the servants were easier to relate to. Kind of strange how they were convinced of the superiority of royalty & so willingly did their bidding !

All in all I am grateful that my friends recommended this series to me . I thoroughly enjoyed the story , but was disappointed how  it was ended. There were several intriguing plots & twists , but a few were left dangling. Maybe I just enjoyed it so much I did not want it to end.  After all the world goes on.

I liked the series because of its social, cultural and historic perspectives. Although obviously a fictional story line, the backdrop, the surroundings, the views of events from the time period and the location are somewhat authentic.... therefor of interest and value.
It seems something of a National Geographic Documentary cloaked in a fictional storyline.
The culture shock caused by the War, the practical financial implications to being in the aristocracy and financing an English estate, the need to view Estate ownership as a business, moral views toward unwed mothers, social class and the attendant distinction and interaction between them, managing ego and self esteem while pursuing self interest and maintaining social discourse and acceptance in the community.
The first 4 series have been excellent in covering a broad range of social, moral, inter-racial, cultural, pragmatic issues associated with the time period and location and keep an interesting story line.  The challenge in future seasons will be to maintain its historical and informative value and not devolve into a near meaningless soap opera with a somewhat different "setting".

Downton Abbey is my alternate universe.  I adore the house, the characters, the story line, the clothes, the accents, the history, etc.  I heard "rumblings" when Season 4 was being shown in the U.K. that Season 4 was lacking in some way -- that it didn't stand up to previous seasons.  I reserved judgement until I watched the entire Season 4 DVD.  Season 4 did lack the terrible, wrenching tragedies of Season 3.  Downton Abbey devotees will know exactly of which I speak.  Yet, there was ample suspense, passion, and surprises to make this season one of my very favorites.  It was good to see Lady Mary coming out of her grief to begin to live again.  It was even better to see Lady Edith come front and center in this season.  She really came into her own.  Lady Mary's new love interests were diverting. The Dowager Countess was impressive and impeccable as always.  Lady Rose I've never cared for and that didn't change.  It was fascinating to see how the Great War brought about such change in Britain in all classes.  Now if only Season 5 would hurry.

Now I am waiting for Edith to get pregnant, have the baby and the roof falls in and crushes her, or of course they most likely will just skip poor Edith and her horrible love life and go right to cousin Rose, the rebellious teenager.  Like I said I have watch 3 seasons but I put this revue here because I do not want to spoil anyone who hasn't seen the first three seasons.  Hopefully the 4th will start giving some more originality like what really happened in the years from the 20's to now where almost all of these houses were forever changed from victorian gilded age to museums for tourists or torn down.  Many noble families lost their homes during this time that the show barely showed.  I would have like them to talk why this was, not them having an even larger house staff then they did in 1912 at the beginning of the series, really a butler, under butler, Head maid?, 2 valets, 2 lady maids, 2 footmen, a head cook and her assistant, 3 kitchen maids(two seemed to be always quite for some strange reason), 3 house maids and a nanny/nurse.  That is only the main house and does not include the cook/maid at Crowley house, no one knows how many servants at grandma ma house and all the chauffeurs they employ for the family.

I find Downton soothing, like yoga class or a walk in a garden.  With that in mind, Season 4 delivered a higher dose of Zen than the arbitrary plot twists and character swerves of Season 3.  The Abbey returned to a steady keel, where even a world war failed to disrupt the routine of dressing for dinner.  Some characters thrived in the closed environment, growing deeper roots so that each appearance blossomed with potential.  Others stagnated into wooden caricature.  Treated to periodic walk-ons, they paraded frozen personality traits in case a future plot development requires a resurrection.  While fence post characters annoy, other cast members simply go missing, somewhat awkwardly as if excused due to previous engagement.  No need to name names but one departs for America and another absconds to have a baby.  And so we learn disappearance renders them dispensable.  Out of sight, out of mind, they are barely mentioned and soon eclipsed by the ghosts of the keenly missed lost from prior seasons.  Death and  familiarity have shrunk the Abbey.  The crises are less shocking and more efficiently resolved. The largest payoffs are not surprises but affirmations of the predictable.  There are some welcome and some regrettable new additions, some loose ends, some promises to keep and some intrusions from the real world, but no compelling cliff hangers to launch Season 5.  For that, I am grateful.

With the shocking conclusion to Season 3, many Downton Abbey aficionados wondered whither, and whether, the series could go on.  Season 4 demonstrates that there can indeed be life "after Matthew" for the noble Earl and Countess of Grantham, their daughters, son-in-law, grandchildren, mother, and ever loyal staff.

It's the 1920s, and life is really getting back to "normal" again at Downton Abbey after the upsets of World War I.  Lord Grantham continues to deal with the changing face of the world, assisted now by the surprisingly able Lady Mary, his eldest daughter who is now the mother of his heir.  His son-in-law Tom Branson and his younger daughter Lady Edith continue to search for roles of their own.  There's a new young lady in the house now, Lady Rose, a cousin of the Granthams who is making her London debut (her presentation at Buckingham Palace is marvelous).  Meanwhile, below stairs the servants loyally keep the house moving smoothly most of the time, barring the occasional catastrophe here and there.

I enjoyed Season 4, though in truth I must say that I find Downton wearing a little ragged around the edges.  The original concept was so quintessentially Edwardian that it doesn't seem to quite fit into the Jazz Age, though Julian Fellowes and his writing team continue to do a masterful job.  As always, it's the wonderful cast that makes the series worth watching, especially Maggie Smith, Penelope Wilton, Michele Dockery, and Jim Carter.

This marvellous series from England is magnificent in every way.  This fourth season is just as spectacular as the previous three, and it is almost comical to see reviewers vying with each other to try pick apart the series.  A smash hit certainly brings out the envy
in many!  The familiar characters are all there except for the late Matthew and Mrs. O'Brien, who runs off in the night.  The new characters are most interesting, and the scripts are so well done.  I have liked Julian Fellowes ever since Gosford Park.  The stolen letter from the Prince of Wales stretched things a bit, but it gave viewers a chance to see the old fashioned debutante presentations during the reign of George V and Queen Mary.  Queen Mary looked most appropriately bored.  Buy this DVD, buy the other seasons!  You will be in for hours of viewing pleasure, and those hours will.be repeated.  I am counting the days until January 2015 when Downton Abbey 5 will appear in the USA.

There is so much poor quality viewing on regular TV that watching a Masterpiece Classic as Downton Abbey, well, there's no comparison whatsoever.

I have been a huge fan of this series since day one.  It is with some trepidation I even write a review below five stars.  But it is because seasons 1 and 2 set the bar high.  Season 3, while generally very good, did not quite seem to reach the heights of 1 or 2.  With the 'ahem' occurrence at the end of season 3, the show has changed drastically.  Without spoilers, I would say that many of the characters have changed, and though many portray things realistically, I felt that the 'new' characters are not quite as interesting as they once were.

A few events tend to grate on my nerves.  Most notably was the Earl taking part in a plot to re-steal a scandalous letter from a blackmailer.  Granted, he didn't want shame on his house, but the old Earl would not have taken part in something so dishonest, no matter the stakes.  Especially when he sends members of his family to con the hotel into letting them into the blackmailer's room!  Completely out of character and unrealistic.  The fallout of that scandal would have been worse than the original had they been caught!

That is just one example.  But overall the show is still good.  I do dislike that the writers take a few story arcs and beat them to death.  It's much more drawn out than even the whole Bates murder trial event.

Again - still good!  I just hope the melodrama gets toned down in future seasons.  And I know that Penelope Wilton and Maggie Smith were busy filming, but I also hope we get more of them in the next season than we did in this season.  And bonus points for Paul Giamatti.
I am so sick of seeing trash on tv, so this is a nice change for our family.  I love the old feel of the show as well as the beautiful mansions featured on each episode.  I'm addicted!

Season 4 is "darker" than the first three, especially with the assault on Anna. Even though "she was a nasty piece of work" I miss Siobhan Finneran (O'Brien) who left service at Downton right at the beginning of season 4. Matt Milne (Alfred) has also left. I'm still getting over the departure of Dan Stevens (Matthew Crawley), as is everyone at Downton. And I still miss Jessica Brown Findlay (Lady Sybil Crawley). I know life goes on as actors have other roles to pursue. However, to me, these actors played irreplaceable characters. (If Maggie Smith were ever to leave, I think Downton would be done for.)

I also found the first three seasons to be sweeter, more romantic. I wish Thomas (Rob James-Colier) will find a love interest in Season 5. Perhaps then he wouldn't be such a brat!

SPOILER ALERT!  It beggared belief that Edith decided to be an unwed mother in Edwardian England.  She would not be accepted in America, so is she, too, going to get lost in Germany?  Go to New Zealand?  The last episode ended like a game of chicken with the opposing cars racing head-long for one another:  Were the cars going to crash?  Or not?  Was Downton going survive?  Was the capable manager going to scoop up his offspring and head off to America?  Nothing was resolved.  It was like a chapter-ending in the "Da Vinci Code."

Many people go crazy over Cheetos, but few of the Cheetos fanatics would ever claim that Cheetos are actually "good."  They recognize that their favorite junk food is basically crap.  I doubt if they'd go on line and give Cheetos a five-star rating because they recognize a distinction between what they like and what is good.  When it comes to the arts, though, people are unable to make or even consider any such distinction.  If they like it, it's "good."  You'll hear that a classically terrible movie like "Plan 9 from Outer Space" is "so bad it's good."  This is, of course, impossible: an excess of bad doesn't equal good. What they mean, of course, is it's "so bad it's enjoyable."
  Like  millions of other people I watched  the first three seasons of "Downton Abbey" religiously every week.  But I knew it was silly nonsense full of idiotic plot twists.  In a review of these seasons I pointed out its stupidity, but I gave it three stars anyay, as a sort of compromise between its quality and its watchability.  But I finally gave up in the fourth season, and now I can happily report I'm as free of Downton Abbey as I am of Cheetos. I'm not going to rehearse the absurdities of the plot, but let's have a little fun with the worthless characters.  Here are a few of the characters we are supposed to care about:

*.  The Earl of Grantham--a cross between the silly-ass, clueless aristocrat best captured by PG Wodehouse in his novels about Lord Emsworth and his pig and the equally clueless, pompous, self-righteous fathead Lord Darlington in "remains of the Day."

*  his wife--Here the problem is not so much the characters as the actress. Elizabeth McGovern.  I've never met anyone who could stand that sweet/sad crooked smile of hers. You just want to hit it with a Boston Cream Pie.

*  Carson the butler-- See comments about the Earl.  We are asked to believe that he was once a music hall performer who was abandoned by his true love.  I prefer to think he is a priest defrocked for his inability to keep his hands off the choirboys.

* Bates--Oh come on!  This character makes no sense at all.  In this fourth season he travels to London by train to kill his wife's rapist.  But the shmuck neglects to destroy the ticket stub that proves he was in London! In fact, he leaves it in his coat pocket.

*Dowager Countess of Grantham--Maggie Smith was the only reason to watch the first season.  She was, of course,, playing a version of Lady Bracknell from "the Importance of Being Ernest."  But they've softened the character to such a degree that she no more fun.

* Lady Edith Crawley (Matthew's mother)--There used to be (and for all I know still is) a comic strip called "Mary Worth,"  whose eponymous heroine kept interfering with everybody's else's life.  (I remember a MAD Magazine parody in which someone asked her, "What do you do actually beside sticking your nose in everybody else's business?")  Well, here she is, little Miss Do-gooder

*Tom Branson--This is the Irish Catholic Socialist revolutionary chauffer who improbably marries one of the daughters. The actor's Irish accent reminds me of what the Harvard Lampoon said of Ryan O'Neal in "Barry Lyndon":  "His Irish accent wouldn't fool Fernando Lamas." Now I know the actor is from Dublin, but I'm from Brooklyn and I don't sound like Sheldon Leonard or Tom Pedi (anyone remember them?)

  Well, that was sort of fun (for me at least).  If you want a really good british series, try "Mr Selfridge."  It's as enjoyable as this one and you don't feel like you're eating a bag of Cheetos.
