I was worried that, at this point, the series would have gone stale.  It's so hard for a TV series to remain fresh year after year.  It's even harder when it's a series that is constrained by a certain time period.  If you think about it, the Abbey is somewhat of a prison, as most of the action takes place there.  They are also limited by what happened in history, rather than creating what is or what could be now.

However, I was delighted to find that the series was still interesting and yes, fun.  And some of what I'm going to say may contain spoilers if you haven't watched the third season, and then I am going to discuss some of the plot from this season, so...

SPOILER ALERT!

 Dame Maggie Smith was in her element and stole the show in every scene in which she participated.  She's just so GOOD in this role.  I admire actors who can take on a character who would be so easily hated and make them lovable (such as Alan Rickman with Snape in the Harry Potter movies.)  I loved how kind she was to Lady Edith and to Isobel.

I also enjoyed Penelope Wilton's Isobel, as she beautifully took us through the grieving of her son.  And the interactions between Maggie Smith and her were quite wonderful.

Michelle Dockery continues to amaze me with her restrained performance of Lady Mary.  Every trouble in the world is laid at her feet, and then people wonder why she can be hard as nails?  Can't imagine why!  She also did a great job in conveying her grief over the loss of Matthew.

Finally, Joanne Froggat did a beautiful job in such a difficult performance.  The emotions she portrayed, the way they showed in her face, even the way she held herself...she's truly talented.

If I had some complaints, it would be these (SPOILER ALERT):

1.  Can there be no happiness for long for Mr. and Mrs. Bates?  First he's in jail, now she's raped.  I'm not saying it's not realistic - life can be very hard - but can they have SOME joy?
2.  I'm dying to know Baxter's background.  I can't believe it was not revealed at all.
3.  I couldn't remember what Daisy and Ivy were fighting about and honestly, it was just way too much for too long.
4.  The whole Prince of Wales letter debacle was just, well, stupid.  Felt completely out of place.

Still, great job by the whole cast and the storylines were mostly interesting and enjoyable.

Highly recommend.
Great follow up to previous seasons.  Highly recommend if you like the previous seasons. Hope this great series continues! Thanks!

Bought all seasons so far. Can't get enough. This is about the lives of a wealthy family and the struggles of keeping an estate that was passed down from generation to generation. About a year ago I decided to watch the first three Downton Abbey series, which I did over the course of two days. From the first episode I was hooked -- the sets and scenery were sumptuous, the ensemble cast worked well together, and the overall plot depicted a period about which I am most interested.

Several days ago I took time to watch all of the fourth series and I came away feeling the show had become stagnant. In fairness, I decided to view all four series a second time. Again, I loved the first three series but felt series four was running on life support -- I could not bring myself to view it all again.

As a previous reviewer stated, few of the principal characters are evolving, and characters added to the fourth series are little more than wooden cutouts of those they're replacing. The plot arcs are becoming clichd and utterly predictable. Doubtless, I will watch the fifth series, and I do hope Julian Fellows puts it back on track, but I doubt there will be a sixth series, nor should there be.

A couple of side comments:

1. I do hope Amazon can get its collective head out of its arse and deliver streamed programming that isn't constantly interrupted and which, frequently, will not reconnect at all. I do not have this problem with Netflix and I'm very curious why a company with Amazon's resources cannot do a better job.

2. After 50 some odd years of watching television I've really grown tired of relatively unknown actors who find themselves in a highly successful ensemble cast, like Downton Abbey's; then, because of the show's success decide to 'make their mark' in Hollywood, thus destroying the show's continuity, and subsequently never to be heard of again.

I just finished episode one of season 4 and was partially into episode 2. The rape of Anna????? I don't care if this is a spoiler. I wish someone had warned me. In addition to that, episode one continues the scheming and condescending Thomas antics along with the pathetic new ladies maid. Aside from the beautiful sets, costumes and music, you have turned an amazing, beautiful glimpse into history into a tawdry soap opera. I realize rape happened, continues to happen, in our world. I do not want to experience it on my screen. Witnessing abuse is not my idea of entertainment. So very sad Julian Fellowes.

to re-enjoy at a later date

What else is there to say that hasn't already been said? Love period dramas with great acting, story lines, outfits, and beautiful surrounding? Watch the whole four seasons.

I give this a 4 because the quality is not as good as usual, it looks like they filmed a lot of it without proper lighting. The scenes are dark  in color and even with a lot of adjustments on my t.v. it doesn't lighten up the dark colors, makes the bright parts to bright! As usual there are scenes cut out, not as bad as season 3, but just the same, what we are seeing on pbs is not fully on the discs. I love this story and can't wait till season 5, I can assume that they will cut out parts on those discs as well.

I was very anxious to see this new season on dvd, and have just finished it. There is some that is pretty good, some that is really good, and sadly, some that is not so good, but even with frustration with some of the plot lines, the acting is for the most part, excellent.

SPOILERS..........................SPOILERS.......................SPOILERS......................SPOILERS..............................

There seemed to be some reversion to character traits of earlier seasons, which was unfortunate, since we had seen some development. I don't think it was just being with Matthew that "changed" Mary," but I had hoped, some maturing through the war, etc. All that is gone, and Mary is completely cold and self absorbed again. Even though Anna was expected to, and did, help her carry Pamuk's dead body to his room so that Mary's secret might be kept, and even though Bates left his job, his security, his happiness, to return to psychowoman, so that Mary's secret might be kept, when Mary was faced with the choice to keep his or not, what did she tell Mrs. Hughes? "it's a man's life, it's WRONG." She had no proof that Bates was the killer but was that ready to sell him out. ONLY when Bates yet AGAIN saved her family and the monarchy from another embarrassing scandal did Mary change her mind.  Mary is loyal only to her position. Period. It broke my heart, and Carson's, when she was cruel to him. I am glad he got in the last shot. Nor did she tell Anna or Bates what she had done with the ticket, so Bates has to live in worry.

I thought there were some layers of human complexity in Thomas last season, but that too is all gone. He is back to being "one note" evil, causing trouble for everyone for no apparent reason. Additionally, the thing with the Nanny was clunky. He was trying to get her in trouble, but she cooked her own goose when Cora heard what she said to Sybbie, which had nothing to do with Thomas. In contrast, the guy who plays him, from what I have seen in the extra features, seems to be a nice guy. He is good at being bad! I wonder what if it had been Tom who heard Nanny, and what he would have done to her. Sadly, there were probably many many children of "privilege" who were at the mercy of nannies and governesses like Nanny West, and even still.

I thought it was too bad that both Robert and Cora seemed to suffer from extreme amnesia this season, to the point of seeming demented. First, when Thomas and Braithwaite were pointing fingers at Anna, saying she was being mean, they believe them, even though they know Anna is the sweetest person ever, and is never mean to anyone! They even speak to Bates about her. Totally wrong. It was the same in the scene where Thomas is complaining to Robert about the other staff and Robert said, "are you not liked downstairs?" Never mind that there were incidents of theft and attempts to frame Bates in earlier seasons, and what kind of person Thomas is, which Robert well knows. Amnesia, I say.  Robert and Cora should have laughed Thomas out of the room. Why is he still working there? I was glad Braithwaite got kicked out early on, and loved her smackdown by Mrs. Hughes. Additionally, when Violet was questioning Robert about his wanting total control of the estate, I too was thinking, yeah, because you have done so well with that up til now!"

Now Edith. She seems to present as a sympathetic character for alot of people, but she isn't to me. While Mary is not a nice person, she never did anything to really hurt Edith in the first season, yet what Edith did to her by telling the Turkish guy what happened to Pamuk, would have ruined Mary's entire life, if she had not married Matthew. She would have never married and even worse, have been shut out of the society she lived for. I thought it perfect karmic justice that Edith was jilted at the altar, losing her chance to marry, and now experiencing what would cause equal scandal for her. I wanted her to remember what she did to Mary, but the show didn't go there. I have to say that Cora and Mary were pretty blind to not know Edith was pregnant, since they knew she had a boyfriend,had to have started to show, and suddenly off to Switzerland for months. Stevie Wonder would know. I thought Violet's reaction was great.." I see I will have to take the slow path" but not judgmental, nor was she of Sybil and Tom. For all her clinging to the old ways, she was pretty down to earth with her granddaughters and matters of love and sex. It was funny how Robert chastised Dr Clarkson for saying the word "urine" in front of her! Tis a mystery what happened to Gregson. If the Nazis killed him, they would have found a body? They didn't have camps yet in 1922 I don't think. has he faked his death? Why would he give Edith his power of attorney?

I didn't like Rose at all. She was a spoiled little rich girl who didn't give a thought to anyone else, but wanted what she wanted. No replacement at all for Sybil, who was a real person, with  brains and a heart. I SO miss Sybil. Matthew was a nice guy but I loved Sybil. I wish that Cora's mother had been there when Sybil was dying. She would have thrown Sir I Know it All out the window, got Sybil to the hospital, and saved her. I absolutely think Dr Clarkson was right and would have saved her, had they listened to him. I agree with Cora, and didn't want her to reconcile with Robert, even though Violet pushed her to. It was completely Robert's and Sir Know it All's fault.

I thought the Daisy/Ivy/Alfred/Jimmy adolescent posturings went on interminably, but Daisy and Mrs Patmore's relationship matured, which was nice to see.

I got really tired of seeing Molesley whining and feeling sorry for himself. I liked how he stood up for Baxter though, helping her to feel better about herself, and hopefully telling Thomas to go jump in the lake. I see a relationship developing there, no matter what she's done.

The pig stuff was dumb. When DID Mary learn to make eggs?

Cora's mother and brother stuff was dumb and unnecessary. Also the cloak and dagger spy stuff in trying to get the letter back. If it was that important, maybe girlfriend shouldn't have had it in her bag and then left her bag unattended!

What was REALLY good...

Anna's storyline, and her acting. She brought it!!! I hope they have British Emmys, she should definitely win. I really wanted her to go to the police after she knew Bates knew though. I thought that she was selling him a bit short for being so sure that he would kill Green, and ruin their lives together. I LOVE Mrs Hughes, she is such a badass! I thought she was going to kill Green with her bare hands, and I bet she could have. Such great scenes with Anna, with Green, with Braithwaite, with Carson. ALL of them. It's such a shock to see her on the show and then how she looks in real life, a decade younger, like Mrs. Patmore. I also love Carson. He is absolutely old school, and is judgmental and rigid and everything else, but it is his job to make sure everything goes right. It was all on his shoulders. He does have a caring heart though. He adores Mary, though I am with Mrs Hughes on that, and I loved the scene with he and Sybbie. One of my favorite scenes was when he had just found out Mrs Hughes was okay, and he was singing and laughing while he polished the platter, so unlike him, but so sweet. The final scene of this season is right up there too, with Carson in BARE feet, wading, and holding Mrs. Hughes' hand for security! Others think they should be married, I don't know, but even if not, their friendship is wonderful to see.

I don't think Bates is the killer. It would take alot of things to fall into place to take the train to another town, rent a car, find where the guy lives, follow him to where you would be able to hit him, with no one seeing it, or you, then returning the car and getting back on the train. It is possible he had someone else do it, but they would have the same problems. He was hit by a car right?  I think it was an accident. I wanted someone to kill him, but slowly. I can only imagine how many victims he had. As vulnerable as women have always been to sexual assault, I feel sure that women and girls in service positions were especially easy to victimize.

Tom matured this season, I thought. I didn't like him when he was with Sybil. He was controlling, willing to let her sacrifice everything in her life for him but gave up nothing for her,not wanting her to "disappoint him" I hated that, or to have ideas about their child that disagreed with his, and not even treating her family with the slightest respect, when they were sheltering him and even keeping his ass out of prison. I understood and agree with where he was coming from but he could have given Sybil that much. He was a jerk but did start to grow up after Sybil's death.  I think maturity involves the ability to not only see your corner, but the other guy's as well, including the English, and he was getting there. It was such irony to see him dancing at the ball with monarchy. I wonder if the "troubles" are going to rear their head again next season, since one of the guys after Mary has a castle and holdings in Ulster, which I believe is in Northern Ireland. How would Tom deal with Mary becoming an occupier?

I LOVE LOVE LOVE Dame Maggie Smith. I love her snarkiness and her wisdom.  Her scenes with Isobel were gold. It was well done how Isobel could have gladly strangled her, yet when Violet was ill, wouldn't leave her side. Even sick, Violet had good lines! The scene where they are playing cards and having fun together is great. I had a sad moment though, in seeing her ill scenes, to realize she is nearly eighty years old. She is a treasure, and always will be.

This show is a treasure as well, even with all its faults. It has stellar performances and often excellent writing. I don't compare it in any way with Upstairs Downstairs. This is its own entity, and it is awesome to see how many people around the world love this show.
Was so happy to find all the seasons on Amazon. Definitely not the easiest show to find. Love instant streaming especially being free with the amazon prime!

Great writing, characters with depth, clever plot lines - especially, the "Mr. Green Trips & Dies" to the "Prince's Letter Caper" - reminded me of Sherlock, Agatha Christie and Poirot ... justice is always satisfying to viewers ... especially this viewer, fan and follower.  LOVE DOWNTON!!!

Downton Abbey is without doubt the best TV series being produced today. This show has a worldwide audience well over a 100 million people. I have purchased every episode from Amazon instant videos. It has been said that you cannot produce quality television programming, because only a few people will watch it. Not true! There are millions of people around the world who crave quality programming. The season has between seven and nine episodes--usually nine. Season five is being filmed right now.

It is so good that it has a cult  following all around the world. I tend to judge my friends and acquaintances by whether or not they watch Downton Abbey--that is if they have seen the show and know about it! It was the middle of the third season before I was able to get my wife to start watching. Now she is more of a Downton fanatic then I am. We watch all the current episodes together and now we are going back and watching each episode from the very beginning together! Now Amazon is selling some of the jewelry and clothing and other items that are Downton related. There are several hardback books that can be purchased from Amazon, as well as some of them in e-book format. The Hardback books have some of the greatest photography that I've ever seen in a book.

If you have an Amazon prime membership you can watch all the episodes for free, or you can purchase any or all of the episodes for $1.99, or  an entire season for a little bit less. It is so much fun to be able to watch such a great program together with your spouse and/or your friends. I would give it 10 stars if that was possible!

Great storytelling and historical concept ! The clothing vehicles and background seem almost real as in real time. Love this show and hope they continue to move forward and embrace the issues back then.

His Grace Baron Fellowes keeps writing and laying the vision, and it only keeps getting better with each new season.  This has great potential for some very longevity for faithful fans of this kind of genre.  After we lived in Scotland for a number of years, toured large houses and estates now open to the public, we really appreciate the authenticity of context and culture Julian exacts.
Fantastic Series!  One of my all time favorites!  It's classy, well acted, produced and directed.  Pleased to see this series continuing.  Will be sad if it doesn't return!
I love this show so much,I hope it never stops.  I love how all the servants are taken care of by the family.  I can't get enough of the lovely wardrobes again  GREAT show again!
Have been watching Downton Abbey from the start but occasionally have had to miss an episode.  So , was glad to be able to add this to the collection and it was shipped right away!

can't wait for season 5, I don't watch on TV, I place my Downton Abbey order with Amazon as soon as the  DV D is available......I power watch it and actually finish before it's over on TV.  This is my yearly ritual and look forward to it....

I have been following Downton Abbey through all four seasons and never tire of going back and watching the dvd's again.  This is a well-written story filled with a cast of fabulous English actors, with a few of us Yanks thrown in.  It has encompassed a World War, some crimes of passion, family squabbles, clashes between classes, and some deaths -- all set in England during the early 1900's.  Recommended for anyone with an interest in recent history, and an admiration for some excellent acting and set production.  The sets are fantastically accurate.

Its all here folks, if you're a 2014 liberal:
(1) Abortion: watch a woman choose (literally) between life and death for her baby  shes a victim of a culture that won't let her choose to have her baby out of wedlock
(2) Interracial marriage: watch a woman fall in love with a colored man and have to let him go  shes a victim of a culture that won't let her choose to marry who she wants
(3) Feminism: watch a woman be told by her daddy that she is an idiot and cant know how to manage a farm, after which we hear feminist cheering (years before feminism arrived!) of hes afraid of a woman taking charge  shes a victim of a culture who won't allow her gender to be in a leadership position

The men are portrayed as incompetent boobs (Marys men fighting over an ungrateful spoiled wench single mom, Robert portrayed as a greedy uncaring dad, Carson portrayed as the uptight sot, etc).

The only men spared this anguish? Victim men: Thomas the gay victim, Bates the disabled & wrongfully accused victim, Mosley the penniless victim and Branson the social class victim

Welcome to Downton Abbey  where victims flourish and everyone else crashes and burns.

Impeccable writing, period dress, language, and attitudes, and an eternal plot, as applicable to human nature then as now.  Characters we can love or hate, belittle or praise, actions and reactions we can condemn or condone.  Add the pithy issues of social change, socialISM, imperial attitudes, personal liaisons, and certainly our own personal biases and prejudices...and,we find ourselves talking about the characters and story lines long after we've turned off the TV.

I received a dvd which did not work on my dvd machine.  It was only showing in black and white.  I contacted the shipping company and explained the problem to them.  They came back to me saying that it was because of my machine.  I have been watching dvd's on the same machine and they worked just fine. They then told me that some dvd made for the UK do not show colour unless you have a special machine that works for both countries. I asked for a return number so I could return the dvd.  The answer was simply Sorry! no return possible since it was opened.  How can I have known that this was the problem before I opened it since I never had this problem before?  I will not buy from Amazon again unless they resolve the problem.

Does the name of the estate "Downton" suggest that eventually events will begin dragging them "Down"?

When I received multiple e-mails about ordering Season 4 of Downton Abbey.  It stated that it was being sold at it's lowest price, if ordered by a certain date.  I knew I would want it for my collection as well as my friend's.  I did not need it before the season ended, as a matter of fact I did not even watch it in advance.  I ordered it because I said if this is going to be the lowest price, I will order it now.  One for me and a gift for my friend.  Two weeks later, I wanted to order Seasons 1,2,3 and 4, as a donation to a fundraising auction at my school, being held March 6.  I was surprised, very surprised, to see the price a bit lower for Season 4 than I had paid for the 2 that I had ordered.  It angered me.  I will never again be fooled by your promotions or "sales".  It was not because the season had ended, as it is still being aired.  I would love anexplanation, a refund, or even a donation of some type for the auction I am working on.  I am sure I will get none of those things.

Even though Amazon sold this as Blu-Ray, and the DVD package says "Blu-Ray" at the top, the picture quality is far below what I see on PBS. Reading the back of the package it claims to be "HD 1080i" but it looks more like 720p.
Second, there is no Surround Sound, as there is on the PBS Broadcast! It's Stereo!
Even though my Blu-Ray player identifies the sound as "DTS-HD Master," there are only two channels (L&R). So if I want surround sound in my home theater my receiver has to emulate a surround mode.
So, if you want HD video and 5.1 Surround, watch or record the PBS shows.
What a disappointment.

The angle of this particular knock-off of Pride and Prejudice is that the Bennet sisters take on the social status and manners of the Bingleys.  The character who most resembles the Liza we remember is Matthew, in a thoroughly modern gender reversal.  Don't fear for Mr. Darcy's character, however; successors abound.

Alternatively, Downton Abbey may of course be viewed as an Upstairs, Downstairs knock-off, with Matthew and Lady Mary acting out the back-story of Richard Bellamy and Lady Marjorie.  In place of Jean Marsh's relatively spare, grown-up world of London and a professionally active head of household, Downton Abbey adopts as its principal character the consumer values of the house itself, with its decor, furnishings, table settings, and grounds (and of course the costumes and hair styles).  Perhaps it's a case of "Upstairs, Downstairs Meets The Age of Innocence."  The production values are obviously very high.

In any case, what's really new is that the action of Downton Abbey comprises about 13 -- or is it 30? -- sub-plots running simultaneously.  The cutting is fast and furious, as if it needs to get each scene in before the next tweet hits the audience's smart phone.

One aspect that has been a little surprising to me is that, for a work with an atmosphere that is predominantly humane, the bodies do pile up, don't they?  I don't think they're trying to be Shakespearian; it's just that no one has tenure any more -- everyone's an adjunct.

Downton's realization that Ireland exists ensures its fourth star.

Such unexpected twists! The 1920's are proving to be full of drama, and desire for the Downton household. Grandmama with her fantastic one liners and Mary with her bold wit, another great season, I anxiously await each show!

The costumes, the scenery, Maggie Smith - my goodness, the old gal is a phenomenon!  The first three seasons were intriguing.  These seem to be dragging a bit, but who can resist all the glitter, the make-up, the hoopla of a generation or a world most of us cannot even imagine.  As for me, I'll go down to the servant's kitchen and drink with the heart of the castle before I retire quietly in the drawing room and listen to some high pitched daughter in a gown that has never been wrinkled sing a very tiring piece of music that would put even the hound to sleep. It's worth it, if you can stand the painful articulation. Never mind that no one blinks.  Long live Maggie Smith!

I have stopped watching this show after this episode.  It has become incredibly formulaic and the characters are completely shallow.

One of the characters, Daisy, is continually upset that some particular boy doesn't like her.  Meanwhile, some other boy is entranced with her... but she is only interested in the guy who doesn't like her.  This would be more entertaining if there was any reason for anyone to like Daisy-- but there isn't.  She's a shallow, selfish character.  I am no longer paying money to listen to her complain about how some guy doesn't like her.  There are better things on televsion.

If you are a fan of Jane Austen, the Brontes, and classic love stories, then Downton Abbey is the show for you. Based on a book about a maid in a large household in this time period, as well as Upstairs Downstairs, the classic BBC show, Downton Abbey takes you into the lives of the Earl of Grantham and his family, as well as the staff that work at the Abbey. My husband calls it a period soap opera, and while there is quite a bit of drama, it doesn't quite have the falseness that a soap opera would. You get attached to the characters though, and when something happens to them that you don't like, or don't foresee, you really feel for them. Downton Abbey is great overall.

Costumes, hairdos are so appropriate and beautiful.  I also so enjoy the interaction of the servants.  Always a little intrigue.  I recommend this series very highly.

Downton Abbey is a great series.  I love the concept a following changes in social trends while being connected to the inner workings of a family.  There are some changes in season 4, some of which I don't particularly love.  However, this season, although maybe not quite as engaging as the previous 3, is still strong and definitely worth the watch.

No Spoilers. Why does everyone I know love Downton Abbey? When I ask the question, no one has a real answer.  For myself, I don't know either but I am enamored with it.  Season 4 introduces new characters and they are completely in sync with the existing cast.  It always amazes me that there are so many characters and so many stories held within each episode.  Season 4 does not disappoint.  We find ourselves in the thrust of the economic times and how the "House" is going to continue its survival.  Mary's spirit leads the House into times that "stirs the pot." I was hoping for a larger role for Tom this year but with so many characters, Tom's character continues to be stand-up-able. Edith, who previously has shown less characterization, has actually had more substance than previously and I believe that her story line will be extremely interesting for next season.  I really loved Season 4 but it seemed that it had difficulty in picking up the pace as well as creating the enthralling dimensionality that we have all enjoyed through the first 3 seasons.  Truth is that one of season 4's greatest accomplishments have been the continued growth of each cast member.  I really like the aspect of age.  We get to see Sibby and George through the generations to Grandmama.  The introduction of Americans in the script is so much fun and I so enjoy the quipping between the English and the Americans.  Also the bickering and challenges between Violet Crawley and Isobel Crawley is fun and really makes the quality and honesty of the family work some how.  I have been told that others just don't like TV about rich people.  I always chuckle because it simply isn't about the rich, it is simply about life in the 1920s.  Some of the most heart felt story lines are based on the staff.  I feel that the staff and the Crawleys are an inter-changeable family. Season 4 is Excellent and Fun to watch on Amazon Prime. It was interesting this season because I was able to seen the entire Season 4 in January.  Where on regular TV, it won't be completed until sometime in February. That was a great perk!
I am completely addicted. So glad PBS picked this up because I can't say enough about this show and hope it never ends.

Even with all the rave reviews everywhere, I avoided this show until now, early 2014.  What could a bunch of stuffy upper-crusters from another time possibly have to offer?  Especially after the glorious ending to the inglorious Walter White on Breaking Bad, I was sure this one would be a snoozefest.  Well, I couldn't have been more wrong!

From the very first frame, this show draws you into the rarefied world of the landed aristocracy of pre-WWI England, and darned if it doesn't just hook you!  While the elegant Crawley family maneuvers to preserve its social standing and financial future upstairs, a small army of assorted servants bustles about downstairs, keeping it all pristine and orderly. Every character is carefully drawn and superbly acted.  And despite all the conniving and spying and betrayal, you find yourself growing fond of these characters, waiting impatiently for the next episode to see what happens to them.

It doesn't hurt that the castle where all this takes place is breathtakingly gorgeous.  Plus, there's Maggie Smith!  Hands down, the absolute BEST Snooty Old Bat, ever!  She's the most judgy, sarcastic, acid-tongued and hilarious matriarch on TV, and you'll love her!

Go ahead, watch one episode.  I dare you to stop!

My wife and I looked forward to Season 4 with great anticipation, and at first blush we were not disappointed.  We have the same richly textured character interest and the same superb production and acting.  However, we can't avoid a feeling of disappointment as some of the plot lines have slipped into cliches and political correctness. Indeed we have a sense that we have descended into a rather ordinary soap opera, overlaid with our post modern norms and mores.  Whereas the Thomas gay plot line had been handled with sophistication and realism, we now need to be hit over the head with the obligatory racial bigotry bit.  Oh please, we know all about it.  But why include the racial sub plot while ignoring the Irish rebellion that was ongoing at the time?  It is 1922 after all, and the Branson character is portrayed as sensitive to the plight of the Irish worker and workers generally.  While I am at it, it seems that the Branson character's continual playing of Hamlet about his true allegiances has become trite and tiresome in the 4th season.  And along with the racial plot line, we have the equally hackneyed rape story line that hits us over the head yet again by telling us how difficult it was for a poor working girl to deal with a violent sexual attack by someone in a superior social position.

Summing up, the series is still well worth watching for its sparkling performances by many of the cast (the interplay between Maggie Smith and Penelope Wilton is pure pleasure), but be prepared for an overlay of post modern cliches that take much of the luster off the goings on.

We have been watching the series from the beginning with great enjoyment.  The acting has been excellent.  But this week I had an epiphany: these people are pampered and useless. They treat their staff nicely---like pets. Their sense of entitlement is so out of touch with justice that is borders on the psychotic.  Britain should have eliminated the aristocracy prior to WWI; perhaps if all Europe had done so, the Great War would have been prevented.  Why are Americans so enamored with this series?  What does that say about us?  Do the viewers secretly harbor a desire to be pampered by servants?  Do we feel entitled to live in wealth while ordinary people struggle?  Maybe the Russians had the right idea: they stood the aristocracy up against a wall and shot them.  The French, of course, had a more incisive method for dealing with them.  I advocate a boycott of the series.  All red-blooded Americans should refuse to watch any more British shows that glorify the upper crust. The Brits have produced plenty of good series that are cynical about their class system.  There is no reason to support Downton Abbey.  Why do they live in an abbey anyway?

I gave it a four, because it was enticing!  It started many new avenues of interest for each character, and it just kept building and building and building, but then left me hanging with many areas unresolved. I am very nervous about the situation with Mr.. Barrow and Tom and how negatively that will affect Tom.  I really want Tom to find some happiness with the family and in his life. Then again, hitting up Bates in a possible bad light as a result of Anna's situation, my jury is out on this tale.  I don't want another long trial and to have their happy situation destroyed. Then there are all the possibilities for Mary that are very interesting and scary at the same time because Michael and Tony are both pretty good and strong characters for Mary.  I see Michael winning out, because of his impending wealth, and also his great sense of challenge for keeping Mary on her toes.  He seems the better fit for her, but yet I feel their is more about him that we do not know yet! Lady Edith... I have no idea how to interpret her situation yet!  This is why I gave the season 4 stars, good start but very little finishes!  Can't wait for next season!!!!

So very disappointed with the format for the subtitles.  This edition featured the subtitles in a much smaller print than previous seasons of Downton Abbey, and the print was in yellow, which I found to be  too distracting. I don't know if this is a characteristic of the Blu-Ray edition.

It is hard for me to write a review, as it is hard to base my decision to watch on someone else's tastes.  Downton Abbey targets a specific audience.  Must love Brits and the humour of Dame Maggie. I could watch until Sybbie has grandchildren.  The series will be better watched from the beginning. It's a trip worth taking.

First the bad:
As an American I have always hated the way that this series portrays Americans. Why does British tv always pick actors with the worst American accents? They make us sound so odd. And why do we always have to be loud, obnoxious, wide eyed, eager, big mouthed, rude, and effusive? Are we single dimensional?

Shirley McClaine only appears in the last episode, but the banter between her character and Violet is stale. It was funny the first time. Now they both just look like harpies.

This season moves really fast compared to previous ones. It's bam, bam, bam! This one's in, now she's out. This happens and then it's over. While the pace of previous seasons seemed slow before, now it seems to fit because those were slower times. Maybe that is why they've sped things up. It feel jarring.

The good:
Basically what is good about it is all the things that we all liked before. There are the spectacular costumes, acting, sets, and historical backdrops. The characters are still interesting. I feel they have replaced breadth for depth, but they are still good. The stories are fresh. You can see how prosperity is returning after the war. I liked the attention paid to Branson's evolution. It will be interesting to see how that plays out. The competition for Mary is also interesting. I thought the pacing for that was good. The final episode was definitely a show stopper. Very grand.

This round started out with O'Brien's abrupt, middle of the night departure (although I guess a hint of the possibility was given in the season 3 "special"). As of tonight I've watched PBS through part 6 and the rest on DVD- it all looks good. Some have complained about the writing or some of the story bits- you do get some surprises  but most viewers will think the Downton standard isn't slipping.
Thomas Barrow is his old self again, Daisy & Ivy upset over Alfred, Bates turns out to be a most interesting character as a result of his time in prison (he's able to help Lord Grantham save the monarchy from embarrassment)- he and Anna have a violent storyline that may still be around next season. Mary still grieves over her loss of Matthew but ends up with 3 new suitors while Edith, poor girl, is still unlucky in love ( I'll be interested in seeing how that works out- that one will be difficult). Roseis Rose, She never really tames down.
I loved the new locations and vehicles used, even a street scene outside Buckingham Palace (very impressive effort though I'm sure it wasn't used for interior shots which still looked good).
My biggest irritations are actually very minor- Lady Cora told Mrs. Patmore they were getting a new electric refrigerator (this was soon after the new electric mixer) - never saw /heard mention of it again. I'd have liked to have seen little Sybil and baby George more too-  they didn't get 10 minutes screen time between them the whole season!

You do get the season 4 finale, "The London Season", with this set so don't go buying it separately.

3 very good extras are included; "Downton Diaries", "The Making of" and "Meet the new cast" (some of them)- all worthwhile. I'm always suprised at how much a wig or hairstyle can change a persons appearance  and "behind the scenes bits are always good.

If you could preorder 5th season this early I don't think you'd be taking too big a risk about viewing quality, 1-4 are that good.

Oh the intrigue and the plot twists - this is the best season yet and leaves us hanging for the next.  Season three ended on a flat note with the untimely demise of Matthew and the previous passing of Lady Sybil.  Season four opens with everyone moving on in their relationships and the brave new world of post WWI England.  Both above and below stairs relationships become deliciously complicated with some crossing the barriers between the staff and the noble family members.  Lady Edith, a previously neglected and somewhat insipid character, comes into her own as an interesting and evolved member of the family.  Mary attracts numerous suitors and is able to string them along with elegance and detachment.  The Dowager Countess, played magnificently by Maggie Smith, is given and delivers some the most delicious zinger lines ever and is well matched in the verbal ping pong match with the virtuous and iron willed Mrs Crawley.  The season ends, sadly so, leaving us on the edge of our chairs waiting for the next breathtaking installments.

I'm not fully finished with season 4 yet but it remains pretty much as interesting as season one.
"Original UK edition" means that it is uncut and not interrupted by commercials, but yes, if you
bought it in the States (like on Amazon) then it will play on North American format players.  I
got the Blu-Ray edition and WHY NOT, when some of the best aspects of this series are the
stunningly beautiful interiors and costumes?  Also the countryside scenes--all these things
shine better in higher definition (while of course close-ups of faces show more blemishes).

What, bad people don't get dismissed from service?  Gee I've never heard of that happening
in REAL LIFE!  What--people believe malicious gossip?  I never heard of that either!

Besides the costumes, the interiors and the scenery, what keeps the series interesting is
a combination of two things: A portrayal of how the after-effects of World War I devastated
the old English nobility, and rather realistic portrayals of people, the "good" ones having their
faults, and the "bad" ones having their positive features as well.  In short, it has a lot that
resonates with real life, but all with a grander setting.

Did I mention the acting remains superb?  And thankfully there are subtitles for those who
have a hard time following everything by soundtrack.  There are about 30 minutes of
"bonus features" on the DVD / Blu-Ray.

This series is so well done. One falls in love with the characters and their lives. Its very educational about the times and changes in England prewar, during, and postwar. I'm totally hooked and it makes my hour on the treadmill go so very quickly watching the this series on my Kindle Fire.

I loved everything about season 4 of Downton Abbey. The drama, writing, locations, costumes and especially the great English characters! Downton just may be the best drama ever. It is a shame that American actors aren't more than just celebrities; the English actors are sooooooo much better. Everyone I know loves this series.

As I predicted, the series "Jumped the Shark" after the main character, Matthew Crawley, was killed off.  Main plot for three seasons was Mary and Matthew (Michelle Dockery and Dan Stevens had huge chemistry).  Now the plots are getting boring (Ivy, James, Alfred, Daisy=BORING!!!) .  A series "Jumps the Shark" when "long-lost relatives" are added on (Cousin Oliver on Brady Bunch, cousins on Happy Days, cousins and long-lost siblings on Little House on the Prairie, original Beverly Hills 90210).  There was no reason to add Cousin Rose to Downton, when Julian Fellowes could have focused his attention on Mary, Branson and particularly Edith and her relationship with Gregson.  I wanted to see Edith become a famous writer.  The addition of the black character is weak.  The rape of Anna and how it is resolved is extremely disappointing.  Mary's suitor Blake (Julian Ovenden) is poor casting, as the actor is 4 inches shorter than Michelle Dockery (Mary) and it's very awkward.  Three men, all good looking and rich, in their mid to late 30s still single after "The Great War," is unrealistic. The dialogue was terrible "Mary, you fill my head up!"  Please!!!  Edith's baby mess was ridiculous.  Elizabeth McGovern's acting has gotten so much worse (look at her face when Anna and Bates run into her at a restaurant).  Finally, Branson's school teacher lady friend is about 4'9 inches tall and annoying. The camera angle when Isobel and Branson are talking to her is ridiculous.

The series is still wonderful, and I will continue to watch it (for a while longer, at least), but with Matthew and O'Brien gone it just doesn't have the same appeal to me.  Anna getting raped was very disturbing, and I'm not sure it was a good move when there are other directions the show could have gone in to create a dramatic situation. I understand rape is unfortunately  a fact of life, but I was not happy it was included in Downton Abbey, especially in that day and age when help for a rape victim was mediocre, at best. Also, I found myself rolling my eyes in disbelief when Carson's old buddy shows up again and moves in with Isobel because Mrs. Hughes takes it upon herself to befriend him and orchestrate his salvation. Really? Cora's one-dimensional character is beginning to grate on my nerves. For example, when Branson's seducer, the former house maid Edna returns, gullible Cora hires her on the spot as her lady's maid, based upon the fact she had been employed by Downton previously for about three days before she was bounced by Mrs. Hughes. Edna has little if any experience as a lady's maid and was the only applicant, but 18 year old Rose likes her and encourages Cora to give her a try. Now there's a reliable source when considering who to hire as your closest personal employee! However, Mrs. Hughes, Carson, and Branson agree they simply can't tell poor Cora about Edna's inappropriate behavior toward Branson when she worked in the house before, because Mrs. Hughes did write her a good reference when she left (at Branson's request). They fear if they told gentle Cora the truth about Edna, Her Ladyship might come down with the "vapors" and need a smelling salt, or something! Please!  Robert, although I do like him basically, can be too much of a snobby prig for words...has he totally forgotten he would have lost Downton because of his really bad investment if Matthew hadn't come to the rescue?  Now at times he doesn't have the insight, humility, or willingness to listen to others who have excellent suggestions on how to profitably run the estate.  Mary and the Dowager Countess are the only interesting and multifaceted characters left, in large part because of their superb acting and excellent writers. I also think Isobel adds a lot to the show with her terrific acting skills and interactions with the Dowager Countess.  I also love Daisy, and hope they build some story lines around her other than her mooning over Alfred. Thomas is always terrific fun to watch, as his mischievous ploys downstairs and upstairs are usually wickedly delicious. If Mary and her British grandmother go the show is doomed. I love Shirley MacLaine, but her stiff portrayal of Cora's mother is dull and adds nothing. In my opinion, continuing with the deeper progression into Edith's struggles, relationships, and activities is the way to proceed with this character. I enjoy watching this great actress work, and more of her would be most welcome. Some of the most captivating episodes to come will hopefully revolve around who Mary becomes romantically involved with...that's worth continuing to tune in for at least a while longer. I realize this series takes place in a different place, time, and social class than 21st century America, and overall I feel it is a wonderfully researched, written, and acted series that I have enjoyed tremendously.  In conclusion, I believe the quality and direction of the first four episodes I've watched of Season Four do not rise to the level of the first three seasons.  However, I suppose I'm still mourning the loss of Matthew, Lady Sybil, and the complex O'Brien. I truly hope Season Four will "settle in," and the compass of excellence will be regained.

In spite of one totally and completely unnecessary plot development regarding Anna Bates (I would ask Julian Fellowes what the hell he was doing!!!???), this 4th season of Downton has been masterfully done!  We're all able to mourn Matthew and allow both Mary and Isobel time to heal and begin to live again.  Many people seem to dislike Rose but I like her quite a lot.  She has a lot to overcome with regard to the bitter relationship with her mother but it is my greatest hope that she will continue to grow and become a lovely person indeed.  She hasn't got Sybil's sweetness but she does have some of her spirit.  I love Tom more than ever and hope that season 5 will bring him good things indeed.  Violet is still a treat as is Cora.  I wish Thomas' redemption had continued more fully...and I hope Julian Fellowes will consider allowing Thomas to redeem himself.  All in all, this is a very satisfying series with only a few hiccups along the way.  And I do highly recommend it if you've loved Downton Abbey so far!

The continuation of Julian Fellowes masterpiece has been downgraded to tragic mediocrity.  His opening chapters have served as quick explanations for the death of Matthew, the loss of O'Brien, the treachery of Thomas, the blindness of Cora, and the ineptness of Robert.  It has also reached into the private cubbies of the faithful viewers to crush their carefully created perceptions and beliefs about those remaining characters that have so boldly taken up residence in our hearts.  Fellowes has torn us from that intangible fabric that I describe as character continuity.  Without it, the viewer becomes lost in an aimless sea of change.  What made Downton Abbey different was the viewers ability to count on the responses of the remaining characters to reasonable crisis.  The launch of season 4 has destroyed that expectation.  Fellowes failed to fully take us, the fans, into his many considerations as he dealt with the troublesome issues of cast mutiny and other more mundane production issues.  The result is mediocrity, and in my opinion, unrecoverable fan alienation.  That is not to say the show will fail, on the contrary, I think it will succeed, but with a very different viewer base.  Those of us who have made it a viewing hit have been "kicked to the curb".  I suppose that is the way of things, but I cannot in good conscience let such a flagrant disregard for the feelings of those who "brung you to the dance" go without a protesting word.

The launch of season 4 indicates that Fellowes has repositioned the series.  It is no longer in the category of a masterpiece classic, but in the genre of a soap opera styled period tragedy.  It has lost the spark of differentiation that pushed it to masterpiece status and has been relegated to idiotic inconsistencies and unbelievable situations.  Come on Julian you can do better than that!

Lady Rose MacClare has come to live at Downton Abbey.  She is a wild child with poor judgment.  She is a liar and a seeker of experiences below her station.  She is a 1920's "flapper" who has had an affair with a married man in London and looks for excitement in the most dangerous of places.  There is no reason whatsoever for anyone at Downton to trust her.  She prepared an ad to find a ladies maid for Cora, and placed it in a shop window in town.  She collected the responses and presented them to Cora.  Why?  Cora did not ask her to do this nor did she give Rose permission to solicit on her behalf.  There is no reason for Rose to take it upon herself to place the advertisement.  Cora on the other hand is an American who is self sufficient and used to doing things for herself.  Edna Braithwaite applies along with others, but Rose pushes Cora to accept Edna.  Rose has no prior known relationship with Edna, therefore, no good reason to push for her acceptance by Cora.  During the interview, Cora finds out that Edna once worked at Downton, but left with a good reference from Mrs. Hughes.  Cora is aware of the politics that surrounds the management of subordinates.  She knows that giving a good reference to a terminating employee is not always evidence of good behavior on that job.  However, she does not consult Mrs. Hughes to determine the facts of the termination, but accepts the recommendation of Rose.  This situation doesn't pass the smell test.  In the past, Cora has proven that she is level headed, and capable.  She is not stupid.  Why would she accept an applicant without confirming the circumstances of the termination with her long term employee, Mrs. Hughes? This situation is unbelievable and highly insulting to the American character of Cora.  In other words, American women ain't that stupid!

Edna Braithwaite is a character with vindictive and selfish purpose.  Upon learning of Branson's circumstances and his rise to aristocratic station, she has set out to bring him down or join the ranks of aristocracy herself through her manipulated bond with him.  It is unclear, at this juncture, which direction she intends to pursue.  She has shown her willingness to ignore the protocols of her station in the household and snub some minor advice from Anna about Thomas.  She does not show great commitment to the job of Ladies Maid for Cora and demonstrates a propensity to defy the orders of Mrs. Hughes.  Thomas makes overtures to Edna and she accepts his friendship.  When she negligently damages a garment of Cora's, Thomas assists by instructing her not to admit guilt and he puts the blame for the damage onto Anna.  Anna has been a trusted employee for years.  She has never demonstrated behavior that would cause Cora to question her trust. However, in this unbelievable situation, Cora accepts the explanation of Thomas because of his newly acquired status of trust which he gained through Nannygate, and does not ask Anna for an explanation about the damaged garment.  The American woman whose financial fortune saved Downton Abbey is being portrayed as an easily manipulated idiot.

A nanny is employed to care for the two grand children of Cora and Robert; Tom Branson's daughter, and Matthew Crawley's son.  She isolates the children from most of the family and refuses to take orders from Thomas, the "Under Butler".  Thomas, for the wrong reasons, rightfully informs Cora that the nanny is not all she is cracked up to be.  Cora eavesdrops on her and discovers she is being cruel to her first grandchild, the former chauffer's (Tom Bransons) daughter.  Cora immediately dismisses her.  On the surface, this situation appears appropriate.  Thomas appears to be a Good Samaritan.  Beneath the surface, he appears to be vindictively attacking the nanny for failing to recognize his authority as "Under Butler".

A package addressed to Mary arrives.  It contains the personal effects of Matthew.  Mrs. Hughes convinces Carson that the contents should be inspected for items that may cause Mary additional grief.  Carson decides that Robert should be given that dubious honor.  The ethics grow increasingly fowl with this decision.  Do Mrs. Hughes, Carson, and subsequently, Robert think they should withhold, hide, or destroy some item(s) that rightfully belong to a grieving widow in some poorly reasoned desire to mitigate her grief?  Mary has proven over the last three (3) seasons that she has the ability to handle her own affairs.  A letter is found by Robert in Matthews personal effects that clearly outline his wishes regarding the disposition of his estate.  It is clear that this is a holographic will.  Robert shares it with the Dowager who tells him that it must be presented to Mary, its rightful owner.  Mary rightfully shows displeasure with her father for going through her husband's effects and sharing the contents of the letter with her grandmother.  Robert claims the letter is not a will and must be sent to the family attorney to determine its validity and authority.  The family lawyer confirms the status of the holographic will and Mary is recognized as 50% owner of Downton Abbey.  The lack of ethics displayed by Mrs. Hughes, Carson, and Robert are a slap in the face of British aristocratic culture for that era.

Rose, the wild child convinces Anna to chaperone her on a visit to London.  They go to a rough and ready bar where a fight breaks out between two men who want her attentions on the dance floor.  When they return to Downton Abbey, one of the two men call on her thinking she is a ladies maid.  Anna assists her in the deception by helping her dress in maid's attire.  Rose greets the young man and lies to him regarding her status.  She tells him she is involved with another man, but passionately kisses the visiting man goodbye.  She tells the first footman, Jimmy Kent, who just happened to be in the rough and ready bar in London at the time of the fight, and helped she and Anna escape, to go along with her lies.  Julian!!  What are you thinking?  Is everyone at Downton corrupt?  What's going on here?

Branson begins to feel uneasy with his new status.  He tells Edna Braithwaite and she quickly responds.  This situation was anticipated when Edna was hired by Cora.  The replacement of O'Brien with Edna Braithwaite was not properly developed.  However, this situation can be corrected.

Lord Gillingham arrives for a party with his valet, Mr. Green.  The valet waits for an opportunity to be alone with Anna, the only married woman on the staff.  He beats and rapes her.  Anna hides in Mrs. Hughes' quarters.  Mrs. Hughes arrives to find Anna beaten, bloodied, and raped.  Mrs. Hughes wants to call in help.  She wants to call in Dr. Clarkson, but Anna demands that she not reveal to anyone what has happened to her.  She is afraid that her husband, Bates will kill the jackal and go back to prison for murder.  Mrs. Hughes complies.  Is Anna to become pregnant with a rapists child and hide the ancestry of the child from her husband?  Will she have a child and put it up for adoption?  Will she have an abortion?  Will she lose Bates for failing to trust him as a man and husband?  Is Anna the latest of many victims of this rapist?  Will rapist Green return or try to blackmail Anna?  This occurrence tipped the scales for me.  Downton Abbey is no longer a masterpiece classic, it is a soap opera styled period tragedy that does not challenge the viewer in a modestly intellectual way, but shocks and tramples the established character traits of its remaining cast.

I am so disappointed in the first three installments of Season 4, that I am giving thought to boycotting the remainder of the season.  I probably won't, but I am giving it some thought.  In the first three seasons, Thomas and O'Brien were the ethically challenged culprits.  In Season 4, just about every main character is an antagonist.  Who can we the viewers trust to have integrity?  Now when I see the beautiful Highclere Castle, it does not bring about feelings of warmth, security, and respectability as it has in times gone by.  It now looks like a house of horrors filled with death, debauchery, rape, and personal ruin.  When I want to endure that kind of tragedy and pathos, I will turn to Shakespeare or Mickey Spillane.
What can I say I just love this show. It has so many good qualities to it. Your always a Yankee WONDERING q h at is next episode going to be . Like

So hooked on Downton Abbey! Wish is was on at least one more time each year! As a lover of British movies and TV, Downton Abbey is one of my very favorites of all time. Season 4 -- superb and brilliant!

Maybe understandably (the sudden 'death' of two key characters must be hard to 'work-around' - the proverbial "elephant in the room" so to speak) the first few episodes seemed a bit weak - at least relative to prior seasons. But now the cast & characters & the writers seem to be back on track - with the possible exception of Lady Edith's pregnancy storyline. (Is this becoming Watership Down-ton Abbey?)
Downton Abbey represents that all too rare combination:  All around excellence from the setting, the characters, the story and the quality of the production.
As always - we find ourselves amazed at the plot - the characters - the reality - that again - we are left loving Downton!
Excellent series.  Couldn't stop watching until I had gotten caught up with all the series  can't wait to see the last two.

Like many others, this was a solicited response
It's a great show! I can't get enough. Great acting and the show pulls you in. If you enjoy comedy, suspense and romance .. This is your show.

Rich storyline and characters.  Love this series!  Perhaps a slower start in season 4, but full season is amazing.  Could not hit closer to real life dealing with how to move forward as fer a lived one passes, especially with different characters.

This whole series is wonderful - it pulls you right in to whatever is going on and tells you more of the story.  The characters become like dearest friends and you wonder during the weekdays (between airings) what will happen next...how will she/he deal with whatever new 'thing' has happened.  So much happens (or is alluded to) each episode (that's only 48 min. long) that you have towatch it again (and maybe again) before you've 'caught' it all.  The set, costumes, the characters are all real and you only want more as each episode ends.  It's about a time I never knew, but I feel like I'm transported back to the 1920s as I watch it unfold.  It also makes one research British and world history for that time to see what's going on beyond Downton Abbey.  I love it!
Downton Abbey has got to be one of the best shows on television in years. All of the characters are very well developed. The storylines, while at times can be predictable, are well executed.

As a fan who has watched this series since day one, it saddens me a bit to see how the show has dropped a notch or two in its' overall level. With the unfortunate departure over the last two seasons of three of the shows' main characters, it has a very large void to fill. Unfortunately, the void is being filled with "modernization".
Thankfully, Mr. Carson still keeps the ship steady, and saves the season.
However disappointed I am with season four, the original characters who remain, and that have been there since day one
are the seasons' saving grace.
If there is a season five, which I hope there will be, perhaps the "modernization" can at least be slowed down a bit.

I have all four seasons now and truly enjoy it.  They are great to pop in the DVD player on a rainy weekend, or when you're home on a "stay-cation" or feeling under the weather.  It's fascinating to watch the interaction and "plotting" of certain servants. It's an excellent period series, very well written with a lot of attention to detail, the costumes and acting are superb.  It also gives you a true appreciation for modern day conveniences.

While I do believe Fellowes and the creators of this show might be catering just slightly more to American audiences than they did before, I still enjoyed this season the most of any of them.  Every situation is dealt with so logically and in such interesting and unexpected ways.  One of my favorite ideas in Season 4 is the growing relationship between Isobel and Violet (Penelope Wilton and Maggie Smith) in the wake of Matthew's death.  And the stories of Mary and her new suitors are exciting.  Another thing I love about this show, and Season 4 was a perfect example, is that each season doesn't end with the typical cliffhanger.  It does leave stories open to continue but you feel a sense of satisfaction at the end.
I wonder, though why I would pay for Prime, if I'm already paying for episodes that were originally free on Public Television?

What has been done to Anna, Bates, Edith, Mary, is disappointing. But still as a whole it is worth watching. British Television in the U.S. at its best.

I do miss Matthew though. That was a real disappointment.

Again you get to peer into a pre WW2 Manor House and the lives of everyone from the Countess to the scullery maid. "Spoiler" My only sadness is that we never see Mr. Bates kill Mr. Green.

I looked forward to season four with great anticipation and it was delivered on the first day of distribution.  My husband and I settled down to watch the entire season and I must admit that I was disappointed.  Season four seemed to lack the excitement and the anticipation of exciting things ahead.  It seemed to be more a series of short events strung together.  It moved quickly from scene to scene that things hardly had a chance to develop.  I actually fell asleep in my chair during Part 9 and missed part of what was happening (or not happening).  I can't believe that I actually fell asleep during Downton Abbey!  That would have been impossible in the previous seasons.  There just wasn't much excitement in this series.  Rose does nothing for me.  Of course I will watch season five when it comes out (and I may even watch  part nine of this season that I slept through again to see if I missed anything of real interest).  But something was lacking.  It was slow moving.  You can never dislike Downton Abbey, but I do have to say that this season I was disappointed and let down by my favorite show.

As an avid fan and owner of every UK Version of this series, I'm sad to find that I find myself more frustrated than satisfied with Season 4. As others have mentioned, the wicked characters continue to get away with their schemes, there's very little vindication - which seems to happen off-camera to quickly wrap-up plot lines and not to mention, the attempt to tackle at least 3 major issues in one season: Rape, Abortion and Interracial Dating! How, or better yet, WHY do you introduce these weighty topics and give them not much more than a cursory glance!? While watching, you're mentally cringing and sighing "Oh, Geesh! I know where this one's headed!" It's ridiculous!  Substance is lacking, the pace feels rushed, much of the personal growth the characters underwent during past seasons has seemingly been lost....it's just simply not the same. It's not the violence or the topics that offend me, but rather the treatment of them. I don't watch the series on TV; I prefer to wait until I can buy the entire season on DVD and then binge-watch. If I had to wait a week between episodes, I would've given up after maybe the 3rd episode. I'm not anxiously awaiting the next season - I'll watch the first episode on TV to see if there's been any improvement first and then decide if I want to continue. What a shame....I expected so much better.

Downton Abbey  is simply wonderful...I have all the seasons so far and will continue to love them as long as it goes on (forever would be good).  I takes everything I have not to watch the entire season as soon as it arrives...who am I kidding, of course I watch all of it as soon as possible (I still watch and support, PBS every Subday night).

It's really a shame the writers of Downton Abbey have ruined this classy production with violent rape.  In the first two episodes of season 4 it seems the writers have lost their muse and are producing a labored and rather boring story line, so they have to resort to the sordid rape of a favorite character in episode 3.  Add that to the deaths of two of Downton's  characters in Season 3, it's just too much and the joy is gone.  I think Downton's secret in the early seasons was to have just enough pathos to keep the plot interesting without becoming an American-style soap drenched with sleeze, creeps, blood and violence.  If you really want to enjoy the series, turn off the DVD player at the point where Mary presents their new baby to Matthew.  It's a real shame to see the high class of Downton trashed by sleeze.
Downton Abbey continues to mesmerized us with complex plots, superb acting, and, of course, the fascinating setting. Atmospherics are constantly outstanding.
