Love it love it love it.  Great acting great scenery  beautiful clothing love the story. This is one story I like to watch over and over

Downton Abbey is a very enjoyable and heartwarming presentation of that particular time and life-style in history.  I have re-watched a lot of the old episodes on my Kindle Fire many times.  It is just plain 'old-fashioned' good!!!  I hope to enjoy many more episodes.
Many interrsting storylines are beginning to form. As the family deals with tragedy the new house guest Lady Rose brings joy and mischief. interesting dynamics between Lady Mary and her father.

Good. Clean. Quality. Period.
TV has gotten quite graphic. This is a refreshing show. And, no, I'm only in my 30s!!
Happy to see Mary not letting her father run over her.  Not sure that I like this new Ladies Maid and Barrow - seems scheming.

Downton Abbey - have watched all three series and not episodes 1-3. There is one story line in the third episode that the writers should have put in the trash basket. I found it UN-necessacary, with no entertainment value. I hope they don't drag it through the remainder of Season 4. Other than that, it's a great show that I will watch again and again,.

As I watched the ending of season 3, I wasn't sure how the writers would be able to bring back the characters from that horrific ending. I mean, how much heartache and loss can people take before there is just no coming back from that? Then I remembered my own, and realized that through my own life, I have never given up on life or love in the face of tragedies such as these. Losing a child, a spouse, war. The fact is, there can always be a happy ending. There can always be new love. And the writers did a wonderful job of bringing in new plot twists, story lines, and even new loves to soothe our beloved character's broken hearts. And to continue captivating us yet again. Well done.

I love every season of Downton Abbey and so far (3rd episode) I'm not disappointed with season 4.  This season is definately dealing with some serious issues.  They have brought in lots of new characters, some good and some not so good.  No spoilers here, but I was shocked and concerned after watching the 3rd ep. I'm curious to see how this plays out......
This is the best tv series ever! Its family friendly and even my husband has watched!! Looking forward to watching the rest of season 4!!!!!!!!!

I've adored this series since it first began. I love the comfort of a more genteel era, despite the occasional modern frustration of watching characters who won't communicate about delicate issues. I watch a lot of historical fiction precisely because it's generally free of the grit and gore that populate modern works.

Season Four opened on a bit of a low note. I was saddened by O'Brien's and Matthew's absence, as they both were strong characters on opposite ends of the spectrum. I wasn't pleased to see Braithwaite, because her relationship with Tom seems destined for repetition, and it wasn't very interesting the first time around. His Lordship seems to be retreating into fuddy-duddyhood with all his assumptions, pronouncements, and unilateral decisions that rub wrongly on the other characters.

And then, the infamous Episode Three aired.

Just. No. Omg, no.

The level of violence at the end seemed entirely out of character for the show. The character who performed it seemed to have walked in from a 1970's thriller. His actions seemed illogical and careless, as if he were accustomed to getting away with such violence. Even if the times did support such a conspiracy of secrecy despite facial injuries on various women servants everywhere he went, modern audiences have managed to evolve somewhat. The end result is that the attack scene feels horribly offensive, out of alignment with the show's seasons-long tone, and sewn on from another genre about as subtly as Frankenstein's limbs, All in order to garner controversy, ratings, views, discussion, and other things that drive SEO and publicity.

I'm not watching the rest of the season. I'm seriously annoyed at Mr. Fellowes and his outrageous hubris. If you'd stuck to what you're clearly good at, this season would be more entertaining, but apparently ruining a beloved show is your Get Out of Jail Free card, so you can dash off to America to shoot your next project (as mentioned in a Montreal Gazette interview) without having to listen to us poor besotted fans begging you to come back and make more. If you wanted to be rid of us, Mr. Fellowes, you shouldn't have made Season Four at all.

We missed the first episode so we downloaded it form Amazon.  The only version available is the UK version and it ends about 15-20 minutes before the US version so we did not see the whole thing.  Frustrating.  This would be a helpful tip for Amazon to add to the summary.
This is the most amaZing show ever! And the fourth season does not disappoint! I own all three of the other seasons and will be buying this episode by episode!! Love it!!
I do not see where I purchased the above and I haven't received it.  I have seen the first two episodes on PBS and really do like it.
lover how this story goes on and on. Keeps you guessing what's going to happen next. looking forward to the last of the season

Some of the characters and story lines are become too farfetched, particularly the negativity and evil acts, the most appalling being Anna's attack - how could the writers do that, you did not need this shock value.  Why would the show reduce this very fine production to trashy TV soap opera, with Barrow continuing his nastiness, should be a better person after all the events; the chauffeur Sybil's husband should have risen to his station and not AGAIN be falling for the silly maid, etc.  Again, becoming too trashy, where are the high standards we have come to expect?  Writers beware, we are watching this and not other low moral and TRASHY TV, you are falling into a trap.  I may watch another episode watchng for improvement, if there is none, I will give up.  Redeeming qualities:  Maggie Smith character, thoughtful older characters.
I have watched and purchased for myself and others all of Downton episodes, but may refrain on 4th Season.
"Disappointed, but hanging in there for one more episode"

Seems the Abbey has lost its luster.  The trouble makers never learn their lessons and the good guys always get hurt (rape scene).  This same old script is tiring me and after Season 4, Episode 1, I've had enough.

I was so upset at the end of season 3, I was ready to call it quits! What is wrong with a little happily ever after that we Americans are so accustomed to! Those Brits and their tragedy!!! lol But of course I had to come back for more and was not disappointed. Planning on joining my daughter and friends for next years season premiere at a big celebration. Why not? We are all hooked, and it will be tons of fun! Yes we will be dressing the part!

My husband and I love the show until they killed off Mathew but knowing he wanted to leave we decided to keep watching. Then we watched episode 2 of this new season!!!! SPOILER ALERT!! Why, Why does this show kill off their best characters. Then anybody still worth watching the show for they rape and beat them up. Anna is one of the really decent characters they have left and they  destroyed the one pure thing about it. We were so sickened by that scene that my husband has written the show off. I know keeping it real is what ratings are about in all shows but does this show have to be like every other trashy show out there?  I'm hanging by a thread!
love this show!  Great new story line under way.  If you haven't watched the previous seasons it won't make much sense.
Downton Abbey has continued to keep my interest and can hardly wait for new episodes. Great cast and production! The sets and costumes are fabulous.

I watch Downton Abbey on PBS channel 13.  I have enjoyed the first three seasons.  Love, love.  Last night premiered episode 3 of season 4 and I am totally disgusted with what happened to Anna.  What I witnessed was unreal and very bothersome.  I won't say what as some of you may not have seen it yet.  But I had to get online this morning to read some reviews of other viewers.  Yes, this is a British soap but just as our soap's here in the US can get bothersome and disgusting so can this one.

I agree with so many of the reviews on what they've witnessed.  But what happened on last night's episode was off-the-hook for me!  I might continue to tune it just to see justice done, but, honestly, I'm hanging by a thread.

Raggedy, just raggedy.

In addition, I've noticed that the run time for episode 3 of season 4 is 50 minutes.  Well, on PBS we get a full 60 minute episode and no commercials.  So something is missing from the Prime video and most likely the UK version which I believe is the same.  That's raggedy too.
Very frustrated as this is not episode 2, it's just the extended part of episode 1. Paid for something I've already seen. Please return my money!

With the number of staff dwindling and Lady Edith taking up with a married man who will have to go to lengths to obtain a divorce in order to marry her, as well as Lady Mary's adjustment to Matthew's death and to having an important part in the decision making processes of the Abbey, we can learn how well Lord and Lady Grantham will adjust to these more modern times.  The Dowager Countess (Maggie Smith) seems to always land on her feet.

Like most, I thought I would never watch again after Matthew's death. But I'm watching and after the first two episodes I'm loving it. Feisty, strong Mary is back and all the other story lines have pulled me in once again. Although, could we just get rid of Thomas once and for all!

I've loved this show from the beginning and purchased Seasons 3 and 4. Like everyone, I was shocked at the ending of Season 3, explained by the fact that they hoped the actor playing Matthew would renew his contract, but he did not. Having watched all of Season 4 now, I have to say it feels like the author needed to fill time/space created when a few actors didn't renew, and after watching quite a few PBS and BBC programs, it appears they do tend to recycle a lot of actors through many different programs (and usually, they are very good actors), but maybe there is a limit to the number of "outside" actors they are allowed to use, and so it's difficult or too time-consuming to come up with entirely new characters that could require different actors, if there isn't a lot of lead time to plan. And the plot lines suffer as a result.

I still love this show, but agree there are some far-fetched story-lines here, that depend on showing the upstairs family as not very bright or thoughtful, even after all that has gone on previously, and the downstairs people as one-dimensional--either all good or all bad. They've almost turned "Lord Robert" and "Carson" into buffoons. I don't want to give away too much, but actually, that may be the problem I have with this Season: it's all either predictable or far-fetched, so I just didn't enjoy it as much as the first three.

I know they've said there is to be a Season 5, so hopefully, they have enough advance time to plan story lines, write dialogue, employ actors, and so create a better show for the rest of us to watch. Perhaps, Julian Fellows needs some help.

We started watching Downton Abbey because it was free on Prime. We knew nothing about the hype and popularity. (Now we've done our research and know that everyone's watching this series.)

Season 4 is just as good as the earlier seasons. The only advice I can give before you start to watch this season is that if you've not yet seen seasons 1 through 3, watch them first.
The story between the upstairs and downstairs characters is awesome! Love this show - it's fun to see the interaction between the upstairs and downstairs characters.

Appreciate how, among many other things, each character has a crucial role in the show. Also appreciated is the moral dignity that has been evident throughout the shows existence.
My family and I would recommend the show to anyone.
So happy that this is on again with a new season.  Can't wait to see next episode to see what happens with Mary and her Father.

As always Downton Abbey is coming back with new characters, new locations and I can't wait for each episode to come out.  I have all the Seasons ( 1, 2, and 3) on my Kindle Fire and couldn't wait for season 4 to start.  This has been one of my favorite TV shows that has come out the past few years.  I hope it continues for many years to come because Masterpiece Theater has had some of the best shows ever on TV.  One thing I like about my Kindle Fire, I can download the episode right away when it is shown on TV.
The drama always has an interesting twist and the characters draw you in to either love them or loathe them.
As with the other three seasons, this one promises to deliver a wonderfully well acted, well written show. The best show on televison.
This series is very compelling and draws you immediately into the lives of the characters.  Series 4 is well worth wathching

I was so looking forward to Season 4 and now I am hoping that it will improve quickly! I just don't understand how Cora could believe Thomas over Anna. and for Robert to believe that is just too much for me.  I hope this is resolved quickly but have a feeling this will be a storyline throughout the season. The addition of Edna was a total letdown. think it would have been a great story to have O'Brien give her notice in person--which I think she would have--rather than the anticlimatic scene of her sneaking out in the middle of the night.  I can only hope the storyline improves or I will just enjoy re-watching Seasons 1 - 3.

LOVE THIS PBS SERIES.  Couldn't wait for it to come back this month.  It's a well written and directed show.  The actors play their parts well; some you dearly love and some you have learned to hate (Thomas for example).
As usual the beginning of Season 4 of Downton Abbey was extraordianry. It was exciting and the story line kept you on edge and wanting more. What a great way to begin a new season!
We love this series. Well written and great acting. We love tuning in to watch how the independently wealthy live and react to certain situations.
The culture and history of "the help" and "the royalty" captivates the viewer!  Love the plot twists and surprises within each episode.
As usual the dialogue is wonderful, especially when it comes to that of "granny" Smith. A few of the plot points are a total stretch, but we let them pass because we like everything else so much.
I wasn't sure how I'd like it now that Matthew is gone, but the remaining characters are still great. There 's also a healthy smattering of new folks to keep the story moving forward.
An interesting and surprising storyline. Love this whole series and hope it never ends.  Recommend it to all my friends..
I was wondering how the plot was going to play out after the death of Matthew, but it got off to a great start!
Best show on television! You are pulled into each of  characters lives! There are twists and turns to the story! And you can watch it with your whole family!!!
I love that this movie goes back to core values of Love, Service, Compassion, yet I still see some of the struggles that we have today with Jealousy and competition with others.
Never fails to enchant.  Great acting, great story, great characters.  Wish there were more like this.  So many intertwining stories about the characters lives.

In one of the scenes of Season 4's first show, there's a scene where Moseby, the former butler for Isabelle Crawley is trying out for another butler's position by way of a recommendation from Lady Grantham; Dame Maggie Smith. And it is so funny when the (outgoing, jealous butler) makes Moseby jump when he yells "Watch it" and then hands poor unsuspecting Moseby a hot serving platter, that he immediately drops in burning pain.  If anyone has a chance to watch that scene over again as I have, because I recorded it.  You will just fall out laughing everytime you see it !  The servants in DA can be quite devious, and terribly hateful toward one another.  And it is wrong to be this way toward another fellow human being.  However, that scene has me chuckling everytime I think about it.

You have got to see it !
Historical fiction at it's best.  Beautiful castles and costumes.  I love the characters and plot lines too.  Awesome show, my husband and I are hooked!!
Fantastic period program. Can always count on PBS bringing in good wholesome shows for the entire family. I highly recommend it.

We bought season 2 & 3 partly based on the fact we would get season 4 included.  Since we don't own a Huku, or xbox,etc we can't stream it. Our current blueray player is not compatible with Amazon's system. I called Amazon's help desk. They said someone would contact me with a solution. That was 5 days ago. No call yet. Poor service and false advertising

I've already seen the whole season, and by the third episode I thought Julian Fellowes was going to drag season 4 out as he did three, but he managed to redeem himself by the end of this season. Though this season is not on the same level as 1 & 2, it isn't AS ridiculous as season 3. I do wish the season ended better though.

I really do think he should have just ended this show by season 2 as he originally planned.

I love being able to subscribe to this show and then get the episodes as they are shown on air. It is such an excellent show that I like to watch it over because sometimes its easy to overlook something. It is well worth the money and plays excellent on my new Kindle Fire 8.9 HDX as well as on Amazon on demand on my Smart Tv. So nice not having to get up and look for the dvd before playing it and it will never wear out.

Tried to watch this online for free at the Masterpiece Theater site and it wouldn't go so I PAID for this and it doesn't work! What a rip off! If you are charging for this IT SHOULD WORK!! I want my money back!

So Love this Show
Great Characters, Costumes, and Story line
I Love Getting Lost in it the show Sunday Evenings
I enjoyed the costumes, actors, Scenery.  However, the story line was a bit "soap operaish" .  Still it is a very well done work and work viewing.
Amazing every single time! So well done.....,I am never dissappointed with this show. I look forward to it every season.
Love this time period! Can not wait to see more of season 4.  Please provide more shows like this.  Thanks
This is an excellent series and gives one an insight into the struggles of the twentieth century.  One easily get swept into the family life at Downton Abbey.

Season 4, episodes 1 and 2  of Downton Abby are GREAT!  Looks like an interesting beginning to a new season with new characters and interesting problems to solve.  I can't wait to see the rest of the episodes.  Highclere Castle looks better than ever.  I especially liked the sacking of the nanny scene!
Just started watching this show in the last week.  Really got addicting.  Maybe a bit over-dramatized at times but isn't that what soaps are about ?

A period piece that lives up to its hype with every episode (so far!).  The start of this season appears very promising, and viewers have not been viewers heretofore it should stimulate them to go back to the beginning.

The high quality of the acting, photography, set design, together with a meticulous re-creation of the clothing, automobiles and furniture of the World War I era draws me into the sometimes funny, sometimes deadly serious stories, several of which are told by each episode.
This is an amazing and truly captivating series! America has lost it's dramatic creativity but very happy to see the UK has picked up the ball! Keep up the great work!

I thoroughly enjoyed Seasons 1, 2 & 3 of Downton Abbey. Then I saw the Journey to the Highlands and the first 3-4 episodes of Season Four. Are Julian Fellows and the series writers just taking their cues from the pulp writer's formula of "piling on more grief" or have they simply run out of creative ideas? Not only are they adding massive melodrama, but they are doing in a way such that two major characters are acting completely out of character. This is not how characters grow, this is how they grow stilted and die. About the only two interesting character lines left are Mary's and Tom's -- but these are only touched on sometimes, while the focus is on the melodramatic plot lines. I honestly don't think I will continue to watch the DVD set of Downton Abbey Season 4. It's too sub-standard.
The accuracy of the period sets compensates for the sometimes predictable 'soap' like plot. The scenes and historical references are interesting.  Maggie is awesome as usual!

No matter how much the producers are paying the writers of this show, it is not enough.  The first two episodes of the new season were wonderfully complex, and one feels as though the characters are real.  Superb television.
Have been looking forward to it, enjoyed it, new kindle was terrific, but I felt it was just introducing topics for later shows.
I Love Dowtown Abbey, it is by far the classiest drama on Tv :) I can tell this season is going to be full of it!
I am always amazed at the twist, when the heck is Barrows going to get his just rewards. this season?
Very excited about the new season and the new cast members! I do miss the old ones, and wish they didn't keep killing them off so young!
Love this show! The cast, the sets, the acting, the plots, the drama... everything is superb. I highly recommend this show to everybody!

After waiting almost a year for the continuation, I was not disappointed.
Maybe the fact that it is not week after week, all year, gives it more substance.
The characters and story line is great!  The best, clean decent show I've seen in a long time!  Hope it stays on for much longer
I just can't get enough of Downton Abbey.  I was so excited for the new season to start.  Although I must say that we will all miss "Matthew" I think that is his name.
Epic fail: Miss the Season 4 premier!  Thanks to Amazon, I was able to catch up!  Excellent quality, and now I didn't miss a thing .  $2.99 for Prime members, though :-/
Excellent pick-up from Season 3, which btw is the "hanger of hangers!" Highly recommend the whole series. Go for it.
I love this show.  Finally got to U.S.  The characters are great, love that the maids, butlers, cooks, etc. are treated kindly by the Lord and Ladies and love Maggie Smith.

Honestly I can't write anything that has not been written before. This is by far one of the best series I have ever watched. I even bought the season pass because I had to have it before anyone else. I highly recommend!

Very good development of the characters and plot. I cannot wait
to watch the next episode this coming Sunday night!
I am a big Downton fan. The show continues to intrigue me with plot twists and turns. I can't wait for the next episode.

So pleased to have quality, dignity, pure entertainment back on TV.
Well done. Looking forward to the season of Downton.

I love the propriety of these characters as they plunge into the true "age of liberation" of the 20th Century.  Every character is learning the moral theorem they need to proceed in life, and I can't wait to see what comes next.

They have a lot to recover from with all the deaths of young people in previous seasons especially Matthew. The next couple who gets pregnant on that show should get very nervous given the odds of survival for one of them based on past story lines!! Need some lasting good news for a couple.

Just like so many others! Yes it's a soap opera but so well done. I lone Maggie Smith. She's my favorite. I have loved this time period for years, and women's suffrage, although it's in England. The acting is terrific and the characters well developed. Interesting relationships between the aristocrats, between the syaf and between the aristos and staff. I highly recommend to anyone who loves a well developed story, theme, and characters.
Fabulously entertaining.  If you like British shows, you will love this one.  The characters are great and the story is remarkable.
PBS shows this too late for me to watch and I intend to see it every week on my Kindle Fire.  Upstairs and downstairs, so much is going on.  Love it.
Downton abbey is just a unique with great dialogue, costumes and story. It's nice to see that you don't need a murder every episode to have a good show unlike most shows nowadays.
It grabbed me at the start. What a great lead into the new season. Ready for more. Can't wait! Bring it on!

Really enjoy this program and they always have surprises like the death of Mathew to keep you engaged with what is happening. Is so easy to get wrapped up in what is happening on the screen. This is in my Amazon library so I can watch at anytime and also see the episodes in order if I want to do a Abbey binge watching.

They did not show the death of Mary's husband.  It is already assumed.  Mary mopes around speaking in a monotone voice for the full first episode.  The most exciting event that occurred was the fact that O'Brien left to be a lady's maid for a relative.  Will Elizabeth McGovern learn how to dress and bathe herself?  Stay tuned for that exciting event!!! Yawn.  I fell asleep while watching this.  I do hope it picks up.

Was sad to see Matthew die, his character still had so much growth.  But, now we get to see Mary take charge and that will make heads roll.  I hope they finally build Edith into the strong thinking woman they started last season.  So far a great start.
I love this TV pass!  It's so nice not having cable and being able to watch my favorite shows.  This show is amazing and fantastic.
Best series on tv hands down. The only ones close to it is Upstairs Downstairs or maybe Are you being served.
Long wait it seemed but was worth the wait. Can't wait for next episode. It promises to continue being a classic.
I thought I would not like the show with Mathew gone...but it is just as good...maybe they can work him back in...like in a dream or something...just for our hearts

Amazon doesn't seem to like anyone telling you that you can get this free at the pbs website. I am rewriting this review without the actual link to the pbs network website, in hopes that they will not reject it again. You can watch current episodes there absolutely free.
Yes, I do enjoy the series and from what I can see it will continue to be superior TV.  I just felt that they had introduced too many different plots/problems for the characters at once.

The story moves on at a good pace and does not labor a point and drag on & on.
Characters are complex and not jone demention, good or bad but complex like humans.
Can't wait for Season 5. So glad I pre ordered the Season 4 DVD.

I found this series and really enjoy the story and characters. Good casting. Interesting story. Great costumes and the background is interesting to see too. Nice surprise to find a great series like this. Well done!

It seems that true effort went into all the effects in this series.  I am amazed by the clothing, the cars and the furnishings in the abbey.  Sorry that Michael left as he was a real bright spot in the show.  No, I have never watched a soap or series before.
Starting off a little slow as always but I know it will continue to get better and better. Good show!

Julian Fellowes does a masterful job of describing the differences between the social classes in England in the early 20th century and the struggles each individual in the story endures as he or she comes face to face with the changing cultural standards in a new century - from Isobel's distress that her widowed daughter-in-law should inherit very little from her deceased husband while the widow's infant son is "as rich as Croesus," to Mrs. Patmore worrying that the advent of electrical kitchen appliances will usurp her role as cook.

This is the very best series that I have ever had the pleasure of watching I can hardly wait for the next weeks viewing.
Thank you Martha Leddy
Does this have the Christmas special?  I watched the first and saw I saw somwhere that it does-Does it? I really am fond of this show.

Seems like their doing a lot of setting up for what will happen. The message seems to be "moving forward". If that's the case and there are over 12 episodes, then great. But if not, would give it a star less.  We shall see.

I can't get enough of this series, I hope that it continues for a few more years. The pacing and characterization is perfect, plenty of twists and subplots keep the suspense and intrigue going throughout. I want to watch it all in one sitting, like a good book. Bravo to season 4!
This is a great series, love all the characters! The authenticity of the wardrobe and teh Abbey are exquisite. A must watch.
have not seen it,buyt  if it is as good as the previous seasons . they were great probably better than the other junk ouy there.
Great story great cast great production super - not much else to say except it is a great series yea
The Abbey is buzzing for the new year.  Overcoming tradegy and going forward in Season 4 will be great in 2014.
Love Downton Abbey... sorry that one of the main characters was killed off but the new season looks like there will be lots of new interests coming up.

...and some new people. Downton still has the magic, like going home for Christmas. Downstairs, upstairs, all around the house, the Brits have a talent for this sort of thing.  You keep expecting Winston Churchill to pop out from beneath one of the tapestries.
Love this season of Downton Abbey.  I am enjoying the new people who have joined the show. Can not wait for next week!
i AM A HUGE FAN,  LOVE THE SHOW, CAN'T WAIT TO WATCH THE SEASON PLAY OUT OVER THE NEXT FEW WEEKS.

Maybe it just doesn't work without Matthew and no amount of filler can paste it back together! I watch it, but almost am bored. The familiar characters are comfortable, if predictable. The witty lines are few. The clothes are great, Mary goes from widow's black to many shades of purple. I enjoy it as I once did when I watched soap operas after school, to fill my afternoon. Basically, nothing is happening, but another episode has passed with the folks of Downton Abbey.
Great opening after being off for so long! I missed Thomas' conniving ways.  Mary come back in full force! Don't let your dad hold you in your grief
This series is wonderful as far as I am concerned. Look forward to each new episode and season! I hope it lasts a long time.
This show is fabulous.  I'm glad to see Mary coming alive at the end of the first episode.  Can't wait till next week!
Fascinating plot twists.  Well written, well casted, and well acted.  I especially enjoy Maggie Smith's portrayal of the dowager countess.  She is wonderful!
too much information at once.but I am hopeful!  I loved seeing everyone again and the new babies are adorable, of course.  Nice to see some depth in the main characters.

I love Downton Abbey but on several occasions there was a pause or need to reload. I thought you gave me a credit , yet my CC was charged?  I would not have ordered it but for the credit. Can you help me?

Love lost.  Family and friends say snap out of it.  Way too much concern to protect emotional feelings of loss with hint of other self interests.  OK, I guess I must channel my energy into new endeavors now that I think I will never get over my loss of love.
Good story and you strangely get sucked in to all the characters. Now enjoying the latest episodes on PBS.org for free. :)
Downtown Abbey is definitely an evening, high brow soap, but it's fun.  Except maybe for the dad's patriarchal patronizing.  Oh well,
This show is so well written. The costuming is gorgeous and the set is so accurately decorated. Love love love!

If you are a Downton Abbey fan, you love it.  If not, you either haven't seen it or it is just not your thing.  Wonderfully performed, beautifully filmed, and fascinating characters.  Something for everyone.
It's only just started but it is not disappointing me at all.  It is just a s good so far as the previous seasons

The writing is excellent and the characters are all interesting.  It may be a soap opera, but it is superb!  It is easy to care about the lives of these people.  They seem real in an historical context.

It's refreshing to watch a program that's entertaining and gives its viewers the courtesy of thinking we're intelligent, and that we appreciate the authenticity with which this series is presented. Thank you Masterpiece for, once again, hitting the mark!
This show is top notch entertainment! The attention to detail, love of the actors snd crew for what their doing is amazing.
As usual the cast and story-line are excellent. Just the first episode, but I expect it to be as classy. witty and intriguing as ever.
I have never been disappointed with this excellent period series.  The 2 hour premier went by so fast, too fast.  I plan to watch every episode!!

Technically speaking, as a production, I find it nearly flawless, other than a few script and character choices. Killing off Mathew because the actor wanted out of the series seemed a poor, poor choice, a senseless murder in my opinion. There must be a thousand other lovely young blonde boys that could have filled the role and I wouldn't have been offended.  If he'd done a good job we wouldn't have missed his predecessor.

Acting, costumes, sets, camera work, music, location, attention to detail...are we sure this isn't a real place and all the men and women real players?  Where the heck is Isis in Season 4?  Did she quit, too? We knew O'Brian had to go, wished it anyway.  Bringing Braithwate back, really, with a new hair color? Glad to see most of the family in tact and downstairs, too.

After the two deaths during Season 3, both after the birth of a child, I began to wonder if the writers of this show were getting pretty lazy. Then, we have one conflict after another, as if the writers think the viewers will jump up and turn off the TV if something doesn't happen to someone every other minute.  How many conflicts do you need in one 2- hour episode?  That episode is definitely going to make it easier for me to totally stop watching the show, if I decide to do so.  After reading of the horrific thing that is going to happen to sweet Anna in the next episode, there is a very good chance that I am going to do so, too.  Julian Fellowes obviously doesn't realize how many viewers watch "Downton Abbey" for entertainment and escape.  That's too bad and too sad.

Afterthoughts 1/14:  I am really going to miss Violet, Edith, Mrs. Hughes, Daisy, Mrs. Patmore, Anna, Mr. Bates, Mr. Carson, Isobel, Dr. Clarkson, Mr. Molesley, Sir Anthony, Ethel and Miss O'Brien.  I did not watch the episode last Sunday night about Anna, and will never watch another new episode.  I am finished.

I am finished being jerked around by Julian Fellowes, when he's in the mood to add a strong dose of "realism" to a show that is ironically based on a fantasy--the fantasy  that the upstairs and downstairs residents were like one big, caring family back in the early 1900s. Mr. Fellowes should have stuck to his fantasies, and continued entertaining us with an astoundingly addictive and fun to watch show.

I was flabbergasted by the recycled dialogue, the lack of spark that now exists between this ensemble of suburb actors. I think Mr Fellows has seriously lost a handle on what drew me to this sensational show to begine with. Somehow the honesty, and humanity of all characters had me identifying and hanging on the edge of my seat. Nothing happened in this episode ,expect Mary moping, a nanny gets sacked because of Thomas' continuing bad behavior, Valentines cards have all the excitement of a wet edition of the daily paper. There is even a sense in Dame Maggie Smith that the zingers she has excelled at , are not filled with the insouciant humor that has marked all of her remarks in the past and she is frankly not sure how to bring them off any more than she can. The changes in dress, machines, etc are done rather than with a sense of humor mixed with anxiety practically without emotion. I am astonished that this series could so completely lose its delicate balance of ensemble acting, fine writing, visual feasts , to become practically mundane. My goodness what has happened Mr. Fellows ?

My wife and I loved Downton Abbey from the first episode. To an extent, we still think very highly of it.

But we watched the first two episodes of Season 4 last night and, when they ended, heaved a big "meh."

There are a number of problems with Season 4 of Downton Abbey:

CAUTION: MIGHT BE SPOILERS AHEAD!

1. Thomas is still there, and still a colossal pain in the ass. Despite being one of the most despicable people at Downton Abbey, nearly universally disliked by every other character, Thomas is still employed at D.A.

2. Now that Miss O'Brien is gone (she left in the middle of the night without telling anyone), Cora Crawley needs a new Lady's Maid. Enter Edna, who more or less tricks her way back into D.A. by answering an ad to be Miss O'Brien's replacement. The character was without scruples when we last saw her; she's not improved now, and quickly forms an alliance with Thomas.

3. So, once again, Thomas is paired with a woman - this time Edna - to wreck havoc on the other servants at D.A.

4. The problem with that is two-fold: (a) the person they chose to stab in the back is Anna. Anna! The sweetest, most compassionate and kind member of the staff; and (b) the Earl and Countess of Grantham actually believe Thomas and Edna when they speak ill of Anna. Cora Crawley, apparently not the sharpest crayon in the box, always took the side of Miss O'Brien, too. But now she's taking the side of a brand new Lady's Maid against Anna! How can that be? Can Cora and Robert Crawley really be that bad a judge of character? When Robert confronted Bates to tell him to keep Anna in check, my wife and I looked at each other and shook our heads. Would Robert have done that? Does he not know what kind of people Bates and Anna are?

5. The fact that we now have nearly the same configuration of characters we did in Season 1, with the nearly the same conflict, tells me that Julian Fellowes is out of ideas. Now he's just recycling what came before, only setting it in a new year (1922, if I recall the super on the screen correctly). Characters who do not change, who remain the same, are really bad, two-dimensional characters. Cora Crawley hasn't changed. She's still a dimwit. Thomas hasn't changed. He's still a manipulating scuzz ball. Bates and Anna are still the moral center of Downton Abbey. But now that Thomas and Edna are set on attacking them, I'm afraid we're ready to stop watching.

We enjoyed Season 1-3 and watched them religiously. A few of them made us cry. We really got into the characters and the stories.

But something feels really off about Season 4. Or maybe something feels precisely on. Everyone is exactly the same. And if all Julian is going to do is recycle the same conflicts (usually with Thomas and his female cohort), then we've got better things to do with our time.

If you are on Season 4, you know if you love this show or not.  But for those of us with Prime who do not want to wait, the show is available on PBS's website - new episode each week until the series is over. You have to sit through a couple of 30 second commercials, but I am ok with that.

Loved this show. But after seeing the first episode of series 4 it is clear that the original storyline is no longer going to thrill and intrigue us as it did. The Jane Austinish "entailment" issue ended with both the birth of little George and the death of Matthew. In fact that could have easily been the end of the series altogether. All the threads had been woven together well enough to call it quits. As Julian Fellows said, Had Matthew lived it would have been a series of scenes where he and Mary discussed and argued about the running of Downton etc. As it is now a whole new group of characters enter in tell a whole new story, while the principles sort of sit back and react but have rather little to do. I'll still watch, as I did the last 2 or 3 seasons of X-Files, but the spark had gone and I'm afraid the same applys to Downton Abbey. I own the series on discs and I think I will do what I've done with other films whose endings I do not like. I'll trim the part where Matthew has his accident and go to Mary lovingly holding her baby and that will be the end of the show. Matthew is driving home smiling and Mary is serene...and they lived "Happily Ever After".

I cannot imagine Cora at this point offering to take care of Mrs. Hughes like she did at the beginning.
Generally, it seems to be more like season 2 were they are in the shadow of war and they are not sure if Matthew and Mary will get together than Season 1 or Season 3 (my favorite) where there is more hope and glitter.

For those who don't just swoon over something out of habit, I think most actual viewers will acknowledge (with regret) that something is definitely off about the opening episode(s) of DA's Season 4.  To me, the first hour was just tedious with a now very unsympathetic Mary, who actually seems more disgruntled than grieving.  Her self-absorption carries a bitter bite and less interest than usual in anyone but herself, including her child.  However, the second hour picked up, along with Mary's spirits.

Overall though, that unmistakable vital edge we have become accustomed to with DA was sorely lacking, rendering the whole rather flat, acting included.  The scenes in the downstairs area particularly palled for the first time, especially some in the kitchen.  Same great people, but the fire is missing. Even Maggie Smith's parts were lackluster.  There's a point where the best actors cannot overcome trite dialog and boring recycles of old themes.

I had understood formerly that Julian Fellowes is involved in at least one other large project, and perhaps that explains what seems a lack of due diligence to this one.  Even with that, he seems to be diminishing his main characters in stature and depth while escalating devious and underhanded elements. His current presentation appears to be going in the way of his "Gosford Park," where everyone was foibled - and worse.

Whatever it is, overall and in several key areas like the writing, directing and now some of the acting, unless this one picks up with continuing episodes, it is destined to end in a fizzle, a shadow of its former self.

Regardless, I will cherish my first two seasons DVDs as they will always carry the vibrant pulse and excellence that set Downton Abbey apart.
The plots are intertwined and catch the viewers attention and pulls them in.  The Downton Abby series has peaked my curiosity and makes me wonder what will happen next.

British viewers have already viewed Season 4, or The fourth series, as we would say over here, and in my humble opinion it's the best one yet.  Julian Fellowes writes brilliant conversation pieces with brilliantly conceived characters.  However, his plots seem a bit improbable at times.  The character, 'Matthew' had to be written out because the actor hungered for greener pastures thereby giving Fellowes the headache of how to remove him from the show permanently halfway through his storyline without destabilising the whole season's plot.
As for the reviews and previews submitted so far, there appears to be a dividing line between those who hunger for more action, and those who feel they have had rather too much of it already.  This stretches our credulity at times, and  those who are looking forward to a little more fun without any major disasters removing yet more of our favourite characters, will have much to celebrate in Season 4.  Meanwhile, we await this year's Christmas Special with bated breath.

Region B/2 is Europe only.  While previous seasons have had UK releases that were Region A1/B2 and playable in the US, Season 4 is not.  Amazon has not prominently/clearly labeled this fact in the current listing.

Please be careful to select the correct region coding.

I yield to no one in my appreciation of Julian Fellows's genius.  Downton Abbey is the best thing I've seen since I can remember and Season Four is terrific.  After all the turmoil and tension and bad feeling and heartbreak displayed in Season Three, Season Four comes as a healing wave.  The outstanding characteristic of this season is the flood of love that surrounds this house.  There are all kinds of non-romantic love duos: Violet and Isobel; Rosamund and Edith; Violet and Edith; Mary and Tom; Mrs. Patmore and Daisy, and others.

However, as wonderful as this sense of peace and love is, I find that Julian Fellows has gone off the rails once again and written a scenario that is so implausible as to be unbelievable and this one is the latest in a trend.  Once a year Fellows flits off into never-never land and writes a scene that is impossible to credit.  First was Bates's trial; then we had the episode with Tom Branson's drugged cocktail and now there is the attack scene in Season Four.  Since the producers of Downton Abbey tell us in the bonus material how careful they are to be historically accurate why isn't someone checking Fellow's work before it is produced.

Consider:  with young women today and even teen-aged girls engaging in every kind of sexual activity, with date-rape drugs rampant and after 40 years of women's liberation - men of today look at women very, very differently than did the men of the 1920s.  Most women in the 1920s came to marriage a virgin.  Women were cherished.  Women were protected.  In this environment, therefore, there is no way that a visiting servant would think that he could attack one of the Downton Abbey staff and get away with it.  The perpetrator would have to assume that the victim would tell the housekeeper who would tell the butler who would tell Lord Grantham and although the perpetrator probably wouldn't have been lynched, at the very least he would have been horsewhipped.  Only the viewing audience knows why the victim wouldn't have told anyone and I can assure Julian Fellows that none of us passed that information along to the perpetrator.

Under no circumstances would the perpetrator have returned to the concert, bid his victim good night and casually sauntered into breakfast the next day unless he was insane.  He would have been anxious to put as much distance between Downton Abbey and himself as quickly as possible.  I am not asserting that women were never attacked in the 1920s but this scenario as written is completely unbelievable.

I cannot understand why Julian Fellows, as hugely talented as he is, goes off on these weird tangents every so often and writes material that is so obviously impossible.  These bouts of irrationality are becoming a trademark.  There is another coming up in the 2013 Christmas Special in which a 21-year-old Rose will have her debut season.  I wrote about this in the review of the 2012 Christmas Special where it was hinted at.

We were introduced to Rose at the end of Season Three.  She was 18.  In the 2012 Christmas Special "one year later" Rose was 19.  Season Four is six months later and Rose is 19-20.  The Christmas Special for 2013 is going to be about Rose's debut season and will take place in the following year: Rose will be 20-21.  Here we have another ridiculous implausibility.  The only reason why the Marquess and Marchioness of Flintshire would not have had their daughter presented when she was 18 - as everyone else did - was if she was in a sanitorium in Switzerland with TB - or for some equally serious medical reason.

Fellows doesn't even try to explain why the girl was not presented along with all the other 18- year- olds; why her parents would have flouted tradition.  He ignores reality again and again and then boasts of the historical accuracy of the series.  I wonder if there are two Julian Fellows - one rational, talented Dr Jekyll and an irrational persona who every so often comes to the surface and writes material that is so ludicrous as to be unbelievable.  A 21-year-old debutante would be the laughingstock of the season.  Poor Rose.
it is a fascinating and delightful window on the world of historic England, with superb actors and costuming of the early 20th century
Has all the elements of good story telling, interesting individual stories, good acting and best of all great visual scenes typical of the Edwardian era.

I love to be entertained and I love seeing things from a different perspective. Downton Abbey is visually pleasing, well written, in most cases well acted and opened my eyes to some historical & lifestyle aspects. I HATE history but love things like this and "North and South" which weave non-fiction with fictional characters so I'm actually LEARNING in an entertaining way. DA lets us peek into the lives of not only the wealthy but also he servants. We learn that being poor doesn't mean you can't be happy nor does being rich prevent you from experiencing grief and heartache.

Great story line, and acting. The traditions are neat, and I love how servants had integrity, and dignity.  As well as how the family truly cares for them, I like to think that was more the norm back then.  I just finished Season 3 this morning, can't believe 2 great losses in one season!

All my friends were talking about it from seeing it on tv.  We ordered it and me and my husband loved the series so much we order the last one.

Linda

Absolutely crackling with inaction, positively palpitating with procrastination, and racing along with all the speed of treacle flowing uphill, this Fourth Series of "Downton Abbey" really doesn't go anywhere, or advance the story much at all.
Keep your eyes riveted on the flower arrangements during the first two episodes, because that's where all the action is.
And those much talked about production values are definitely slipping.
In the second table shot, ...(there are quite a few), eager eyes will notice that the fish knife of the third place setting is slightly askew. (Ho-hum!)
Oh and later on even those new-fangled electrical appliances manage to steal every scene they appear in. You know you're in trouble when the gadgets become the stars!

It's not until late in episode THREE that anything REALLY happens this time round. (And it's the ONLY significant event in the whole Season too!)
Before that it's just long lingering shots of Lady Rigor-Mortis (Mary) mooning and moping about in a semi-comatose state, dressed in her widow's weeds, and walking as though she has a broom handle secreted somewhere within her girdle.
She's just SO stiff and cold, and only livens up a little towards the last episodes, .....but it takes a tumble into some pig s*** to achieve this. Even that is so prettily handled that it manages to make the s*** look more like the finest Belgian chocolate. Which I'm betting it was for the shoot!
The storyline, ...(if you could call it that), tends to centre on Her Ladyship for this series but her mono-tonal delivery, white white skin, wraith-like appearance and inexpressive acting style are more suited to a haunting.....or a Mrs Danvers role perhaps?

The other characters are not given much to work with here.
Ladies Maid O'Brian is never seen. Just an anonymous pair of legs and a suitcase doing an early morning flit from Downton at the very beginning of Episode One. We are only told that it was indeed O'Brian that was leaving sometime later on.
Bates is reduced to constantly creeping about and lurking in the semi-darkness of the lower corridors looking like some resurrection of Dracula. He doesn't seem to have many duties upstairs as he spends all his time looming from the shadows to accost people and looking positively sinister! His scenes with his wife are actually quite creepy really. He is devoid of any warmth now.
Wife Anna manages some very difficult scenes well, ....but the situation she's in then gets stuck into some sort of hiatus and doesn't really develop until the very end five episodes later.

Long time devotees of this series will no doubt be pleased to hear that Elizabeth McGovern has maintained her acting style of tilting the head forward and peering myopically through her lashes.
It's comforting, because D.A. just wouldn't be the same without that.
The script seems to have forgotten that second daughter Edith was developing as a writer when we left Series Three, and having her articles published in a spirit of independence. It's not mentioned at all here.
Nor is her once fierce rivalry with Mary.
Dead Matthew's Mother Isobel Crawley mutates as we watch from her deep and quite touching mourning into something of a blend between Pollyanna, Florence Nightingale and Mother Theresa.
Maggie's Smith's jowl-quivering Dowager is now falling perilously close to caricature, but again she plays it very well, and her better acerbic one-liners can still raise a laugh.
Downstairs supervisor Mrs Hughes, who gets some of the best scenes to play, turns in a fine performance, but again, everybody is so "controlled" that all the excessive histrionics are left for the flighty little piece of new fluff upstairs, who is just so gushy and determined to be "thoroughly modern" that she seems to have walked in off the set of some amateur production of "The Boyfriend".(I was expecting her to break into "Won't you Charleston with Me" at any minute!)
Her cheesy grinning and over-acting was so supremely irritating and she seemed such an unnecessary and superfluous addition to the cast that I'd have left her back in ye banks and braes of the Scottish Highlands.
Dame Tiri Tekanawa has a brief cameo role as Australian opera singer Dame Nellie Melba, although her singing is the butt of some very derogatory remarks made downstairs by the new villain.
Oh and if you'd forgotten just how irritating that damned "ding-ding-ding-ding....ding-ding" theme tune can get, .....you are very quickly reminded again. It's repeated endlessly!

I call this the "Series of Non-Events".
Some examples here in no particular order. ( I have deliberately avoided any mention here of "THE ONE BIG DEAL" in the plot. Anything below is inconsequential.)
MINOR SPOILER ALERTS!!!
1/ Lady Rigor-Mortis has the opportunity to remarry, and to a very promising man who professes undying love.....but she doesn't.
2/Deceased Matthew's recently discovered but unwitnessed will may be disallowed, which would dis-inherit Lady Mary, ....but it isn't.
3/The new triumvirate now running Downton are all set to evict the heir of a very long term tenant from his family holding.......but they don't.
4/ It looks like a new young gardener is going to be unfairly dismissed for stealing bric-a-brac from Maggie Smith's drawing room, ...but he isn't.
5/ Maggie Smith's character is made out to be dying at one stage, ...but of course she doesn't.
6/ The ex-chauffeur now part Downton owner Tom Branson feels out of place in the upper class and plans to leave for America with his young daughter , ...but he doesn't.
7/ It looks like Tom Branson is to be trapped into marriage by an unscrupulous re-employed maid feigning an opportune pregnancy to marry up into the cushy life, ...but he isn't.
8/ It is made to appear that the young footman who has ambitions to be a chef misses his great opportunity at The Ritz, ...but he doesn't.
9/ Mr. Molesley, a desperate out-of-work ex-employee who is reduced to working on the roads appears to have missed his opportunity of filling a recent vacancy at Downton, ...but he doesn't.
10/ Mr Carson staunchly tries to maintain his decision not to have any contact with his old vaudeville partner, ....but he doesn't.
11/ Evil Thomas (yes, he has relapsed since his apparent redemption last season) appears to be planning some great and nefarious scheme to benefit himself, ...but he doesn't.
12/ At one stage there are fears that Bates' wife Anna may be pregnant, ...but she's not.
13/ That new flouncy young thing at Downton annouces she's going to marry a ....Gasp! Shock!.....BLACK band singer, much to everyone's horror....but she doesn't.

There are more than a few other examples, but suffice to say that the plotline consists of so many of these situations that have lots of potential, but then they are just allowed to fizzle out and the story creaks on maintaining the status quo as before.
Perhaps some of these ideas may be further visited in ....god help us, ...Series Five?

Well what did I enjoy I hear you ask?
It must be said that once again there are some most beautiful settings. The apartment of the Aunt in London is truly magnificent. (Furniture and decor to die for!) There are also those aforementioned scene-stealing flower arrangements and of course the exteriors and countryside locations are all breathtaking in their story-book beauty. The briefly glimpsed tenant's farm is immaculate post-card perfection. The vintage cars, motorcycles and London bus are an enthusiast's delight, .....and even of interest to those who just enjoy seeing such well-maintained vintage pieces.
The costumes too are truly sumptuous in their detail, ...although some particular dresses get rather too much wear. This may be a continuity problem but I can't see those upper class women turning up in the very same frock again and again in very quick succession.
Overall the eight episodes are a quick watch.
I managed this in two night sittings, and I guess for me the frustration came from the lack of any real tension, or development of any of the set-up situations. That and the sheer predictability of the thing. You always know exactly where this is going, and that makes it fall into the "coffee-table book" genre.
You pick it up just to glance through the beautiful pictures, ...and on that level it succeeds very well.
The potential was there for this to be so much more, but Fellowes seems reluctant to carry on his ideas from his initial concept to some sort of interesting narrative.
The cast move about in front of the gorgeous settings like stilted paper dolls, ..beautifully costumed to be sure but shackled by the author's restrictive idea of period.
Yes, we know that emotions were restrained back then, but it still has to hold interest for the viewer. A cast full of people all so doggedly maintaining that "stiff-upper-lip" do not make for engaging viewing.
If half-star ratings were allowed I'd make this a 2 overall, but as they are not I'm giving it the THREE stars, ....and that's primarily for the undeniable visual appeal.

There will of course be those who find all I've written above akin to heresy of the very highest order, but mistaking the style that this show has in abundance for substance which is almost totally lacking will no doubt be a common enough error.

The German politician Otto von Bismarck said once, smart people do not learn from their own mistakes, but from those made by others. By this definition, Julian Fellowes is not very smart... He makes the same mistake so many drama television series have made before him: Too much drama! After killing two(!) most beloved main characters in series three, he just keeps the catastrophes coming (though no more deaths, thankfully). While, on the one hand, some characters suffer terribly, on the other hand, nothing much happens in "the bigger picture". There is not enough character development, no progress to the historical aspects like WWI before. Better end a good series with an unspectacular happy ending than let it go on to get hit by tragedies again and again until it dies ungracefully. While the last episode ends without further misfortunes, I cannot help but anticipate the next blow. I adored the last shot of the last episode of series three (note: NOT the Christmas special!): Lord Grantham, a son-in-law in each arm, all three of them laughing. THAT would have been a good ending to a good drama television series.

With a global audience of over 125 million, Downton Abbey Season 4 is probably the most anticipated show this year.  This number of followers is set to increase as Chinese State TV has, apparently, just started to broadcast it, although what the average Chinese television viewer will make of the antics of the Crawleys I shudder to think!  This time round we pick up six months on from the tragic end to the Series 3 Christmas Special.

Downton has moved with the times, and, as usual, great care has been taken to make the setting, including all the small details, correct for the period.  Hence clothes and hair styles have changed and advances in technology, such as the telephone and even new fangled electric kitchen gadgets are evident.  The cast has all the significant characters who survived the last series, so Maggie Smith continues as the matriarch who dominates every scene she is in, and Shirley MacLaine makes a welcome reappearance after her all too brief involvement in the previous series.  Seeing her sparring with Maggie Smith must be one of the more memorable aspects of this show.  There are some new faces to look out for, one of whom is Kiri Te Kanawa, the New Zealand opera singer as well as a couple of other well known characters in cameo roles.

More of the scenes this time round have been filmed on location in London.  Meanwhile at Downton itself, the antics and interaction of those `below stairs' continues to contribute some very interesting story lines and their trials and tribulations are, in many ways, one of the most interesting aspects of the show.  Above stairs initially Lady Mary is, understandably, rather subdued whilst Lady Edith really seems to be coming into her own having, perhaps, been somewhat overshadowed previously.  The producers have publicly promised no more deaths, at least for a while, but I will not be giving away any key parts of the plot here as I certainly do not want to spoil anyone's enjoyment!

Downton Abbey has certainly continued to go from strength to strength and has confounded those critics who thought it would peter out after a couple of series.  If you enjoyed the previous seasons then Season 4 is unlikely to disappoint, and there is every sign that the show is set to continue.  I do not believe any announcement has been made about Season 5 yet but apparently some of the key figures have already signed contracts for it.  However, personally I would not be surprised to see it run up to the 1930s in due course.  I certainly hope so!

For those of you interested in additional features this set includes 'The Making', The Downton Diaries and New Arrivals.

Edit in January 2014 - Just to clarify following a number of comments on the review.  This review was written when Season 4 was released in the UK three months ago.  The set issued in the UK did not include the Christmas Special episode which is the finale as it was not aired until December 25th.  However, this North American issued set being released on Jan 28th certainly does include the Christmas Special (even though it is subtitled UK Edition!) ie this set as sold here does include the Christmas Special. Hope this makes sense.

1. Anemic drama. Drama is agon or contest, conflict, clash, disputation, etc., between pro- and antagonist, one of each at least. Even when one side is hostile fate or what the gods, God, history, society, etc., fling, throw against the promulgated hero and his cohort. Even when alleged lackeys and other social inferiors, impudent or inept, pester our dear noble sire, they will have some purpose, cause, justification, inspiration, cleverness, or whatever it takes, to make them worthy opponents, make the drama dramatic. But in "Downton" all potentially dramatic conflict is glossed over, brushed aside, too easily, unconvincingly, like dandruff on the Earl's tux. Even the deaths are convenient. The show is more infomercial than drama -- a soft-core selling of certain country mansions and owners. Has tourist traffic there increased? Do more good citizens see the glamour of the top 1% and understand that they deserve more power? That little people should be happy to serve? 2. Strange rituals. A grown man dresses in a tuxedo to visit the bedroom of another grown man and help him, although he is able-bodied, get dressed into a fancier tuxedo, then finishes by brushing dandruff off the man's tux. Solemn, serious, like a religious ceremony. And this today has a fan-club. 3. Hollowness of mind. Indicated by the apparent dominance over the Earl of contact language, the function of language we use when we ask the most asked question in our language, "How are you?", and give the most given answer, "Fine, how are you?". Yes, necessary to some extent to establish that both sides know the language and its little rites of etiquette and are quite willing to obey these for the ease of relations or simply to get going. But what if all other functions of language -- and therefore thought and imagination -- and all social issues become mere extensions of this petty procedure and its superficiality, insouciance, and never go past these limits? When all questions and all answers are only repetition of formalities, customary chit-chat, ritualized trifles, signifying nothing but delusional shine around a hollow core or sordid mess? Call it entropy of spirit. What would Hamlet instead say, in mockery? Or Lear's bright fool? 4. The Earl's rite of dinner and coziness of mind and the social hierarchy must not be disturbed -- as if that's the height of all human endeavor: dinner impeccably served. Through the 19th century aristocrats were already portrayed as more often useless or feeble-minded or archaic than not, as educated philistines or hollow costumes on parade, yet still with dangerous power over others, and then were blamed more than others for the blinkered narrow-mindness which led to the disaster known as the Great World War. Yet all this is swept under the fancy rugs of Downton Abbey. Where is the Spanish Inquisition when you need it? And aren't these the people who inspired Monty Python? 5. Two antidotes to "Downton": The Remains Of The Day and Fanny and Alexander (The Criterion Collecton Theatrical & Television Version). In "Remains" the butler and housekeeper come to recognize that their superb efforts on behalf of the lord of the manor were wasted due to the latter's sheer banality of thought and imagination, too fogged to clearly see the realities confronting him. "Fanny and Alexander" presents drama about European urban haute bourgeoise civilization at its height near the turn of the century, a family engaged both for and against aims beyond smug dinner every day forever. 6. Fellini was a master of Dinner Disrupted. I'd love to see what he might have done with one long Downton dinner not going smoothly. When polite chit-chat and haute ritual pigging-out and obedient servants are confronted by something more substantial and subversive, with humor. My imagined scenario: one or two of the daughters on a trip to London meet a gang based somewhat on the Bloomsbury group and associates, and invite them to Downton where dinner then features the Earl and his family and other proper lords and ladies on one side of a long table, and on the other side characters loosely based on Virginia Wolf, her lover Vita, and Lytton Strachey, J.M. Keynes, Clive Bell, Bertie Russell and Alfie Whitehead, and T.S. Eliot and Aldous Huxley, and Lydia Lopokova too . . . After more than a few drinks, the guests become impudent, more lewdly loquacious, confrontative and rambunctious. It will end very badly of course, interestingly so. Set it in that cruelest month, April. 7. There are many buildings more admirable than Downton Abbey née Highclere Castle. The Scrovegni Chapel in Padua was financed in hope of atonement by a wealthy family famous for usury and therefore fearing punishment in Hell; Giotto's frescoes there offer a vision of Christianity at its best. The Palazzo dell'Accademia in Mantua was built, organized by aristocrats and other eminent citizens to promote knowledge and cultural advancement; its beautiful theater featured science demonstrations as well as art performances (the first musical evening presented a prodigy named Mozart). One can visit houses where Leonardo painted, Beethoven composed, Kafka wrote --all more admirable than the doings at Downton. Or sit in the Theater of Dionysus in Athens, or stand in front of the remains of Simon the Cobbler's shop where Socrates (not well-dressed) and his gang annoyed passers-by and talked of matters, questions unwelcome at Downton Abbey. I'd like to see more dramas set in these places, about these people. And the Baltimore housing projects in the first season of "The Wire" hosted more interesting conversations too. 8. "Tell me what you pay attention to and I will tell you who you are" -José Ortega y Gasset. The spiritual crisis of our age is revealed by our difficulty in differentiating between low and high, the slimy or stupid and the sublime, the tacky and the transcendent. Our most slavish, crude or mediocre appetitive inclinations have an easy time masquerading as something else. What's really presented for adulation? Call it Golden Calf Worship. Coarse Consumerism Dressed Up But Going Nowhere.

There is no other show on television that plays with our emotions and moods as successfully as Downton Abbey. The classy story of the Grantham family and the parallel world of their servants will involve you, thrill you, make you cry, laugh, cringe, and repeatedly draw you back for more. Sure it's a wee bit soapy, and some scenes border on the melodramatic and the sentimental, but heck, who cares? That's the entire reason it succeeds; it's pure unadultered escapism entertainment. Well that and Downton Abbey's superb cast, led by the impeccable Hugh Bonneville and the great Elizabeth McGovern, with the incomparable Maggie Smith giving a fiery supporting lead, with Paul Giamatti, Brendan Coyle, and Michelle Dockery rounding out the talented main cast. Add to that excellent cinematography, rich costumes, beautiful sets and scenery, and authentic dialogue, and you have the makings of a fine show indeed. But when you add to THAT the brilliant human emotion, tangled relationships, colorful, sympathetic characters, wry humour, and a smart, fast-paced plot...you have the makings of near-perfection as only Masterpiece Theatre can make. This is Downton Abbey, and while it is not as epic as Game of Thrones, or as riveting as Breaking Bad or Person of Interest, Downton Abbey is like no other show on television. Your moods will rise and fall with the episodes and the fate of your favourite characters, be it Nurse O'Brien (who we all love to hate), or Edith Crawley (who we all hate to love) and every time you pop in the disc, you will be swept away for a wonderful evening of escapism to the lush mansion of Downton. Here's to much Downtonian delight in the future! 4.5 Stars!

The origin of naming an English estate building "abbey" comes from Henry VIII giving confiscated Roman Catholic Church property (an abbey or a friary or a monastery) to English nobility (the aristocracy), as a reward for service to the king or, in the case of very powerful nobility, for simply supporting Henry in his "Great Matter", which was his quest to divorce Catherine of Aragon and marry Anne Boleyn, which lead to the separation of the English Catholic Church from the Church of Rome. The producers really should have sought out a structure that actually looks like an abbey (which Highclere Castle doesn't) or had Julian Fellows change the name of the estate. None of this makes a particle of difference, of course, to "Downton Abbey" which I absolutely love! I can't wait for Season 4!

I stumbled onto the first season of Downton Abbey quite by accident and enjoyed following both "families" upstairs and down. The writing is excellent and the story lines amusing and engaging. I enjoyed all of the seasons since and was surprised by the deaths of Sybil and Matthew, but not shocked. Both lead further into great drama and add the suspense of the "cliff hanger" for the next season to begin upon. The addition of the naughty cousin Rose may make some new inroads with the story line. With Mary now widowed with a son, and Tom now a widower with a daughter, who knows what tangled plot may now ensue? There is always more backstabbing and sneakiness to be sure between the likes of Thomas and Miss O'Brien, so I think all is not lost. Maggie Smith as the Matriarch is pure gold. She's my favorite! If a face could launch a thousand ships, her expressions could easily wipe out an entire Navy!! She's no sourpuss...she's just a powerhouse! She can say more with one look than most can say with pages of dialogue. I look forward to season 4 and hope there will be more.

I'm sure it was a decision he thought through completely before making it official. I'm sorry that Dan's left the series but I'm sure that Season 4 will be as great as Seasons 1-3.

If art imitated life than the wonderful ethical gracious character of Matthew (at the end of season three) would not have cheated his cast members, or his fans. He would have been more of a team player and not broken up this amazing ensemble group of the best theatre, story and characters I've ever seen. What work could he possibly have found more worthy to pursue than this classic timely tale of humans becoming more human, and the breaking down of the fable that the rich have it any easier than the poor. Downton Abbey is an important work. It is a piece of history and insight into both the past, present and future. A drama that shows that all of us are not always just good or bad, and the reasons we make the choices and mistakes that lead us all to grow, no matter how many pennies we have in our pockets, or pedigrees we hang on our family tree. I hope by the time the fourth season begins the infamous actor who played Matthew will have come to his senses, and the writers will act in the best interest of families everywhere and stop killing them off.

Definately 5*****
